   if you be here today — and I be very happy that you be — you 've all hear about how sustainable development will save we from ourselves . however , when we be not at ted , we be often tell that a real sustainability policy agenda be just not feasible , especially in large urban area like new york city . and that be because most people with decision - make power , in both the public and the private sector , really do not feel as though they be in danger .     the reason why I be here today , in part , be because of a dog — an abandon puppy I find back in the rain , back in 1998 . she turn out to be a much big dog than I would anticipate . when she come into my life , we be fight against a huge waste facility plan for the east river waterfront despite the fact that our small part of new york city already handle more than 40 percent of the entire city 's commercial waste : a sewage treatment pelletize plant , a sewage sludge plant , four power plant , the world 's large food - distribution center , as well as other industry that bring more than 60,000 diesel truck trip to the area each week . the area also have one of the low ratio of park to people in the city .     so when I be contact by the park department about a $ 10,000 seed - grant initiative to help develop waterfront project , I think they be really well - meaning , but a bit naive . I have live in this area all my life , and you could not get to the river , because of all the lovely facility that I mention early . then , while jog with my dog one morning , she pull I into what I think be just another illegal dump . there be weed and pile of garbage and other stuff that I will not mention here , but she keep drag I , and lo and behold , at the end of that lot be the river . I know that this forget little street - end , abandon like the dog that bring I there , be worth save . and I know it would grow to become the proud beginning of the community - lead revitalization of the new south bronx .     and just like my new dog , it be an idea that get big than I would imagine . we garner much support along the way , and the hunt point riverside park become the first waterfront park that the south bronx have have in more than 60 year . we leverage that $ 10,000 seed grant more than 300 time , into a $ 3 million park .     and in the fall , I be go to exchange marriage vow with my beloved . ( laughter )     ( applause )     but those of we live in environmental justice community be the canary in the coal mine . we feel the problem right now , and have for some time . environmental justice , for those of you who may not be familiar with the term , go something like this : no community should be saddle with more environmental burden and less environmental benefit than any other .     unfortunately , race and class be extremely reliable indicator as to where one might find the good stuff , like park and tree , and where one might find the bad stuff , like power plant and waste facility . as a black person in america , I be twice as likely as a white person to live in an area where air pollution pose the great risk to my health . I be five time more likely to live within walk distance of a power plant or chemical facility , which I do . these land - use decision create the hostile condition that lead to problem like obesity , diabetes and asthma . why would someone leave their home to go for a brisk walk in a toxic neighborhood ? our 27 percent obesity rate be high even for this country , and diabetes come with it . one out of four south bronx child have asthma . our asthma hospitalization rate be seven time high than the national average . these impact be come everyone 's way . and we all pay dearly for solid waste cost , health problem associate with pollution and more odiously , the cost of imprison our young black and latino man , who possess untold amount of untapped potential . fifty percent of our resident live at or below the poverty line ; 25 percent of we be unemployed . low - income citizen often use emergency - room visit as primary care . this come at a high cost to taxpayer and produce no proportional benefit . poor people be not only still poor , they be still unhealthy .     fortunately , there be many people like I who be strive for solution that will not compromise the life of low - income community of color in the short term , and will not destroy we all in the long term . none of we want that , and we all have that in common . so what else do we have in common ?     well , first of all , we be all incredibly good - look .     ( laughter )     graduate high school , college , post - graduate degree , travel to interesting place , do not have kid in your early teen , financially stable , never be imprison . ok . good .     ( laughter )     but , besides be a black woman , I be different from most of you in some other way . I watch nearly half of the building in my neighborhood burn down . my big brother lenny fight in vietnam , only to be gun down a few block from our home . jesus . I grow up with a crack house across the street . yeah , I be a poor black child from the ghetto . these thing make I different from you . but the thing we have in common set I apart from most of the people in my community , and I be in between these two world with enough of my heart to fight for justice in the other .     so how do thing get so different for we ? in the late ' 40 , my dad — a pullman porter , son of a slave — buy a house in the hunt point section of the south bronx , and a few year later , he marry my mom . at the time , the community be a mostly white , working - class neighborhood . my dad be not alone . and as other like he pursue their own version of the american dream , white flight become common in the south bronx and in many city around the country . red - lining be use by bank , wherein certain section of the city , include ours , be deem off - limit to any sort of investment . many landlord believe it be more profitable to torch their building and collect insurance money rather than to sell under those condition — dead or injure former tenant notwithstanding .     hunt point be formerly a walk - to - work community , but now resident have neither work nor home to walk to . a national highway construction boom be add to our problem . in new york state , robert moses spearhead an aggressive highway - expansion campaign . one of its primary goal be to make it easy for resident of wealthy community in westchester county to go to manhattan . the south bronx , which lie in between , do not stand a chance . resident be often give less than a month 's notice before their building be raze . 600,000 people be displace . the common perception be that only pimp and pusher and prostitute be from the south bronx . and if you be tell from your early day that nothing good be go to come from your community , that it be bad and ugly , how could it not reflect on you ? so now , my family 's property be worthless , save for that it be our home , and all we have . and luckily for I , that home and the love inside of it , along with help from teacher , mentor and friend along the way , be enough .     now , why be this story important ? because from a planning perspective , economic degradation beget environmental degradation , which beget social degradation . the disinvestment that begin in the 1960s set the stage for all the environmental injustice that be to come . antiquated zoning and land - use regulation be still use to this day to continue put pollute facility in my neighborhood . be these factor take into consideration when land - use policy be decide ? what cost be associate with these decision ? and who pay ? who profit ? do anything justify what the local community go through ? this be " plan " — in quote — that do not have our good interest in mind .     once we realize that , we decide it be time to do our own planning . that small park I tell you about early be the first stage of build a greenway movement in the south bronx . I write a one - and - a - quarter - million dollar federal transportation grant to design the plan for a waterfront esplanade with dedicated on - street bike path . physical improvement help inform public policy regard traffic safety , the placement of the waste and other facility , which , if do properly , do not compromise a community 's quality of life . they provide opportunity to be more physically active , as well as local economic development . think bike shop , juice stand . we secure 20 million dollar to build first - phase project . this be lafayette avenue — and that be redesign by mathew nielsen landscape architect . and once this path be construct , it 'll connect the south bronx with more than 400 acre of randall 's island park . right now we be separate by about 25 foot of water , but this link will change that .     as we nurture the natural environment , its abundance will give we back even more . we run a project call the bronx [ environmental ] stewardship training , which provide job training in the field of ecological restoration , so that folk from our community have the skill to compete for these well - pay job . little by little , we be seed the area with green - collar job — and with people that have both a financial and personal stake in their environment . the sheridan expressway be an underutilize relic of the robert moses era , build with no regard for the neighborhood that be divide by it . even during rush hour , it go virtually unused . the community create an alternative transportation plan that allow for the removal of the highway . we have the opportunity now to bring together all the stakeholder to re - envision how this 28 acre can be well utilize for parkland , affordable housing and local economic development .     we also build new york city 's first green and cool roof demonstration project on top of our office . cool roof be highly - reflective surface that do not absorb solar heat , and pass it on to the building or atmosphere . green roof be soil and living plant . both can be use instead of petroleum - base roofing material that absorb heat , contribute to urban " heat island " effect and degrade under the sun , which we in turn breathe . green roof also retain up to 75 percent of rainfall , so they reduce a city 's need to fund costly end - of - pipe solution — which , incidentally , be often locate in environmental justice community like mine . and they provide habitat for our little friend !     [ butterfly ]     ( laughter )     so cool !     anyway , the demonstration project be a springboard for our own green roof installation business , bring job and sustainable economic activity to the south bronx .     [ green be the new black ... ]     ( laughter ) ( applause )     I like that , too .     anyway , I know chris tell we not to do pitch up here , but since I have all of your attention : we need investor . end of pitch . it be well to ask for forgiveness than permission . anyway —     ( laughter )     ( applause )     ok . katrina .     prior to katrina , the south bronx and new orleans ' ninth ward have a lot in common . both be largely populate by poor people of color , both hotbed of cultural innovation : think hip - hop and jazz . both be waterfront community that host both industry and resident in close proximity of one another . in the post - katrina era , we have still more in common . we be at well ignore , and malign and abuse , at bad , by negligent regulatory agency , pernicious zoning and lax governmental accountability . neither the destruction of the ninth ward nor the south bronx be inevitable . but we have emerge with valuable lesson about how to dig ourselves out . we be more than simply national symbol of urban blight or problem to be solve by empty campaign promise of president come and go . now will we let the gulf coast languish for a decade or two , like the south bronx do ? or will we take proactive step and learn from the homegrown resource of grassroots activist that have be bear of desperation in community like mine ?     now listen , I do not expect individual , corporation or government to make the world a well place because it be right or moral . this presentation today only represent some of what I 've be through . like a tiny little bit . you 've no clue . but I 'll tell you later , if you want to know .     ( laughter )     but — I know it be the bottom line , or one 's perception of it , that motivate people in the end . I be interested in what I like to call the " triple bottom line " that sustainable development can produce . development that have the potential to create positive return for all concerned : the developer , government and the community where these project go up .     at present , that be not happen in new york city . and we be operate with a comprehensive urban - planning deficit . a parade of government subsidy be go to propose big - box and stadium development in the south bronx , but there be scant coordination between city agency on how to deal with the cumulative effect of increase traffic , pollution , solid waste and the impact on open space . and their approach to local economic and job development be so lame it be not even funny . because on top of that , the world 's rich sport team be replace the house that ruth build by destroy two well - love community park . now , we 'll have even less than that stat I tell you about early . and although less than 25 percent of south bronx resident own car , these project include thousand of new parking space , yet zip in term of mass public transit . now , what be miss from the large debate be a comprehensive cost - benefit analysis between not fix an unhealthy , environmentally - challenge community , versus incorporate structural , sustainable change . my agency be work closely with columbia university and other to shine a light on these issue .     now let us get this straight : I be not anti - development . ours be a city , not a wilderness preserve . and I 've embrace my inner capitalist . and , but I do not have —     ( laughter )     you you all have , and if you have not , you need to .     ( laughter )     so I do not have a problem with developer make money . there be enough precedent out there to show that a sustainable , community - friendly development can still make a fortune . fellow tedster bill mcdonough and amory lovin — both hero of mine by the way — have show that you can actually do that . I do have a problem with development that hyper - exploit politically vulnerable community for profit . that it continue be a shame upon we all , because we be all responsible for the future that we create . but one of the thing I do to remind myself of great possibility , be to learn from visionary in other city . this be my version of globalization .     let us take bogota . poor , latino , surround by runaway gun violence and drug trafficking ; a reputation not unlike that of the south bronx . however , this city be bless in the late 1990 with a highly - influential mayor name enrique peñalosa . he look at the demographic . few bogotano own car , yet a huge portion of the city 's resource be dedicate to serve they . if you be a mayor , you can do something about that . his administration narrow key municipal thoroughfare from five lane to three , outlaw parking on those street , expand pedestrian walkway and bike lane , create public plazas , create one of the most efficient bus mass - transit system in the entire world . for his brilliant effort , he be nearly impeach . but as people begin to see that they be be put first on issue reflect their day - to - day life , incredible thing happen . people stop litter . crime rate drop , because the street be alive with people . his administration attack several typical urban problem at one time , and on a third - world budget , at that . we have no excuse in this country , I be sorry . but the bottom line be : their people - first agenda be not mean to penalize those who could actually afford car , but rather , to provide opportunity for all bogotano to participate in the city 's resurgence . that development should not come at the expense of the majority of the population be still consider a radical idea here in the u.s . but bogota 's example have the power to change that .     you , however , be bless with the gift of influence . that be why you be here and why you value the information we exchange . use your influence in support of comprehensive , sustainable change everywhere . do not just talk about it at ted . this be a nationwide policy agenda I be try to build , and as you all know , politic be personal . help I make green the new black . help I make sustainability sexy . make it a part of your dinner and cocktail conversation . help I fight for environmental and economic justice . support investment with a triple - bottom - line return . help I democratize sustainability by bring everyone to the table , and insist that comprehensive planning can be address everywhere . oh good , glad I have a little more time !     listen — when I speak to mr . gore the other day after breakfast , I ask he how environmental justice activist be go to be include in his new marketing strategy . his response be a grant program .    on september 10 , the morning of my seventh birthday , I come downstairs to the kitchen , where my mother be wash the dish and my father be read the paper or something , and I sort of present myself to they in the doorway , and they say , " hey , happy birthday ! " and I say , " I be seven . " and my father smile and say , " well , you know what that mean , do not you ? " and I say , " yeah , that I be go to have a party and a cake and get a lot of present ? " and my dad say , " well , yes . but more importantly , be seven mean that you 've reach the age of reason , and you be now capable of commit any and all sin against god and man . "     ( laughter )     now , I have hear this phrase , " age of reason , " before . sister mary kevin have be bandy it about my second - grade class at school . but when she say it , the phrase seem all catch up in the excitement of preparation for our first communion and our first confession , and everybody know that be you all about the white dress and the white veil . and anyway , I have not really pay all that much attention to that phrase , " age of reason . " so , I say , " yeah , yeah , age of reason . what do that mean again ? " and my dad say , " well , we believe , in the catholic church , that god know that little kid do not know the difference between right and wrong , but when you be seven , you be old enough to know well . so , you 've grow up and reach the age of reason , and now god will start keep note on you , and begin your permanent record . "     ( laughter )     and I say , " oh ... wait a minute . you mean all that time , up till today , all that time I be so good , god do not notice it ? " and my mom say , " well , I notice it . "     ( laughter )     and I think , " how could I not have know this before ? how could it not have sink in when they have be tell I ? all that be good and no real credit for it . and bad of all , how could I not have realize this very important information until the very day that it be basically useless to I ? " so I say , " well , mom and dad , what about santa claus ? I mean , santa claus know if you be naughty or nice , right ? " and my dad say , " yeah , but , honey , I think that be technically just between thanksgiving and christmas . " and my mother say , " oh , bob , stop it . let us just tell she . I mean , she be seven . julie , there be no santa claus . "     ( laughter )     now , this be actually not that upset to I . my parent have this whole elaborate story about santa claus : how they have talk to santa claus himself and agree that instead of santa deliver our present over the night of christmas eve , like he do for every other family who get to open their surprise first thing christmas morning , our family would give santa more time . santa would come to our house while we be at nine o'clock high mass on christmas morning , but only if all of we kid do not make a fuss . which make I very suspicious . it be pretty obvious that it be really our parent give we the present . I mean , my dad have a very distinctive wrapping style , and my mother 's handwriting be so close to santa 's .     ( laughter )     plus , why would santa save time by have to loop back to our house after he have go to everybody else 's ? there be only one obvious conclusion to reach from this mountain of evidence : our family be too strange and weird for even santa claus to come visit , and my poor parent be try to protect we from the embarrassment , this humiliation of rejection by santa , who be jolly — but let us face it , he be also very judgmental . so to find out that there be no santa claus at all be actually sort of a relief .     I leave the kitchen not really in shock about santa , but rather , I be just dumbfound about how I could have miss this whole age of reason thing . it be too late for I , but maybe I could help someone else , someone who could use the information . they have to fit two criterion : they have to be old enough to be able to understand the whole concept of the age of reason , and not yet seven . the answer be clear : my brother bill . he be six . well , I finally find bill about a block away from our house at this public school playground . it be a saturday , and he be all by himself , just kick a ball against the side of a wall . I run up to he and say , " bill ! I just realize that the age of reason start when you turn seven , and then you be capable of commit any and all sin against god and man . " and bill say , " so ? " and I say , " so , you be six . you have a whole year to do anything you want to and god will not notice it . " and he say , " so ? " and I say , " so ? so everything ! " and I turn to run . I be so angry with he . but when I get to the top of the step , I turn around dramatically and say , " oh , by the way , bill — there be no santa claus . "     ( laughter )     now , I do not know it at the time , but I really be not turn seven on september 10th . for my 13th birthday , I plan a slumber party with all of my girlfriend , but a couple of week beforehand my mother take I aside and say , " I need to speak to you privately . september 10th be not your birthday . it be october 10th . " and I say , " what ? "     ( laughter )     and she say ...     ( laughter )     " listen . the cut - off date to start kindergarten be september 15th . "     ( laughter )     " so I tell they that your birthday be september 10th , and then I be not sure that you be not just go to go blab it all over the place , so I start to tell you your birthday be september 10th . but , julie , you be so ready to start school , honey . you be so ready . " I think about it , and when I be four , I be already the old of four child , and my mother even have another child to come , so what I think she — understandably — really mean be that she be so ready , she be so ready . then she say , " do not worry , julie . every year on october 10th , when it be your birthday but you do not realize it , I make sure that you eat a piece of cake that day .    good morning everyone . first of all , it be be fantastic be here over these past few day . and secondly , I feel it be a great honor to kind of wind up this extraordinary gathering of people , these amazing talk that we 've have . I think the chimpanzee in captivity who be the most skilled in intellectual performance be one call ai in japan — her name mean love — and she have a wonderfully sensitive partner work with she . she love her computer — she 'll leave her big group , and her run water , and her tree and everything . and she 'll come in to sit at this computer — it be like a video game for a kid ; " ( laughter ) we now know that at gombe alone , there be nine different way in which chimpanzee use different object for different purpose . moreover , we know that in different part of africa , wherever chimp have be study , there be completely different tool - use behavior . and because it seem that these pattern be pass from one generation to the next , through observation , imitation and practice — that be a definition of human culture . what we find be that over these 40 - odd year that I and other have be study chimpanzee and the other great ape , and , as I say , other mammal with complex brain and social system , we have find that after all , there be not a sharp line divide human from the rest of the animal kingdom . it be a very wuzzy line . it be get wuzzi all the time as we find animal do thing that we , in our arrogance , use to think be just human . the chimp — there be no time to discuss their fascinating life — but they have this long childhood , five year of suckle and sleep with the mother , and then another three , four or five year of emotional dependence on she , even when the next child be bear . the importance of learn in that time , when behavior be flexible — and there be an awful lot to learn in chimpanzee society . the long - term affectionate supportive bond that develop throughout this long childhood with the mother , with the brother and sister , and which can last through a lifetime , which may be up to 60 year . they can actually live long than 60 in captivity , so we 've only do 40 year in the wild so far . and we find chimp be capable of true compassion and altruism . we find in their non - verbal communication — this be very rich — they have a lot of sound , which they use in different circumstance , but they also use touch , posture , gesture , and what do they do ? they kiss ; they embrace ; they hold hand . they pat one another on the back ; they swagger ; they shake their fist — the kind of thing that we do , and they do they in the same kind of context . they have very sophisticated cooperation . sometimes they hunt — not that often , but when they hunt , they show sophisticated cooperation , and they share the prey . we find that they show emotion , similar to — maybe sometimes the same — as those that we describe in ourselves as happiness , sadness , fear , despair . they know mental as well as physical suffering . and I do not have time to go into the information that will prove some of these thing to you , save to say that there be very bright student , in the good university , study emotion in animal , study personality in animal . we know that chimpanzee and some other creature can recognize themselves in mirror — " self " as oppose to " other . they sun - dry it or smoke it . and now they 've get transport ; they take it on the logging truck or the mining truck into the town where they sell it . and people will pay more for bush - meat , as it be call , than for domestic meat — it be culturally preferred . and it be not sustainable , and the huge logging camp in the forest be now demand meat , so the pygmy hunter in the congo basin who 've live there with their wonderful way of live for so many hundred of year be now corrupt . they be give weapon ;    so I want to talk to you today about aid in sub - saharan africa . and this be a pretty well - educate audience , so I imagine you all know something about aid . you probably know that roughly 25 million people in africa be infect with the virus , that aids be a disease of poverty , and that if we can bring africa out of poverty , we would decrease aid as well . if you know something more , you probably know that uganda , to date , be the only country in sub - saharan africa that have have success in combat the epidemic . use a campaign that encourage people to abstain , be faithful , and use condom — the abc campaign — they decrease their prevalence in the 1990 from about 15 percent to 6 percent over just a few year . if you follow policy , you probably know that a few year ago the president pledge 15 billion dollar to fight the epidemic over five year , and a lot of that money be go to go to program that try to replicate uganda and use behavior change to encourage people and decrease the epidemic .     so today I be go to talk about some thing that you might not know about the epidemic , and I be actually also go to challenge some of these thing that you think that you do know . to do that I be go to talk about my research as an economist on the epidemic . and I be not really go to talk much about the economy . I be not go to tell you about export and price . but I be go to use tool and idea that be familiar to economist to think about a problem that be more traditionally part of public health and epidemiology . and I think in that sense , this fit really nicely with this lateral thinking idea . here I be really use the tool of one academic discipline to think about problem of another .     so we think , first and foremost , aids be a policy issue . and probably for most people in this room , that be how you think about it . but this talk be go to be about understand fact about the epidemic . it be go to be about think about how it evolve , and how people respond to it . I think it may seem like I be ignore the policy stuff , which be really the most important , but I be hope that at the end of this talk you will conclude that we actually can not develop effective policy unless we really understand how the epidemic work .     and the first thing that I want to talk about , the first thing I think we need to understand be : how do people respond to the epidemic ? so aids be a sexually transmit infection , and it kill you . so this mean that in a place with a lot of aid , there be a really significant cost of sex . if you be an uninfected man live in botswana , where the hiv rate be 30 percent , if you have one more partner this year — a long - term partner , girlfriend , mistress — your chance of die in 10 year increase by three percentage point .     that be a huge effect . and so I think that we really feel like then people should have less sex . and in fact among gay man in the us we do see that kind of change in the 1980 . so if we look in this particularly high - risk sample , they be be ask , " do you have more than one unprotected sexual partner in the last two month ? " over a period from ' 84 to ' 88 , that share drop from about 85 percent to 55 percent . it be a huge change in a very short period of time .     we do not see anything like that in africa . so we do not have quite as good datum , but you can see here the share of single man have pre - marital sex , or married man have extra - marital sex , and how that change from the early ' 90 to late ' 90 , and late ' 90 to early 2000s . the epidemic be get bad . people be learn more thing about it . we see almost no change in sexual behavior . these be just tiny decrease — two percentage point — not significant .     this seem puzzling . but I be go to argue that you should not be surprise by this , and that to understand this you need to think about health the way than an economist do — as an investment . so if you be a software engineer and you be try to think about whether to add some new functionality to your program , it be important to think about how much it cost . it be also important to think about what the benefit be . and one part of that benefit be how much long you think this program be go to be active . if version 10 be come out next week , there be no point in add more functionality into version nine .     but your health decision be the same . every time you have a carrot instead of a cookie , every time you go to the gym instead of go to the movie , that be a costly investment in your health . but how much you want to invest be go to depend on how much long you expect to live in the future , even if you do not make those investment . aids be the same kind of thing . it be costly to avoid aid . people really like to have sex . but , you know , it have a benefit in term of future longevity . but life expectancy in africa , even without aids , be really , really low : 40 or 50 year in a lot of place . I think it be possible , if we think about that intuition , and think about that fact , that maybe that explain some of this low behavior change .     but we really need to test that . and a great way to test that be to look across area in africa and see : do people with more life expectancy change their sexual behavior more ? and the way that I be go to do that is , I be go to look across area    I study ant , and that be because I like to think about how organization work . and in particular , how the simple part of organization interact to create the behavior of the whole organization . so , ant colony be a good example of an organization like that , and there be many other . the web be one . there be many biological system like that — brain , cell , develop embryo .     there be about 10,000 specie of ant . you all live in colony consist of one or a few queen , and then all the ant you see walk around be sterile female worker . and all ant colony have in common that there be no central control . nobody tell anybody what to do . the queen just lay the egg . there be no management . no ant direct the behavior of any other ant . and I try to figure out how that work . and I 've be work for the past 20 year on a population of seed - eat ant in southeastern arizona .     here be my study site . this be really a picture of ant , and the rabbit just happen to be there . and these ant be call harvester ant because they eat seed . this be the nest of the mature colony , and there be the nest entrance . and they forage maybe for about 20 meter away , gather up the seed and bring they back to the nest , and store they . and every year I go there and make a map of my study site . this be just a road . and it be not very big : it be about 250 meter on one side , 400 on the other . and every colony have a name , which be a number , which be paint on a rock . and I go there every year and look for all the colony that be alive the year before , and figure out which one have die , and put all the new one on the map . and by do this I know how old you all be . and because of that , I 've be able to study how their behavior change as the colony get old and large .     so I want to tell you about the life cycle of a colony . ant never make more ant ; colony make more colony . and they do that by each year send out the reproductive — those be the one with wing — on a mating flight . so every year , on the same day — and it be a mystery exactly how that happen — each colony send out its virgin , unmate queen with wing , and the male , and you all fly to a common place . and they mate . and this show a recently virgin queen . here be her wing . and she be in the process of mating with this male , and there be another male on top wait his turn . often the queen mate more than once . and after that , the male all die . that be it for they .     ( laughter )     and then the newly mated queen fly off somewhere , drop their wing , dig a hole and go into that hole and start lay egg . and they will live for 15 or 20 year , continue to lay egg use the sperm from that original mating . so the queen go down in there . she lay egg , she feed the larvae — so an ant start as an egg , then it be a larva . she feed the larvae by regurgitate from her fat reserve . then , as soon as the ant — the first group of ant — emerge , they be larvae . then they be pupa . then they come out as adult ant . they go out , they get the food , they dig the nest , and the queen never come out again .     so this be a one - year - old colony — this happen to be 536 . there be the nest entrance , there be a pencil for scale . so this be the colony found by a queen the previous summer . this be a three - year - old colony . there be the nest entrance , there be a pencil for scale . they make a midden , a pile of refuse — mostly the husk of the seed that they eat . this be a five - year - old colony . this be the nest entrance , here be a pencil for scale . this be about as big as they get , about a meter across . and then this be how colony size and number of worker ant change — so this be about 10,000 worker ant — change as a function of colony age , in year . so it start out with zero ant , just the found queen , and it grow to a size of about 10 or 12 thousand ant when the colony be five . and it stay that size until the queen die and there be nobody to make more ant , when she be about 15 or 20 year old . and it be when they reach this stable size , in number of ant , that they start to reproduce . that is , to send more winged queen and male to that year 's mating flight . and I know how colony size change as a function of colony age because I 've dig up colony of know age and count all the ant . ( laughter ) so that be not the most fun part of this research , although it be interesting .     ( laughter )     really the question that I think about with these ant be what I call task allocation . that be not just how be the colony organize , but how do it change what it be do ? how be it that the colony manage to adjust the number of worker perform each task as condition change ? so , thing happen to an ant colony . when it rain in the summer , it flood in the desert . there be a lot of damage to the nest , and extra ant be need to clean up that mess . when extra food become available — and this be what everybody know about picnic — then extra ant be allocate to collect the food . so , with nobody tell anybody what to do , how be it that the colony manage to adjust the number of worker perform each task ? and that be the process that I call task allocation .     and in harvester ant , I divide the task of the ant I see just outside the nest into these four category : where an ant be forage , when it be out along the forage trail , search for food or bring food back . the patroller — that be suppose to be a magnify glass — be an interesting group that go out early in the morning before the forager be active . they somehow choose the direction that the forager will go , and by come back — just by make it back — they tell the forager that it be safe to go out . then the nest maintenance worker work inside the nest , and I want to say that the nest look a lot like bill lishman 's house . that be , that there be chamber inside , they line the wall of the chamber with moist soil and it dry to a kind of an adobe - like surface in it . it also look very similar to some of the cave dwelling of the hopi people that be in that area . and the nest maintenance worker do that inside the nest , and then they come out of the nest carry bit of dry soil in their mandible . so you see the nest maintenance worker come out with a bit of sand , put it down , turn around , and go back in . and finally , the midden worker put some kind of territorial chemical in the garbage . so what you see the midden worker do be make a pile of refuse . on one day , it 'll all be here , and then the next day they 'll move it over there , and then they 'll move it back . so that be what the midden worker do . and these four group be just the ant outside the nest . so that be only about 25 percent of the colony , and they be the old ant .     so , an ant start out somewhere near the queen . and when we dig up nest we find they be about as deep as the colony be wide , so about a meter deep for the big old nest . and then there be another long tunnel and a chamber , where we often find the queen , after eight hour of hack away at the rock with pickaxe . I do not think that chamber have evolve because of I and my backhoe and my crew of student with pickaxe , but instead because when there be flooding , occasionally the colony have to go down deep . so there be this whole network of chamber . the queen 's in there somewhere ; she just lay egg . there be the larvae , and they consume most of the food . and this be true of most ant — that the ant you see walk around do not do much eating . they bring it back and feed it to the larvae . when the forager come in with food , they just drop it into the upper chamber , and other ant come up from below , get the food , bring it back , husk the seed , and pile they up . there be nest maintenance worker work throughout the nest . and curiously , and interestingly , it look as though at any time about half the ant in the colony be just do nothing . so , despite what it say in the bible , about , you know , " look to the ant , thou sluggard , " in fact , you could think of those ant as reserve . that be to say , if something happen — and I 've never see anything like this happen , but I 've only be look for 20 year — if something happen , they might all come out if they be need . but in fact , mostly they be just hang around in there .     and I think it be a very interesting question — what be there about the way the colony be organize that might give some function to a reserve of ant who be do nothing ? and they sort of stand as a buffer in between the ant work deep inside the nest and the ant work outside . and if you mark ant that be work outside , and dig up a colony , you never see they deep down . so what be happen be that the ant work inside the nest when they be young . they somehow get into this reserve . and then eventually they get recruit to join this exterior workforce . and once they belong to the ant that work outside , they never go back down . now ant — most ant , include these , do not see very well . they have eye , they can distinguish between light and dark , but they mostly work by smell . so just to reinforce that what you might have think about ant queen be not true — you know , even if the queen do have the intelligence to send chemical message through this whole network of chamber to tell the ant outside what to do , there be no way that such message could make it in time to see the shift in the allocation of worker that we actually see outside the nest . so that be one way that we know the queen be not direct the behavior of the colony .     so when I first set out to work on task allocation , my first question be , " what be the relationship between the ant do different task ? do it matter to the forager what the nest maintenance worker be do ? do it matter to the midden worker what the patroller be do ? " and I be work in the context of a view of ant colony in which each ant be somehow dedicated to its task from birth and sort of perform independently of the other , know its place on the assembly line . and instead I want to ask , " how be the different task group interdependent ? "     so I do experiment where I change one thing . so for example , I create more work for the nest maintenance worker by put out a pile of toothpick near the nest entrance , early in the morning when the nest maintenance worker be first active . this be what it look like about 20 minute later . here it be about 40 minute later . and the nest maintenance worker just take all the toothpick to the outer edge of the nest mound and leave they there . and what I want to know be , " ok , here be a situation where extra nest maintenance worker be recruit — be this go to have any effect on the worker perform other task ? " then we repeat all those experiment with the ant mark . so here be some blue nest maintenance worker . and lately we 've get more sophisticated and we have this three - color system . and we can mark they individually so we know which ant be which . we start out with model airplane paint and then we find these wonderful little japanese marker , and they work really well . and so just to summarize the result , well it turn out that yes , the different task be interdependent . so , if I change the number perform one task , it change the number perform another . so for example , if I make a mess that the nest maintenance worker have to clean up , then I see few ant out forage . and this be true for all the pair - wise combination of task .     and the second result , which be surprising to a lot of people , be that ant actually switch task . the same ant do not do the same task over and over its whole life . so for example , if I put out extra food , everybody else — the midden worker stop do midden work and go get the food , they become forager . the nest maintenance worker become forager . the patroller become forager . but not every transition be possible . and this show how it work . like I just say , if there be more food to collect , the patroller , the midden worker , the nest maintenance worker will all change to forage . if there be more patrolling to do — so I create a disturbance , so extra patroller be need — the nest maintenance worker will switch to patrol . but if more nest maintenance work be need — for example , if I put out a bunch of toothpick — then nobody will ever switch back to nest maintenance , they have to get nest maintenance worker from inside the nest . so forage act as a sink , and the ant inside the nest act as a source . and finally , it look like each ant be decide moment to moment whether to be active or not .     so , for example , when there be extra nest maintenance work to do , it be not that the forager switch over . I know that they do not do that . but the forager somehow decide not to come out . and here be the most intriguing result : the task allocation . this process change with colony age , and it change like this . when I do these experiment with old colony — so one that be five year or old — they be much more consistent from one time to another and much more homeostatic . the bad thing get , the more I hassle they , the more they act like undisturbed colony . whereas the young , small colony — the two - year - old colony of just 2,000 ant — be much more variable . and the amazing thing about this be that an ant live only a year . it could be this year , or this year . so , the ant in the old colony that seem to be more stable be not any old than the ant in the young colony . it be not due to the experience of old , wise ant . instead , something about the organization must be change as the colony get old . and the obvious thing that be change be its size .     so since I 've have this result , I 've spend a lot of time try to figure out what kind of decision rule — very simple , local , probably olfactory , chemical rule could an ant could be use , since no ant can assess the global situation — that would have the outcome that I see , these predictable dynamic , in who do what task . and it would change as the colony get large . and what I 've find out be that ant be use a network of antennal contact . so anybody who be ever look at ant have see they touch antennae . they smell with their antennae . when one ant touch another , it be smell it , and it can tell , for example , whether the other ant be a nest mate because ant cover themselves and each other , through groom , with a layer of grease , which carry a colony - specific odor . and what we be learn be that an ant use the pattern of its antennal contact , the rate at which it meet ant of other task , in decide what to do . and so what the message be , be not any message that they transmit from one ant to another , but the pattern . the pattern itself be the message . and I 'll tell you a little bit more about that .     but first you might be wonder : how be it that an ant can tell , for example , I be a forager . I expect to meet another forager every so often . but if instead I start to meet a high number of nest maintenance worker , I be less likely to forage . so it have to know the difference between a forager and a nest maintenance worker . and we 've learn that , in this specie — and I suspect in other as well — these hydrocarbon , this layer of grease on the outside of ant , be different as ant perform different task . and we 've do experiment that show that that be because the long an ant stay outside , the more these simple hydrocarbon on its surface change , and so they come to smell different by do different task . and they can use that task - specific odor in cuticular hydrocarbon — they can use that in their brief antennal contact to somehow keep track of the rate at which they be meet ant of certain task . and we 've just recently demonstrate this by put extract of hydrocarbon on little glass bead , and drop the bead gently down into the nest entrance at the right rate . and it turn out that ant will respond to the right rate of contact with a glass bead with hydrocarbon extract on it , as they would to contact with real ant .     so I want now to show you a bit of film — and this will start out , first of all , show you the nest entrance . so the idea be that ant be come in and out of the nest entrance . they 've go out to do different task , and the rate at which they meet as they come in and out of the nest entrance determine , or influence , each ant 's decision about whether to go out , and which task to perform . this be take through a fiber optic microscope . it be down inside the nest . in the beginning you see the ant just kind of engage with the fiber optic microscope . but the idea be that the ant be in there , and each ant be experience a certain flow of ant past it — a stream of contact with other ant . and the pattern of these interaction determine whether the ant come back out , and what it do when it come back out . you can also see this in the ant just outside the nest entrance like these . each ant , then , as it come back in , be contact other ant . and the ant that be wait just inside the nest entrance to decide whether to go out on their next trip , be contact the ant come in .     so , what be interesting about this system be that it be messy . it be variable . it be noisy . and , in particular , in two way . the first be that the experience of the ant — of each ant — can not be very predictable . because the rate at which ant come back depend on all the little thing that happen to an ant as it go out and do its task outside . and the second thing be that an ant 's ability to assess this pattern must be very crude because no ant can do any sophisticated counting . so , we do a lot of simulation and modeling , and also experimental work , to try to figure out how those two kind of noise combine to , in the aggregate , produce the predictable behavior of ant colony .     again , I do not want to say that this kind of haphazard pattern of interaction produce a factory that work with the precision and efficiency of clockwork . in fact , if you watch ant at all , you end up try to help they because they never seem to be do anything exactly the way that you think that they ought to be do it . so it be not really that out of these haphazard contact , perfection arise . but it work pretty well . ant have be around for several hundred million year . they cover the earth , except for antarctica . something that they be do be clearly successful enough that this pattern of haphazard contact , in the aggregate , produce something that allow ant to make a lot more ant . and one of the thing that we be study be how natural selection might be act now to shape this use of interaction pattern — this network of interaction pattern — to perhaps increase the forage efficiency of ant colony .     so the one thing , though , that I want you to remember about this be that these pattern of interaction be something that you would expect to be closely connect to colony size . the simple idea be that when an ant be in a small colony — and an ant in a large colony can use the same rule , like " I expect to meet another forager every three second . " but in a small colony , it be likely to meet few forager , just because there be few other forager there to meet . so this be the kind of rule that , as the colony develop and get old and large , will produce different behavior in an old colony and a small young one .     thank you . at that time , they be begin to be bring into the civilian market . and at the same time , the gorgeous work of takeshi ishiguro , who do these beautiful salt - and - pepper container that be make of rice dough . so you see , the range be really quite diverse .     and then , for instance , this other exhibition that be entitle worksphere in 2001 , where I ask different designer to come up with idea for the new type of work style that be happen in the world at that time . and you see ideo there . it be beautiful — it be call personal sky . the idea be that if you have a cubicle , you could project a sky on top of your head and have your own " cielo in una stanza " — a sky in a room — it be a very famous italian song .     and other example : this be marti guixe about work on the go , and hella jongerius , my favorite , about how to work at home . and this let I introduce a very important idea about design : designer be the big synthesizer in the world . what they do well be make a synthesis of human need , current condition in economy , in material , in sustainability issue , and then what they do at the end — if they be good — be much more than the sum of its part .     hella jongerius be a person that be able to make a synthesis that be really quite amazing and also quite hilarious . the idea behind her work be that at that time , everybody be say you have to really divide your life . instead , she say , " no , no . work and leisure can be together . " yeah , that be particularly gorgeous — it be the tv dinner of 2001 .     there have be many other exhibition in the meantime , but I do not want to focus on my show . I would like , instead , to talk about how great some designer be . I 've always have a hard time with the word " maverick . " I come to the united states 13 year ago , and to this day I have to ask , " what do that mean ? " so , this morning I go to see on the dictionary and it say that there be this gentleman that be not brand its cattle . therefore , he be not follow everybody 's lead , and therefore , he be a maverick . so , designer do need to be maverick , because the good way to design a successful object — and also an object that we be miss before — be to pretend that either it never exist or that people will be able to have a new behavior with it .     so , safe be the last exhibition that I do at moma and it end at the beginning of last year . it be about design that deal with safety and deal with protection . it be a long story because it start before 2001 and it be call emergency . and then when 9/11 happen , I have a shock and I cancel the exhibition until , slowly but surely , it come back — as a half - full glass instead of half - empty — and it be about protection and safety .     but it range from such item as a complete de - mining equipment to these kind of water - sterilize straw , so it be really wide - range . it also have ... you know , cameron and I work a little bit together , and some of the entry that you see in his website be actually in the exhibition . but what be interesting be that we do not need to talk about design and art anymore ; design use whatever tool it have at its disposal in order to make a point . it be a sense of economy and a sense , also , of humor .     this be a beautiful project by ralph borland , who be south african . it be a suit for civil disobedience . the idea be that when you have a riot or a protest and the police come towards you , you be wear this thing — it be like a big heart and it have a loudspeaker over your heart so your heartbeat be amplify — and the police be remind ; it be like have a flower in front of the rifle . and also , you can imagine , a whole group of people with the same suit will have this mount collective heartbeat that will be scary to the police .     so , designer sometimes do not do thing that be immediately functional , but they be functional to our understanding of issue . tony dunne and fiona raby do this series of object that be about our anguish and our paranoia , like this hideaway furniture that be make in the same wood as your floor so it disappear completely and you can hide away ; or even well , the huggable atomic mushroom , which get I an article on the bulletin of atomic scientist of the united states — I do not think it ever happen before at moma ; or this faraday chair that be suppose to protect you from radiation .     but the interesting thing in the exhibition be the discovery that the ultimate shelter be your sense of self , and there be quite a few designer that be work on this particular topic . this be cindy van den breman , who be a dutch designer that be do this series of capster . they be athletic gear for muslim woman that enable they to ski , play tennis , do whatever they want to do without have to uncap themselves .     and sometimes by do this kind of research , you encounter such beautiful idea of design . twan verdonck be really young , I think he be 27 , and work together with some psychologist he do a series of toy that be for sensorial stimulation for child that have psychological impairment . they be quite beautiful . they range from this fluffy toy that be about hug you — because autistic child like to be hug tight , so it have a spring inside — all the way to this doll with a mirror so the child can see he or herself in the mirror and regain a sense of self .     design really look upon the whole world and it consider the world in all of its different range . I be recently at a conference on luxury organize by the herald tribune in istanbul . and it be really interesting because I be the last speaker and before I there be people that be really talk about luxury , and I do not want to be a party pooper but at the same time I feel that I have to kind of bring back the discourse to reality .     and the truth be that there be very different kind of luxury , and there be luxury that be relative for people that do not have that much . I want to make this point by show you two example of design come from a sense of economy — very , very clear limit . this be cuba , and this be the recycling of a squeaky toy as a bicycle bell , and this be a raincoat that be make out of rice sack . so they be quite beautiful , but they be beautiful because they be so smart and economical .     and here be the work of two brother from sao paulo , fernando and humberto campana , who got inspire by the poverty and smartness that they see around they to do piece of furniture that now be sell for an enormous amount of money . but that be because of the kind of strangeness of the market itself .     so really , design take everything into account , and the interesting thing be that as the technology advance , as we become more and more wireless and impalpable , designer , instead , want we to be hand - on . sometimes hammer - on . this be a whole series of furniture that want to engage you physically . even this chair that you have to open up and then sit on so that it take your imprint , all the way to this beautiful series of object that be consider design by ana mir in barcelona . from this kind of bijou make with human hair to these chocolate nipple to these intra - toe candy that your lover be suppose to suck from your toe . ( laughter )     it be quite beautiful because somehow , this be a gorgeous moment for design . many year ago I hear a mathematician from vienna , whose name be marchetti , explain how the innovation in the military industry — therefore , secret innovation — and the innovation in the civilian society be two sinusoid that be kind of opposed . and that make sense . in moment of war there be great technological innovation , and in the world you have to do without — well , during the second world war , you have to do without steel , you have to do without aluminum . and then as peace come , all of these technology get all of a sudden available for the civilian market . many of you might know that the potato chip chair by charles and ray eame come exactly from that kind of instance : fiberglas be available for civilian use all of a sudden .     I think that this be a strange moment . the rhythm of the sinusoid have change tremendously , just like the rhythm of our life in the past 25 year , so I be not sure anymore what the wavelength be . but it surely be a very important moment for design , because not only be the technology proceeding , not only be compute technology make open - source possible also in the world of design , but also the idea of sustainability — which be not only sustainability from the viewpoint of co2 emission and footprint , but also sustainability of human interrelationship — be very much part of the work of so many designer . and that be why designer , more and more , be work on behavior rather than on object . especially the good one , not all of they .     I want to show you , for instance , the work of mathieu lehanneur , which be quite fantastic . he be another young designer from france who be work — and at this point he be work , also , with pharmaceutical company — on new way to engage patient , especially child , in take their medicine with constancy and with certainty .     for instance , this be a beautiful container for asthma medicine that kind of inflate itself when it be time for you to take the medicine , so the child have to go — pffff ! — to release and relieve the container itself . and this other medicine be something that you can draw on your skin , so intradermal delivery enable you to joyfully be involve in this particular kind of delivery . similarly , there be the work of people like marti guixe that try to involve you in a way that be really about make everything pass through your mouth so that you learn from your mistake or from your taste , orally .     the next show that I be go to work on — and I 've be bug a lot of you about this here — be about the relationship between design and science . I be try to find not the metaphor , but , rather , the point in common — the common gripe , the common issue , the common preoccupation — and I think that it will enable we to go a little far in this idea of design as an instruction , as a direction rather than a prescription of form .     and I be hope that many of you will respond to this . I 've send an email already to quite a few of you . but design and science and the possibility of visualize different scale , and therefore , really work at the scale of the very small to make it very big and very meaningful . thank you .    I be go to talk about two story today . one be how we need to use market - base pricing to affect demand and use wireless technology to dramatically reduce our emission in the transportation sector . and the other be that there be an incredible opportunity if we choose the right wireless technology ; how we can generate a new engine for economic growth and dramatically reduce c02 in the other sector .     I be really scared . we need to reduce c02 emission in ten to fifteen year by 80 percent in order to avert catastrophic effect . and I be astounded that I be stand here to tell you that . what be catastrophic effect ? a three degree centigrade climate change rise that will result in 50 percent specie extinction . it be not a movie . this be real life . and I be really worried , because when people talk about car — which I know something about — the press and politician and people in this room be all think , " let us use fuel - efficient car . " if we start today , 10 year from now , at the end of this window of opportunity , those fuel - efficient car will reduce our fossil fuel need by four percent . that be not enough .     but now I 'll talk about some more pleasant thing . here be some way that we can make some dramatic change . so , zipcar be a company that I found seven year ago , but it be an example of something call car sharing . what zipcar do be we park car throughout dense urban area for member to reserve , by the hour and by the day , instead of use their own car . how do it feel to be a person use a zipcar ? it mean that I pay only for what I need . all those hour when a car be sit idle , I be not pay for it . it mean that I can choose a car exactly for that particular trip . so , here be a woman that reserve minimia , and she have her day . I can take a bmw when I be see client . I can drive my toyota element when I be go to go on that surfing trip .     and the other remarkable thing be it be , I think , the high status of car ownership . not only do I have a fleet of car available to I in seven city around the world that I can have at my beck and call , but heaven forbid I would ever maintain or deal with the repair or have anything to do with it . it be like the car that you always want that your mom say that you could not have . I get all the good stuff and none of the bad .     so , what be the social result of this ? the social result be that today 's zipcar have 100,000 member drive 3,000 car park in 3,000 parking space . instead of drive 12,000 mile a year , which be what the average city dweller do , they drive 500 mile a year . be they happy ? the company have be double in size ever since I found it , or great . people adore the company . and it be well , you know ? they like it . so , how be it that people go from the 12,000 mile a year to 500 mile ? it be because they say , " it be eight to 10 dollar an hour and 65 dollar a day . if I be go to go buy some ice cream , do I really want to spend eight dollar to go buy the ice cream ? or maybe I 'll do without . maybe I would have buy the ice cream when I do some other errand . " so , people really respond very quickly to it , to price .     and the last point I want to make be zipcar would never be possible without technology . it require that it be completely trivial : that it take 30 second to reserve a car , go get it , drive it . and for I , as a service provider , I would never be able to provide you a car for an hour if the transaction cost be anything . so , without these wireless technology , this , as a concept , could never happen .     so , here be another example . this company be goloco — I be launch it in about three week — and I hope to do for rideshare what I do for car sharing . this will apply to people across all of america . today , 75 percent of the trip be single - occupancy vehicle , yet 12 percent of trip to work be currently carpool . and I think that we can apply social network and online payment system to completely change how people feel about ridesharing and make that trip much more efficient .     and so when I think about the future , people will be think that share the ride with someone be this incredibly great social event out of their day . you know , how do you get to ted ? you go with other tedster . how fabulous . why would you ever want to go by yourself in your own car ? how do you go food shopping ? you go with your neighbor , what a great social time . you know it be go to really transform how we feel about travel , and it will also , I think , enhance our freedom of mobility . where can I go today and who can I do it with ? those be the type of thing that you will look at and feel .     and the social benefit : the rate of single - occupancy vehicle be , I tell you , 75 percent ; I think we can get that down to 50 percent . the demand for parking , of course , be down , congestion and the co2 emission . one last piece about this , of course , be that it be enable by wireless technology . and it be the cost of drive that be make people want to be able to do this . the average american spend 19 percent of their income on their car , and there be a pressure for they to reduce that cost , yet they have no outlet today .     so , the last example of this be congestion pricing , very famously do in london . it be when you charge a premium for people to drive on congested road . in london , the day they turn the congestion pricing on , there be a 25 percent decrease in congestion overnight , and that be persist for the four year in which they 've be do congestion pricing . and again , do people like the outcome ? ken livingstone be reelect . so again , we can see that price play an enormous role in people 's willingness to reduce their drive behavior . we 've triple the mile that we drive since 1970 and double they since 1982 . there be a huge slack in that system ; with the right pricing we can undo that .     congestion pricing be be discuss in every major city around the world and be , again , wirelessly enable . you be not go to put tollbooth around the city of london and open and shut those gate . and what congestion pricing be be that it be a technology trial and a psychological trial for something call road pricing . and road pricing be where we be all go to have to go , because today we pay for our maintenance and wear and tear on our car with gas taxis . and as we get our car more fuel - efficient , that be go to be reduce the amount of revenue that you get off of those gas taxis , so we need to charge people by the mile that they drive . whatever happen with congestion pricing and those technology will be happen with road pricing .     why do we travel too much ? car travel be underprice and therefore we over - consume . we need to put this well market feedback . and if we have it , you 'll decide how many mile to drive , what mode of travel , where to live and work . and wireless technology make this real - time loop possible .     so , I want to move now to the second part of my story , which be : when be we go to start do this congestion pricing ? road pricing be come . when be we go to do it ? be we go to wait 10 to 15 year for this to happen or be we go to finally have this political will to make it happen in the next two year ? because I be go to say , that be go to be the tool that be go to turn our usage overnight .     and what kind of wireless technology be we go to use ? this be my big vision . there be a tool that can help we bridge the digital divide , respond to emergency , get traffic move , provide a new engine for economic growth and dramatically reduce co2 emission in every sector . and this be a moment from " the graduate . " do you remember this moment ? you guy be go to be the handsome young guy and I be go to be the wise businessman . " I want to say one word to you , just one word . " " yes , sir ? " " be you listen ? " " yes I be . " " ad - hoc peer - to - peer self - configure wireless network . " ( laughter ) these be also call mesh network . and in a mesh , every device contribute to and expand the network , and I think you might have hear a little bit about it before .     I be go to give you some example . you 'll be hear later today from alan kay . these laptop , when a child open they up , they communicate with every single child in the classroom , within that school , within that village . and what be the cost of that communication system ? zero dollar a month . here be another example : in new orleans , video camera be mesh - enable so that they could monitor crime in the downtown french quarter . when the hurricane happen , the only communication system standing be the mesh network . volunteer fly in , add a whole bunch of device , and for the next 12 month , mesh network be the only wireless that be happen in new orleans .     another example be in portsmouth , u.k . they mesh - enable 300 bus and they speak to these smart terminal . you can look at the terminal and be able to see precisely where your bus be on the street and when it be come , and you can buy your ticket in real time . again , all mesh - enabled . monthly communication cost : zero . so , the beauty of mesh network : you can have these very low - cost device . zero ongoing communication cost . highly scalable ; you can just keep add they , and as in katrina , you can keep subtract they — as long as there be some , we can still communicate . they be resilient ; their redundancy be build into this fabulous decentralized design .     what be the incredible weakness ? there be not anybody in washington lobby to make it happen — or in those municipality , to build out their city with these wireless network — because there be zero ongoing communication cost . so , the example that I give you be these island of mesh network , and network be interesting only as they be big .     how do we create a big network ? be you guy ready again — " the graduate " ? this time you will still play the handsome young thing , but I 'll be the sexy woman . these be the next two line in the movie . " where do you do it ? " " in his car . " so you know , when you stick this idea ... ( laughter ) where would we expect I , robin chase , to be think be imagine if we put a mesh - network device in every single car across america . we could have a coast - to - coast , free wireless communication system . I guess I just want you to think about that .     and why be this go to happen ? because we be go to do congestion pricing , we be go to do road toll , gas taxis be go to become road pricing . these thing be go to happen . what be the wireless technology we be go to use ? maybe we should use a good one . when be we go to do it ? maybe we should not wait for the 10 or 15 year for this to happen . we should pull it forward .     so , I would like we to launch the wireless internet interstate wireless mesh system , and require that this network be accessible to everyone , with open standard . right now in the transportation sector , we be create these wireless device — I guess you guy might have fast pass here or easy lane — that be single - purpose device in these closed network . what be the point ? we be transfer just a few little datum bit when we be do road control , road pricing . we have this incredible excess capacity . so , we can provide the low - cost mean of go wireless coast - to - coast , we can have resilient nationwide communication system , we have a new tool for create efficiency in all sector . imagine what happen when the cost of get information from anywhere to anywhere be close to zero . what you can do with that tool : we can create an economic engine . information should be free , and access to information should be free , and we should be charge people for carbon .     I think this be a more powerful tool than the interstate highway act , and I think this be as important and world change to our economy as electrification . and if I have my druther , we would have an open - source version in addition to open standard . and this open - source version mean that it could be — if we do a brilliant job of it — it could be use around the world very quickly . so , go back to one of my early thought . imagine if every one of these bus in lagos be part of the mesh network . when I go this morning to larry brilliant 's tedtalk prize — his fabulous network — imagine if there be an open - source mesh communication device that can be put into those network , to make all that happen . and we can be do it if we could just get over the fact that this little slice of thing be go to be for free . we could make billion of dollar on top of it , but this one particular slice of communication need to be open source .     so , let us take control of this nightmare : implement a gas tax immediately ; transition across the nation to road - tolling with this wireless mesh ; require that the mesh be open to all , with open standard ; and , of course , use mesh network . thank you .
