   I grow up to study the brain because I have a brother who have be diagnose with a brain disorder , schizophrenia . and as a sister and later , as a scientist , I want to understand , why be it that I can take my dream , I can connect they to my reality , and I can make my dream come true ? what be it about my brother 's brain and his schizophrenia that he can not connect his dream to a common and share reality , so they instead become delusion ?     so I dedicate my career to research into the severe mental illness . and I move from my home state of indiana to boston , where I be work in the lab of dr . francine bene , in the harvard department of psychiatry . and in the lab , we be ask the question , " what be the biological difference between the brain of individual who would be diagnose as normal control , as compare with the brain of individual diagnose with schizophrenia , schizoaffective or bipolar disorder ? "     so we be essentially map the microcircuitry of the brain : which cell be communicate with which cell , with which chemical , and then in what quantity of those chemical ? so there be a lot of meaning in my life because I be perform this type of research during the day , but then in the evening and on the weekend , I travel as an advocate for nami , the national alliance on mental illness .     but on the morning of december 10 , 1996 , I wake up to discover that I have a brain disorder of my own . a blood vessel explode in the left half of my brain . and in the course of four hour , I watch my brain completely deteriorate in its ability to process all information . on the morning of the hemorrhage , I could not walk , talk , read , write or recall any of my life . I essentially become an infant in a woman 's body .     if you 've ever see a human brain , it be obvious that the two hemisphere be completely separate from one another . and I have bring for you a real human brain .     ( groaning , laughter )     so this be a real human brain . this be the front of the brain , the back of brain with the spinal cord hang down , and this be how it would be position inside of my head . and when you look at the brain , it be obvious that the two cerebral cortex be completely separate from one another .     for those of you who understand computer , our right hemisphere function like a parallel processor , while our left hemisphere function like a serial processor . the two hemisphere do communicate with one another through the corpus callosum , which be make up of some 300 million axonal fiber . but other than that , the two hemisphere be completely separate . because they process information differently , each of our hemisphere think about different thing , they care about different thing , and , dare I say , they have very different personality . excuse I . thank you . it be be a joy .     assistant : it have be .     ( laughter )     our right human hemisphere be all about this present moment . it be all about " right here , right now . " our right hemisphere , it think in picture and it learn kinesthetically through the movement of our body . information , in the form of energy , stream in simultaneously through all of our sensory system and then it explode into this enormous collage of what this present moment look like , what this present moment smell like and taste like , what it feel like and what it sound like . I be an energy - being connect to the you all around I through the consciousness of my right hemisphere . we be energy - being connect to one another through the consciousness of our right hemisphere as one human family . and right here , right now , we be brother and sister on this planet , here to make the world a well place . and in this moment we be perfect , we be whole and we be beautiful .     my left hemisphere , our left hemisphere , be a very different place . our left hemisphere think linearly and methodically . our left hemisphere be all about the past and it be all about the future . our left hemisphere be design to take that enormous collage of the present moment and start pick out detail , and more detail about those detail . it then categorize and organize all that information , associate it with everything in the past we 've ever learn , and project into the future all of our possibility . and our left hemisphere think in language . it be that ongoing brain chatter that connect I and my internal world to my external world . it be that little voice that say to I , " hey , you 've get to remember to pick up banana on your way home . I need they in the morning . " it be that calculate intelligence that remind I when I have to do my laundry . but perhaps most important , it be that little voice that say to I , " I be . I be . "     and as soon as my left hemisphere say to I " I be , " I become separate . I become a single solid individual , separate from the energy flow around I and separate from you . and this be the portion of my brain that I lose on the morning of my stroke .     on the morning of the stroke , I wake up to a pound pain behind my left eye . and it be the kind of caustic pain that you get when you bite into ice cream . and it just grip I — and then it release I . and then it just grip I — and then it release I . and it be very unusual for I to ever experience any kind of pain , so I think , " ok , I 'll just start my normal routine . "     so I get up and I jump onto my cardio glider , which be a full - body , full - exercise machine . and I be jam away on this thing , and I be realize that my hand look like primitive claw grasp onto the bar . and I think , " that be very peculiar .    well , this be such an honor . and it be wonderful to be in the presence of an organization that be really make a difference in the world . and I be intensely grateful for the opportunity to speak to you today .     and I be also rather surprised , because when I look back on my life the last thing I ever want to do be write , or be in any way involve in religion . after I leave my convent , I would finish with religion , frankly . I think that be it . and for 13 year I keep clear of it . I want to be an english literature professor . and I certainly do not even want to be a writer , particularly . but then I suffer a series of career catastrophe , one after the other , and finally find myself in television . ( laughter ) I say that to bill moyer , and he say , " oh , we take anybody . " ( laughter )     and I be do some rather controversial religious program . this go down very well in the u.k . , where religion be extremely unpopular . and so , for once , for the only time in my life , I be finally in the mainstream . but I got send to jerusalem to make a film about early christianity . and there , for the first time , I encounter the other religious tradition : judaism and islam , the sister religion of christianity . and while I find I know nothing about these faith at all — despite my own intensely religious background , I would see judaism only as a kind of prelude to christianity , and I know nothing about islam at all .     but in that city , that tortured city , where you see the three faith jostle so uneasily together , you also become aware of the profound connection between they . and it have be the study of other religious tradition that bring I back to a sense of what religion can be , and actually enable I to look at my own faith in a different light .     and I find some astonishing thing in the course of my study that have never occur to I . frankly , in the day when I think I would have it with religion , I just find the whole thing absolutely incredible . these doctrine seem unproven , abstract . and to my astonishment , when I begin seriously study other tradition , I begin to realize that belief — which we make such a fuss about today — be only a very recent religious enthusiasm that surface only in the west , in about the 17th century . the word " belief " itself originally mean to love , to prize , to hold dear . in the 17th century , it narrow its focus , for reason that I be explore in a book I be write at the moment , to include — to mean an intellectual assent to a set of proposition , a credo . " I believe : " it do not mean , " I accept certain creedal article of faith . " it mean : " I commit myself . I engage myself . " indeed , some of the world tradition think very little of religious orthodoxy . in the quran , religious opinion — religious orthodoxy — be dismiss as " zanna : " self - indulgent guesswork about matter that nobody can be certain of one way or the other , but which make people quarrelsome and stupidly sectarian . ( laughter )     so if religion be not about believe thing , what be it about ? what I 've find , across the board , be that religion be about behave differently . instead of decide whether or not you believe in god , first you do something . you behave in a committed way , and then you begin to understand the truth of religion . and religious doctrine be mean to be summon to action ; you only understand they when you put they into practice .     now , pride of place in this practice be give to compassion . and it be an arrest fact that right across the board , in every single one of the major world faith , compassion — the ability to feel with the other in the way we 've be think about this evening — be not only the test of any true religiosity , it be also what will bring we into the presence of what jews , christians and muslims call " god " or the " divine . " it be compassion , say the buddha , which bring you to nirvana . why ? because in compassion , when we feel with the other , we dethrone ourselves from the center of our world and we put another person there . and once we get rid of ego , then we be ready to see the divine .     and in particular , every single one of the major world tradition have highlight — have say — and put at the core of their tradition what be become know as the golden rule . first propound by confucius five century before christ : " do not do to other what you would not like they to do to you . " that , he say , be the central thread which run through all his teaching and that his disciple should put into practice all day and every day . and it be — the golden rule would bring they to the transcendent value that he call " ren , " human - heartedness , which be a transcendent experience in itself .     and this be absolutely crucial to the monotheism , too . there be a famous story about the great rabbi , hillel , the old contemporary of jesus . a pagan come to he and offer to convert to judaism if the rabbi could recite the whole of jewish teaching while he stand on one leg . hillel stand on one leg and say , " that which be hateful to you , do not do to your neighbor . that be the torah . the rest be commentary . go and study it . " ( laughter )     and " go and study it " be what he mean . he say , " in your exegesis , you must make it clear that every single verse of the torah be a commentary , a gloss upon the golden rule . " the great rabbi meir say that any interpretation of scripture which lead to hatred and disdain , or contempt of other people — any people whatsoever — be illegitimate .     saint augustine make exactly the same point . scripture , he say , " teach nothing but charity , and we must not leave an interpretation of scripture until we have find a compassionate interpretation of it . " and this struggle to find compassion in some of these rather rebarbative text be a good dress rehearsal for do the same in ordinary life . ( applause )     but now look at our world . and we be live in a world that be — where religion have be hijack . where terrorist cite quranic verse to justify their atrocity . where instead of take jesus ' word , " love your enemy . do not judge other , " we have the spectacle of christian endlessly judge other people , endlessly use scripture as a way of argue with other people , put other people down . throughout the age , religion have be use to oppress other , and this be because of human ego , human greed . we have a talent as a species for mess up wonderful thing .     so the tradition also insist — and this be an important point , I think — that you could not and must not confine your compassion to your own group : your own nation , your own co - religionist , your own fellow countryman . you must have what one of the chinese sage call " jian ai " : concern for everybody . love your enemy . honor the stranger . we form you , say the quran , into tribe and nation so that you may know one another .     and this , again — this universal outreach — be getting subdue in the strident use of religion — abuse of religion — for nefarious gain . now , I 've lose count of the number of taxi driver who , when I say to they what I do for a living , inform I that religion have be the cause of all the major world war in history . wrong . the cause of our present woe be political .     but , make no mistake about it , religion be a kind of fault line , and when a conflict gets ingrain in a region , religion can get suck in and become part of the problem . our modernity have be exceedingly violent . between 1914 and 1945 , 70 million people die in europe alone as a result of armed conflict . and so many of our institution , even football , which use to be a pleasant pastime , now cause riot where people even die . and it be not surprising that religion , too , have be affect by this violent ethos .     there be also a great deal , I think , of religious illiteracy around . people seem to think , now equate religious faith with believe thing . as though that — we call religious people often believer , as though that be the main thing that they do . and very often , secondary goal get push into the first place , in place of compassion and the golden rule . because the golden rule be difficult .    as a particle physicist , I study the elementary particle and how they interact on the most fundamental level . for most of my research career , I 've be use accelerator , such as the electron accelerator at stanford university , just up the road , to study thing on the small scale . but more recently , I 've be turn my attention to the universe on the large scale . because , as I 'll explain to you , the question on the small and the large scale be actually very connected . so I be go to tell you about our twenty - first - century view of the universe , what it be make of and what the big question in the physical science be — at least some of the big question .     so , recently , we have realize that the ordinary matter in the universe — and by ordinary matter , I mean you , I , the planet , the star , the galaxy — the ordinary matter make up only a few percent of the content of the universe . almost a quarter , or approximately a quarter of the matter in the universe , be stuff that be invisible . by invisible , I mean it do not absorb in the electromagnetic spectrum . it do not emit in the electromagnetic spectrum . it do not reflect . it do not interact with the electromagnetic spectrum , which be what we use to detect thing . it do not interact at all . so how do we know it be there ? we know it be there by its gravitational effect . in fact , this dark matter dominate the gravitational effect in the universe on a large scale , and I 'll be tell you about the evidence for that .     what about the rest of the pie ? the rest of the pie be a very mysterious substance call dark energy . more about that later , ok . so for now , let us turn to the evidence for dark matter . in these galaxy , especially in a spiral galaxy like this , most of the mass of the star be concentrate in the middle of the galaxy . this huge mass of all these star keep star in circular orbit in the galaxy . so we have these star go around in circle like this . as you can imagine , even if you know physics , this should be intuitive , ok — that star that be close to the mass in the middle will be rotate at a high speed than those that be furth out here , ok .     so what you would expect be that if you measure the orbital speed of the star , that they should be slow on the edge than on the inside . in other word , if we measure speed as a function of distance — this be the only time I be go to show a graph , ok — we would expect that it go down as the distance increase from the center of the galaxy . when those measurement be make , instead what we find be that the speed be basically constant , as a function of distance . if it be constant , that mean that the star out here be feel the gravitational effect of matter that we do not see . in fact , this galaxy and every other galaxy appear to be embed in a cloud of this invisible dark matter . and this cloud of matter be much more spherical than the galaxy themselves , and it extend over a much wide range than the galaxy . so we see the galaxy and fixate on that , but it be actually a cloud of dark matter that be dominate the structure and the dynamic of this galaxy .     galaxy themselves be not strew randomly in space ; they tend to cluster . and this be an example of a very , actually , famous cluster , the coma cluster . and there be thousand of galaxy in this cluster . they be the white , fuzzy , elliptical thing here . so these galaxy cluster — we take a snapshot now , we take a snapshot in a decade , it 'll look identical . but these galaxy be actually move at extremely high speed . they be move around in this gravitational potential well of this cluster , ok . so all of these galaxy be move . we can measure the speed of these galaxy , their orbital velocity , and figure out how much mass be in this cluster .     and again , what we find be that there be much more mass there than can be account for by the galaxy that we see . or if we look in other part of the electromagnetic spectrum , we see that there be a lot of gas in this cluster , as well . but that can not account for the mass either . in fact , there appear to be about ten time as much mass here in the form of this invisible or dark matter as there be in the ordinary matter , ok . it would be nice if we could see this dark matter a little bit more directly . I be just put this big , blue blob on there , ok , to try to remind you that it be there . can we see it more visually ? yes , we can .     and so let I lead you through how we can do this . so here be an observer : it could be an eye ; it could be a telescope . and suppose there be a galaxy out here in the universe . how do we see that galaxy ? a ray of light leave the galaxy and travel through the universe for perhaps billion of year before it enter the telescope or your eye . now , how do we deduce where the galaxy be ? well , we deduce it by the direction that the ray be travel as it enter our eye , right ? we say , the ray of light come this way ; the galaxy must be there , ok . now , suppose I put in the middle a cluster of galaxy — and do not forget the dark matter , ok . now , if we consider a different ray of light , one go off like this , we now need to take into account what einstein predict when he develop general relativity . and that be that the gravitational field , due to mass , will deflect not only the trajectory of particle , but will deflect light itself .     so this light ray will not continue in a straight line , but would rather bend and could end up go into our eye . where will this observer see the galaxy ? you can respond . up , right ? we extrapolate backwards and say the galaxy be up here . be there any other ray of light that could make into the observer 's eye from that galaxy ? yes , great . I see people go down like this . so a ray of light could go down , be bent up into the observer 's eye , and the observer see a ray of light here .     now , take into account the fact that we live in a three - dimensional universe , ok , a three - dimensional space . be there any other ray of light that could make it into the eye ? yes ! the ray would lie on a — I would like to see — yeah , on a cone . so there be a whole ray of light — ray of light on a cone — that will all be bend by that cluster and make it into the observer 's eye . if there be a cone of light come into my eye , what do I see ? a circle , a ring . it be call an einstein ring . einstein predict that , ok . now , it will only be a perfect ring if the source , the deflector and the eyeball , in this case , be all in a perfectly straight line . if they be slightly skewed , we 'll see a different image .     now , you can do an experiment tonight over the reception , ok , to figure out what that image will look like . because it turn out that there be a kind of lens that we can devise , that have the right shape to produce this kind of effect . we call this gravitational lensing . and so , this be your instrument , ok . so now , let us turn to dark energy . so to understand the evidence for dark energy , we need to discuss something that stephen hawking refer to in the previous session . and that be the fact that space itself be expand . so if we imagine a section of our infinite universe — and so I 've put down four spiral galaxy , ok — and imagine that you put down a set of tape measure , so every line on here correspond to a tape measure , horizontal or vertical , for measure where thing be . if you could do this , what you would find that with each pass day , each pass year , each pass billion of year , ok , the distance between galaxy be get great . and it be not because galaxy be move away from each other through space . they be not necessarily move through space . they be move away from each other because space itself be get big , ok . that be what the expansion of the universe or space mean . so they be move far apart .     now , what stephen hawking mention , as well , be that after the big bang , space expand at a very rapid rate . but because gravitationally attract matter be embed in this space , it tend to slow down the expansion of the space , ok . so the expansion slow down with time . so , in the last century , ok , people debate about whether this expansion of space would continue forever ; whether it would slow down , you know , will be slow down , but continue forever ; slow down and stop , asymptotically stop ; or slow down , stop , and then reverse , so it start to contract again . so a little over a decade ago , two group of physicist and astronomer set out to measure the rate at which the expansion of space be slow down , ok . by how much less be it expand today , compare to , say , a couple of billion year ago ?     the startling answer to this question , ok , from these experiment , be that space be expand at a fast rate today than it be a few billion year ago , ok . so the expansion of space be actually speed up . this be a completely surprising result . there be no persuasive theoretical argument for why this should happen , ok . no one be predict ahead of time this be what be go to be find . it be the opposite of what be expect . so we need something to be able to explain that . now it turn out , in the mathematic , you can put it in as a term that be an energy , but it be a completely different type of energy from anything we 've ever see before . we call it dark energy , and it have this effect of cause space to expand . but we do not have a good motivation for put it in there at this point , ok . so it be really unexplained as to why we need to put it in .     now , so at this point , then , what I want to really emphasize to you , be that , first of all , dark matter and dark energy be completely different thing , ok . there be really two mystery out there as to what make up most of the universe , and they have very different effect . dark matter , because it gravitationally attract , it tend to encourage the growth of structure , ok . so cluster of galaxy will tend to form , because of all this gravitational attraction . dark energy , on the other hand , be put more and more space between the galaxy , make it , the gravitational attraction between they decrease , and so it impede the growth of structure . so by look at thing like cluster of galaxy , and how they — their number density , how many there be as a function of time — we can learn about how dark matter and dark energy compete against each other in structure form .     in term of dark matter , I say that we do not have any well motivated ?    so , indeed , I have spend my life look into the life of president who be no long alive . wake up with abraham lincoln in the morning , thinking of franklin roosevelt when I go to bed at night . but when I try and think about what I 've learn about the meaning in life , my mind keep wander back to a seminar that I take when I be a graduate student at harvard with the great psychologist erik erikson .     he teach we that the rich and full life attempt to achieve an inner balance between three realm : work , love and play . and that to pursue one realm to the disregard of the other , be to open oneself to ultimate sadness in old age . whereas to pursue all three with equal dedication , be to make possible a life fill not only with achievement , but with serenity .     so since I tell story , let I look back on the life of two of the president I 've study to illustrate this point — abraham lincoln and lyndon johnson . as for that first sphere of work , I think what abraham lincoln 's life suggest be that fierce ambition be a good thing . he have a huge ambition . but it be not simply for office or power or celebrity or fame — what it be for be to accomplish something worthy enough in life so that he could make the world a little well place for his having live in it .     even as a child , it seem , lincoln dreamed heroic dream . he somehow have to escape that hard - scrabble farm from which he be bear . no schooling be possible for he , except a few week here , a few week there . but he read book in every spare moment he could find . it be say when he get a copy of the king james bible or " aesop 's fable , " he be so excited he could not sleep . he could not eat . the great poet emily dickinson once say , " there be no frigate like a book to take we land away . " how true for lincoln .     though he never would travel to europe , he go with shakespeare 's king to merry england , he go with lord byron 's poetry to spain and portugal . literature allow he to transcend his surrounding . but there be so many loss in his early life that he be haunt by death . his mother die when he be only nine year old ; his only sister , sarah , in childbirth a few year later ; and his first love , ann rutledge , at the age of 22 . moreover , when his mother lie die , she do not hold out for he the hope that they would meet in an afterworld . she simply say to he , " abraham , I be go away from you now , and I shall never return . " as a result he become obsessed with the thought that when we die our life be sweep away — dust to dust .     but only as he grow old do he develop a certain consolation from an ancient greek notion — but follow by other culture as well — that if you could accomplish something worthy in your life , you could live on in the memory of other . your honor and your reputation would outlive your earthly existence . and that worthy ambition become his lodestar . it carry he through the one significant depression that he suffer when he be in his early 30 .     three thing have combine to lay he low . he have break his engagement with mary todd , not certain he be ready to marry she , but know how devastating it be to she that he do that . his one intimate friend , joshua speed , be leave illinois to go back to kentucky because speed 's father have die . and his political career in the state legislature be on a downward slide . he be so depressed that friend worry he be suicidal . they take all knife and razor and scissor from his room . and his great friend speed go to his side and say , " lincoln , you must rally or you will die . " he say that , " I would just as soon die right now , but I 've not yet do anything to make any human being remember that I have live . "     so fuel by that ambition , he return to the state legislature . he eventually win a seat in congress . he then run twice for the senate , lose twice . " everyone be break by life , " ernest hemingway once say , " but some people be strong in the broken place . " so then he surprise the nation with an upset victory for the presidency over three far more experienced , far more educate , far more celebrated rival . and then when he win the general election , he stun the nation even more by appoint each of these three rival into his cabinet . it be an unprecedented act at the time because everybody think , " he 'll look like a figurehead compare to these people . " they say , " why be you do this , lincoln ? " he say , " look , these be the strong and most able man in the country . the country be in peril . I need they by my side . " but perhaps my old friend lyndon johnson might have put it in less noble fashion : " well to have your enemy inside the tent piss out , than outside the tent piss in . " ( laughter )     but it soon become clear that abraham lincoln would emerge as the undisputed captain of this unruly team . for each of they soon come to understand that he possess an unparalleled array of emotional strength and political skill that prove far more important than the thinness of his external résumé . for one thing , he possess an uncanny ability to empathize with and to think about other people ' point of view . he repair injured feeling that might have escalate into permanent hostility . he share credit with ease , assume responsibility for the failure of his subordinate , constantly acknowledge his error and learn from his mistake . these be the quality we should be look for in our candidate in 2008 . ( applause ) he refuse to be provoke by petty grievance . he never submit to jealousy or brood over perceive slight . and he express his unshakeable conviction in everyday language , in metaphor , in story . and with a beauty of language — almost as if the shakespeare and the poetry he have so love as a child have work their way into his very soul .     in 1863 , when the emancipation proclamation be sign , he bring his old friend , joshua speed , back to the white house , and remember that conversation of decade before , when he be so sad . and he , point to the proclamation , say , " I believe , in this measure , my fond hope will be realize . ' " so he wait until he could take up the pen and sign with a bold and clear hand . but even in his wild dream , lincoln could never have imagine how far his reputation would reach .    the career that I start early on in my life be look for exotic life form in exotic place , and at that time I be work in the antarctic and the arctic , and high desert and low desert . until about a dozen year ago , when I be really capture by cave , and I really re - focused most of my research in that direction .     so I have a really cool day job — I get to do some really amazing stuff . I think , myself , that life be a natural outgrowth of the increase complexification of matter over time .     so , you start with the big bang and you get hydrogen , and then you get helium , and then you get more complicated stuff , and you get planet form — and life be a common , planetary - base phenomenon , in my view . certainly , in the last 15 year , we 've see increase number of planet outside of our solar system be confirm , and just last month , a couple of week ago , a planet in the size - class of earth have actually be find . and so this be very exciting news .     so , my first bold prediction be that , be that in the universe , life be go to be everywhere . it be go to be everywhere we look — where there be planetary system that can possibly support it . and those planetary system be go to be very common . so , what about life on mar ? well , if somebody have ask I about a dozen year ago what I think the chance of life on mar would be , I would 've probably say , a couple of percent . and even that be consider outrageous at the time . I be once sneeringly introduce by a former nasa official , as the only person on the planet who still think there be life on mar . of course , that official be now dead , and I be not , so there be a certain amount of glory in outlive your adversary .     but thing have change greatly over the last dozen year . and the reason that they have change be because we now have new information . the amazing pathfinder mission that go in ' 97 , and the mer rover mission that be on mar as we speak now and the european space agency 's mars express , have teach we a number of amazing thing . there be sub - surface ice on that planet . and so where there be water , there be a very high chance of our kind of life . there be clearly sedimentary rock all over the place – one of the lander be sit in the middle of an ancient seabed , and there be these amazing structure call blueberry , which be these little , rocky concretion that we be busy make biologically in my lab right now .     so , with all of these thing put together , I think that the chance of life be much great than I would 've ever think . I think that the chance of life having arise on mar , sometime in its past , be maybe one in four to maybe even half and half . so this be a very bold statement . I think it be there , and I think we need to go look for it , and I think it be underground . so the game 's afoot , and this be the game that we play in astro - biology . how do you try to get a handle on extraterrestrial life ? how do you plan to look for it ? how do you know it when you find it ? because if it be big and obvious , we would 've already find it — it would 've already bite we on the foot , and it have not .     so , we know that it be probably quite cryptic . very critically , how do we protect it , if we find it , and not contaminate it ? and also , even perhaps more critically , because this be the only home planet we have , how do we protect we from it , while we study it ? so why might it be hard to find ? well , it be probably microscopic , and it be never easy to study microscopic thing , although the amazing tool that we now have to do that allow we to study thing in much great depth , at much small scale than ever before . but it be probably hide , because if you be out sequester resource from your environment , that make you yummy , and other thing might want to eat you , or consume you . and so , there be a game of predator - prey that be go to be , essentially , universal , really , in any kind of biological system . it also may be very , very different in its fundamental property – its chemistry , or its size .     we say small , but what do that mean ? be it virus - sized ? be it small than that ? be it big than the big bacterium ? we do not know . and speed of activity , which be something that we face in our work with sub - surface organism , because they grow very , very slowly . if I be to take a swab off your tooth and plate it on a petri plate , within about four or five hour , I would have to see growth . but the organism that we work with , from the sub - surface of earth , very often it be month — and in many case , year — before we see any growth whatsoever . so they be , intrinsically , a slow life - form .     but the real issue be that we be guide by our limited experience , and until we can think out of the box of our cranium and what we know , then we can not recognize what to look for , or how to plan for it . so , perspective be everything and , because of the history that I 've just briefly talk to you about , I have learn to think about earth as an extraterrestrial planet . and this have be invaluable in our approach to try to study these thing .     this be my favorite game on airplane : where you be in an airplane and you look out the window , you see the horizon . I always turn my head on the side , and that simple change make I go from see this planet as home , to see it as a planet . it be a very simple trick , and I never fail to do it when I be sit in a window seat . well , this be what we apply to our work . this show one of the most extreme cave that we work in . this be cueva de villa luz in tabasco , in mexico , and this cave be saturate with sulfuric acid . there be tremendous amount of hydrogen sulfide come into this cave from volcanic source and from the breakdown of evaporite — mineral below the carbonate in which this cave be form — and it be a completely hostile environment for we . we have to go in with protective suit and breathing gear , and 30 part per million of h2s will kill you . this be regularly several hundred part per million . so , it be a very hazardous environment , with co as well , and many other gas . these extreme physical and chemical parameter make the biology that grow in these place very special . because contrary to what you might think , this be not devoid of life .     this be one of the rich cave that we have find on the planet , anywhere . it be burst with life . the extreme on earth be interesting in their own right , but one of the reason that we be interested in they be because they represent , really , the average condition that we may expect on other planet . so , this be part of the ability that we have , to try to stretch our imagination , in term of what we may find in the future . there be so much life in this cave , and I can not even begin to scratch the surface of it with you .     but one of the most famous object out of this be what we call snottite , for obvious reason . this stuff look like what come out of your two - year - old 's nose when he have a cold . and this be produce by bacteria who be actually make more sulfuric acid , and live at phs right around zero . and so , this stuff be like battery acid . and yet , everything in this cave have adapt to it . in fact , there be so much energy available for biology in this cave , that there be actually a huge number of cavefish . and the local zoque indians harvest this twice a year , as part of their easter week celebration and holy week celebration .     this be very unusual for cave . in some of the other amazing cave that we work in — this be in lechuguilla cave in new mexico near carlsbad , and this be one of the most famous cave in the world . it be 115 mile of map passage , it be pristine , it have no natural opening and it be a gigantic biological , geo - microbiological laboratory . in this cave , great area be cover by this reddish material that you see here , and also these enormous crystal of selenite that you can see dangle down . this stuff be produce biologically . this be the breakdown product of the bedrock , that organism be busy munch their way through . they take iron and manganese mineral within the bedrock and they oxidize they . and every time they do that , they get a tiny little packet of energy . and that tiny little packet of energy be what they use , then , to run their life process . interestingly enough , they also do this with uranium and chromium , and various other toxic metal .     and so , the obvious avenue for bio - remediation come from organism like this . these organism we now bring into the lab , and you can see some of they grow on petri plate , and get they to reproduce the precise biomineral that we find on the wall of these cave . so , these be signal that they leave in the rock record . well , even in basalt surface in lava - tube cave , which be a by - product of volcanic activity , we find these wall totally cover , in many case , by these beautiful , glisten silver wall , or shiny pink or shiny red or shiny gold . and these be mineral deposit that be also make by bacteria . and you can see in these central image here , scan electron micrograph of some of these guy — these be garden of these bacteria .     one of the interesting thing about these particular guy be that they be in the actinomycete and streptomycete group of the bacteria , which be where we get most of our antibiotic . the sub - surface of earth contain a vast biodiversity . and these organism , because they be very separate from the surface , make a vast array of novel compound . and so , the potential for exploit this for pharmaceutical and industrial chemical use be completely untapped , but probably exceed most of the rest of the biodiversity of the planet .     so , lava - tube cave — I 've just tell you about organism that live here on this planet . we know that on mar and the moon there be ton of these structure . we can see they . on the left you can see a lava tube form at a recent eruption — mount etna in sicily — and this be the way these tube form . and when they hollow out , then they become habitat for organism . these be all over the planet mar , and we be busy catalogue they now . and so , there be very interesting cave real estate on mar , at least of that type .     in order to access these sub - work and many other complex human motion in order to access these . we face the problem of , how can we do this robotically ? why would we want to do it robotically ? well , we be go to be send robotic mission to mar long in advance of human mission .     and then , secondly , get back to that early point that I make about the preciousness of any life that we may find on mar , we do not want to contaminate it . and one of the good way to study something without contaminate it be to have an intermediary . and in this case , we be imagine intermediary robotic device that can actually do some of that front - in - place airlock to deal with this complex topology , various way of get breathing gas make from the intrinsic material of these body . and the future be there for we to use these lava - tube cave on mar . and right now we be in cave , and we be do science and recreation , but I think in the future we 'll be use they for habitat and science on these other body .     now , my view of what the current status of potential life on mar be that it be probably be on the planet , maybe one in two chance . the question as to whether there be life on mar that be relate to life on earth have now be very muddied , because we now know , from mar meteorite that have make it to earth , that there be material that can be exchange between those two planet .     one of the burn question , of course , be if we go there and find life in the sub - surface , as I fully expect that we will , be that a second genesis of life ? do life start here and be it transport there ? do it start there and get transport here ? this will be a fascinating puzzle as we go into the next half - century , and where I expect that we will have more and more mar mission to answer these question . thank you .

   I be a writer . write book be my profession but it be more than that , of course . it be also my great lifelong love and fascination . and I do not expect that that be ever go to change . but , that say , something kind of peculiar have happen recently in my life and in my career , which have cause I to have to recalibrate my whole relationship with this work . and the peculiar thing be that I recently write this book , this memoir call " eat , pray , love " which , decidedly unlike any of my previous book , go out in the world for some reason , and become this big , mega - sensation , international bestseller thing . the result of which be that everywhere I go now , people treat I like I be doom . seriously — doom , doom ! like , they come up to I now , all worried , and they say , " be not you afraid you be never go to be able to top that ? be not you afraid you be go to keep write for your whole life and you be never again go to create a book that anybody in the world care about at all , ever again ? "     so that be reassuring , you know . but it would be bad , except for that I happen to remember that over 20 year ago , when I be a teenager , when I first start tell people that I want to be a writer , I be meet with this same sort of fear - base reaction . and people would say , " be not you afraid you be never go to have any success ? be not you afraid the humiliation of rejection will kill you ? be not you afraid that you be go to work your whole life at this craft and nothing be ever go to come of it and you be go to die on a scrap heap of break dream with your mouth fill with bitter ash of failure ? "     ( laughter )     like that , you know .     the answer — the short answer to all those question be , " yes . " yes , I be afraid of all those thing . and I always have be . and I be afraid of many , many more thing besides that people can not even guess at , like seaweed and other thing that be scary . but , when it come to writing , the thing that I 've be sort of think about lately , and wonder about lately , be why ? you know , be it rational ? be it logical that anybody should be expect to be afraid of the work that they feel they be put on this earth to do . and what be it specifically about creative venture that seem to make we really nervous about each other 's mental health in a way that other career kind of do not do , you know ? like my dad , for example , be a chemical engineer and I do not recall once in his 40 year of chemical engineering anybody ask he if he be afraid to be a chemical engineer , you know ? " that chemical - engineering block , john , how be it go ? " it just do not come up like that , you know ? but to be fair , chemical engineer as a group have not really earn a reputation over the century for be alcoholic manic - depressive .     ( laughter )     we writer , we kind of do have that reputation , and not just writer , but creative people across all genre , it seem , have this reputation for be enormously mentally unstable . and all you have to do be look at the very grim death count in the 20th century alone , of really magnificent creative mind who die young and often at their own hand , you know ? and even the one who do not literally commit suicide seem to be really undo by their gift , you know . norman mailer , just before he die , last interview , he say , " every one of my book have kill I a little more . " an extraordinary statement to make about your life 's work . but we do not even blink when we hear somebody say this , because we 've hear that kind of stuff for so long and somehow we 've completely internalize and accept collectively this notion that creativity and suffering be somehow inherently link and that artistry , in the end , will always ultimately lead to anguish .     and the question that I want to ask everybody here today be be you you all cool with that idea ? be you comfortable with that ? because you look at it even from an inch away and , you know — I be not at all comfortable with that assumption . I think it be odious . and I also think it be dangerous , and I do not want to see it perpetuate into the next century . I think it be well if we encourage our great creative mind to live .     and I definitely know that , in my case — in my situation — it would be very dangerous for I to start sort of leak down that dark path of assumption , particularly give the circumstance that I be in right now in my career . which be — you know , like check it out , I be pretty young , I be only about 40 year old . I still have maybe another four decade of work leave in I . and it be exceedingly likely that anything I write from this point forward be go to be judge by the world as the work that come after the freakish success of my last book , right ? I should just put it bluntly , because we be all sort of friend here now — it be exceedingly likely that my great success be behind I . so jesus , what a thought ! that be the kind of thought that could lead a person to start drink gin at nine o'clock in the morning , and I do not want to go there .     ( laughter )     I would prefer to keep do this work that I love .     and so , the question become , how ? and so , it seem to I , upon a lot of reflection , that the way that I have to work now , in order to continue write , be that I have to create some sort of protective psychological construct , right ? I have to sort of find some way to have a safe distance between I , as I be write , and my very natural anxiety about what the reaction to that writing be go to be , from now on . and , as I 've be look , over the last year , for model for how to do that , I 've be sort of look across time , and I 've be try to find other society to see if they might have have well and saner idea than we have about how to help creative people sort of manage the inherent emotional risk of creativity .     and that search have lead I to ancient greece and ancient rome . so stay with I , because it do circle around and back . but , ancient greece and ancient rome — people do not happen to believe that creativity come from human being back then , ok ? people believe that creativity be this divine attendant spirit that come to human being from some distant and unknowable source , for distant and unknowable reason . the greeks famously call these divine attendant spirit of creativity " daemon . " socrate , famously , believe that he have a daemon who speak wisdom to he from afar .     the romans have the same idea , but they call that sort of disembody creative spirit a genius . which be great , because the romans do not actually think that a genius be a particularly clever individual . they believe that a genius be this , sort of magical divine entity , who be believe to literally live in the wall of an artist 's studio , kind of like dobby the house elf , and who would come out and sort of invisibly assist the artist with their work and would shape the outcome of that work .     so brilliant — there it be , right there , that distance that I be talk about — that psychological construct to protect you from the result of your work . and everyone know that this be how it function , right ? so the ancient artist be protect from certain thing , like , for example , too much narcissism , right ? if your work be brilliant , you could not take all the credit for it , everybody know that you have this disembody genius who have help you . if your work bomb , not entirely your fault , you know ? everyone know your genius be kind of lame .     ( laughter )     and this be how people think about creativity in the west for a really long time . and then the renaissance come and everything change , and we have this big idea , and the big idea be , let us put the individual human be at the center of the universe above all god and mystery , and there be no more room for mystical creature who take dictation from the divine . and it be the beginning of rational humanism , and people start to believe that creativity come completely from the self of the individual . and for the first time in history , you start to hear people refer to this or that artist as be a genius , rather than have a genius .     and I get to tell you , I think that be a huge error . you know , I think that allow somebody , one mere person to believe that he or she be like , the vessel , you know , like the font and the essence and the source of all divine , creative , unknowable , eternal mystery be just a smidge too much responsibility to put on one fragile , human psyche . it be like ask somebody to swallow the sun . it just completely warps and distort ego , and it create all these unmanageable expectation about performance . and I think the pressure of that have be kill off our artist for the last 500 year .     and , if this be true , and I think it be true , the question become , what now ? can we do this differently ? maybe go back to some more ancient understanding about the relationship between human and the creative mystery . maybe not . maybe we can not just erase 500 year of rational humanistic thought in one 18 minute speech . and there be probably people in this audience who would raise really legitimate scientific suspicion about the notion of , basically , fairy who follow people around rub fairy juice on their project and stuff . " and she would run like hell to the house and she would be getting chase by this poem , and the whole deal be that she have to get to a piece of paper and a pencil fast enough so that when it thunder through she , she could collect it and grab it on the page . and other time she would not be fast enough , so she would be run and run , and she would not get to the house and the poem would barrel through she and she would miss it and she say it would continue on across the landscape , look , as she put it " for another poet .    fifty year ago , when I begin explore the ocean , no one — not jacques perrin , not jacques cousteau or rachel carson — imagine that we could do anything to harm the ocean by what we put into it or by what we take out of it . it seem , at that time , to be a sea of eden , but now we know , and now we be face paradise lose . I guess I do .     for I , as a scientist , it all begin in 1953 when I first try scuba . it be when I first get to know fish swim in something other than lemon slice and butter . " we need to learn everything we can about it and do everything we can to take care of it .     the poet auden say , " thousand have live without love ; none without water . " ninety - seven percent of earth 's water be ocean . no blue , no green . if you think the ocean be not important , imagine earth without it . mars come to mind . no ocean , no life support system .    I 've be work on issue of poverty for more than 20 year , and so it be ironic that the problem that and question that I most grapple with be how you actually define poverty . what do it mean ? so often , we look at dollar term — people make less than a dollar or two or three a day . and yet the complexity of poverty really have to look at income as only one variable . because really , it be a condition about choice , and the lack of freedom .     and I have an experience that really deepen and elucidated for I the understanding that I have . it be in kenya , and I want to share it with you . I be with my friend susan meiselas , the photographer , in the mathare valley slum . now , mathare valley be one of the old slum in africa . it be about three mile out of nairobi , and it be a mile long and about two - tenth of a mile wide , where over half a million people live cram in these little tin shack , generation after generation , rent they , often eight or 10 people to a room . and it be know for prostitution , violence , drug : a hard place to grow up . and when we be walk through the narrow alley , it be literally impossible not to step in the raw sewage and the garbage alongside the little home . but at the same time it be also impossible not to see the human vitality , the aspiration and the ambition of the people who live there : woman wash their baby , wash their clothe , hang they out to dry . I meet this woman , mama rise , who have rent that little tin shack for 32 year , where she live with her seven child . four sleep in one twin bed , and three sleep on the mud and linoleum floor . and she keep they all in school by sell water from that kiosk , and from sell soap and bread from the little store inside .     it be also the day after the inauguration , and I be remind how mathare be still connect to the globe . and I would see kid on the street corner , and they would say " obama , he be our brother ! " and I would say " well , obama 's my brother , so that make you my brother too . " and they would look quizzically , and then be like , " high five ! "     and it be here that I meet jane . I be strike immediately by the kindness and the gentleness in her face , and I ask she to tell I her story . she start off by tell I her dream . she say , " I have two . my first dream be to be a doctor , and the second be to marry a good man who would stay with I and my family , because my mother be a single mom , and could not afford to pay for school fee . so I have to give up the first dream , and I focus on the second . " she got marry when she be 18 , have a baby right away . and when she turn 20 , find herself pregnant with a second child , her mom die and her husband leave she — marry another woman . so she be again in mathare , with no income , no skill set , no money . and so she ultimately turn to prostitution . it be not organize in the way we often think of it . she would go into the city at night with about 20 girl , look for work , and sometimes come back with a few shilling , or sometimes with nothing . and she say , " you know , the poverty be not so bad . it be the humiliation and the embarrassment of it all . "     in 2001 , her life change . she have a girlfriend who have hear about this organization , jamii bora , that would lend money to people no matter how poor you be , as long as you provide a commensurate amount in saving . and so she spend a year to save 50 dollar , and start borrow , and over time she be able to buy a sewing machine . she start tailor . and that turn into what she do now , which be to go into the secondhand clothing market , and for about three dollar and 25 cent she buy an old ball gown . some of they might be one you give . and she repurpose they with frill and ribbon , and make these frothy confection that she sell to woman for their daughter 's sweet 16 or first holy communion — those milestone in a life that people want to celebrate all along the economic spectrum . and she do really good business . in fact , I watch her walk through the street hawk . and before you know it , there be a crowd of woman around she , buy these dress .     and I reflect , as I be watch she sell the dress , and also the jewelry that she make , that now jane make more than four dollar a day . and by many definition she be no long poor . but she still live in mathare valley . and so she can not move out . she live with all of that insecurity , and in fact , in january , during the ethnic riot , she be chase from her home and have to find a new shack in which she would live .     jamii bora understand that and understand that when we be talk about poverty , we 've get to look at people all along the economic spectrum . and so with patient capital from acuman and other organization , loan and investment that will go the long term with they , they build a low - I be hiv positive . I 've deal with it all .    bacteria be the old living organism on the earth . they 've be here for billion of year , and what they be be single - celle microscopic organism . so they be one cell and they have this special property that they only have one piece of dna . they have very few gene , and genetic information to encode all of the trait that they carry out . and the way bacteria make a living be that they consume nutrient from the environment , they grow to twice their size , they cut themselves down in the middle , and one cell become two , and so on and so on . they just grow and divide , and grow and divide — so a kind of boring life , except that what I would argue be that you have an amazing interaction with these critter .     I know you guy think of yourself as human , and this be sort of how I think of you . this man be suppose to represent a generic human being , and all of the circle in that man be all of the cell that make up your body . there be about a trillion human cell that make each one of we who we be and able to do all the thing that we do , but you have 10 trillion bacterial cell in you or on you at any moment in your life . so , 10 time more bacterial cell than human cell on a human being . and of course it be the dna that count , so here be all the a , t , gs and cs that make up your genetic code , and give you all your charming characteristic . you have about 30,000 gene . well it turn out you have 100 time more bacterial gene play a role in you or on you all of your life . at the good , you be 10 percent human , but more likely about one percent human , depend on which of these metric you like . I know you think of yourself as human being , but I think of you as 90 or 99 percent bacterial .     ( laughter )     these bacteria be not passive rider , these be incredibly important , they keep we alive . they cover we in an invisible body armor that keep environmental insult out so that we stay healthy . they digest our food , they make our vitamin , they actually educate your immune system to keep bad microbe out . so they do all these amazing thing that help we and be vital for keep we alive , and they never get any press for that . but they get a lot of press because they do a lot of terrible thing as well . so , there be all kind of bacteria on the earth that have no business be in you or on you at any time , and if they be , they make you incredibly sick .     and so , the question for my lab be whether you want to think about all the good thing that bacteria do , or all the bad thing that bacteria do . the question we have be how could they do anything at all ? I mean they be incredibly small , you have to have a microscope to see one . they live this sort of boring life where they grow and divide , and they 've always be consider to be these asocial reclusive organism . and so it seem to we that they be just too small to have an impact on the environment if they simply act as individual . and so we want to think if there could not be a different way that bacteria live .     the clue to this come from another marine bacterium , and it be a bacterium call vibrio fischeri . what you be look at on this slide be just a person from my lab hold a flask of a liquid culture of a bacterium , a harmless beautiful bacterium that come from the ocean , name vibrio fischeri . this bacterium have the special property that it make light , so it make bioluminescence , like firefly make light . we be not do anything to the cell here . we just take the picture by turn the light off in the room , and this be what we see .     what be actually interesting to we be not that the bacteria make light , but when the bacteria make light . what we notice be when the bacteria be alone , so when they be in dilute suspension , they make no light . but when they grow to a certain cell number all the bacteria turn on light simultaneously . the question that we have be how can bacteria , these primitive organism , tell the difference from time when they be alone , and time when they be in a community , and then all do something together . what we 've figure out be that the way that they do that be that they talk to each other , and they talk with a chemical language .     this be now suppose to be my bacterial cell . when it be alone it do not make any light . but what it do do be to make and secrete small molecule that you can think of like hormone , and these be the red triangle , and when the bacteria be alone the molecule just float away and so no light . but when the bacteria grow and double and they be all participate in make these molecule , the molecule — the extracellular amount of that molecule increase in proportion to cell number . and when the molecule hit a certain amount that tell the bacteria how many neighbor there be , they recognize that molecule and all of the bacteria turn on light in synchrony . that be how bioluminescence work — they be talk with these chemical word .     the reason that vibrio fischeri be do that come from the biology . again , another plug for the animal in the ocean , vibrio fischeri live in this squid . what you be look at be the hawaiian bobtail squid , and it be I ask the question , how many line can I draw through the point but never meet the original line ? " and you all know the answer . do someone want to shout it out ? one . great . okay . that be our definition of a parallel line . it be a definition really of euclidean space .     but there be another possibility that you all know of : spherical space . think of the surface of a sphere — just like a beach ball , the surface of the earth . I have a straight line on my spherical surface . and I have a point outside the line . how many straight line can I draw through the point but never meet the original line ? what do we mean to talk about a straight line on a curved surface ? now mathematicians have answer that question . they 've understand there be a generalize concept of straightness , it be call a geodesic . and on the surface of a sphere , a straight line be the big possible circle you can draw . so it be like the equator or the line of longitude . so we ask the question again , " how many straight line can I draw through the point , but never meet the original line ? " do someone want to guess ? zero . very good .     now mathematicians think that be the only alternative . it be a bit suspicious be not it ? there be two answer to the question so far , zero and one . two answer ? there may possibly be a third alternative . to a mathematician if there be two answer , and the first two be zero and one , there be another number that immediately suggest itself as the third alternative . do anyone want to guess what it be ? infinity . you all get it right . exactly . there be , there be a third alternative . this be what it look like . there be a straight line , and there be an infinite number of line that go through the point and never meet the original line . this be the drawing . this nearly drive mathematician bonker because , like you , they be sit there feel bamboozled . think , how can that be ? you be cheat . the line be curve . but that be only because I be project it onto a flat surface . mathematician for several hundred year have to really struggle with this . how could they see this ? what do it mean to actually have a physical model that look like this ?     it be a bit like this : imagine that we have only ever encounter euclidean space . then our mathematician come along and say , " there be this thing call a sphere , and the line come together at the north and south pole .    interestingly , charles darwin be bear a very lightly pigment man , in a moderately - to - darkly pigment world . over the course of his life , darwin have great privilege . he live in a fairly wealthy home . he be raise by very supportive and interested parent . and when he be in his 20 he embark upon a remarkable voyage   on the ship the beagle . and during the course of that voyage , he see remarkable thing : tremendous diversity of plant and animal , and human . and the observation that he make on that epic journey be to be eventually distil into his wonderful book , " on the origin of specie , " publish 150 year ago .     now what be so interesting and to some , the extent , what be a bit infamous about " the origin of specie , " be that there be only one line in it about human evolution . " light will be throw on the origin of man and his history . " it be not until much long , much later , that darwin actually speak and write about human .     now in his year of travel on the beagle , and from listen to the account or explorer and naturalist , he know that skin color be one of the most important way in which people vary . and he be somewhat interested in the pattern of skin color . he know that darkly pigment people be find close to the equator ; lightly pigment people , like himself , be find close to the pole .     so what do he make of all this ? well he do not write anything about it in the origin of specie . but much later , in 1871 , he do have something to say about it . and it be quite curious . he say , " of all the difference between the race of man , the color of the skin be the most conspicuous and one of the well marked . " and he go on to say , " these difference do not coincide with correspond difference in climate . " so he have travel all around . he have see people of different color live in different place . and yet he reject the idea that human skin pigmentation be relate to the climate .     if only darwin live today . if only darwin have nasa . now , one of the wonderful thing that nasa do be it put up a variety of satellite that detect all sort of interesting thing about our environment . and for many decade now there have be a series of tom satellite that have collect datum about the radiation of the earth 's surface . the tom 7 satellite datum , show here , show the annual average ultraviolet radiation at the earth 's surface . now the really hot pink and red area be those part of the world that receive the high amount of uv during the year . the incrementally cooler color — blue , green , yellow , and finally gray — indicate area of much low ultraviolet radiation .     what be significant to the story of human skin pigmentation be just how much of the northern hemisphere be in these cool gray zone . this have tremendous implication for our understanding of the evolution of human skin pigmentation . and what darwin could not appreciate , or do not perhaps want to appreciate at the time , be that there be a fundamental relationship between the intensity of ultraviolet radiation and skin pigmentation . and that skin pigmentation itself be a product of evolution . and so when we look at a map of skin color , and predict skin color , as we know it today , what we see be a beautiful gradient from the dark skin pigmentation toward the equator , and the light one toward the pole .     what be very , very important here be that the early human evolve in high - uv environment , in equatorial africa . the early member of our lineage , the genus homo , be darkly pigment . and we all share this incredible heritage of having originally be darkly pigment , two million to one and half million year ago .     now what happen in our history ? let us first look at the relationship of ultraviolet radiation to the earth 's surface . in those early day of our evolution , look at the equator , we be bombard by high level of ultraviolet radiation . the uvc , the most energetic type , be occlude by the earth 's atmosphere . but uvb and uva especially , come in unimpeded . uvb turn out to be incredibly important . it be very destructive , but it also catalyze the production of vitamin d in the skin , vitamin d be a molecule that we very much need for our strong bone , the health of our immune system , and myriad other important function in our body .     so , live at the equator , we get lot and lot of ultraviolet radiation and the melanin — this wonderful , complex , ancient polymer compound in our skin — serve as a superb natural sunscreen . this polymer be amazing because it be present in so many different organism . melanin , in various form , have probably be on the earth a billion year , and have be recruit over and over again by evolution , as often happen . why change it if it work ?     so melanin be recruit , in our lineage , and specifically in our early ancestor evolve in africa , to be a natural sunscreen . where it protect the body against the degradation of ultraviolet radiation , the destruction , or damage to dna , and the breakdown of a very important molecule call folate , which help to fuel cell production , and reproduction in the body . so , it be wonderful . we evolve this very protective , wonderful covering of melanin .     but then we move . and human disperse — not once , but twice . major move , outside of our equatorial homeland , from africa into other part of the old world , and most recently , into the new world . when human disperse into these latitude , what do they face ? condition be significantly colder , but they be also less intense with respect to the ultraviolet regime .     so if we be somewhere in the northern hemisphere , look at what be happen to the ultraviolet radiation . we be still get a dose of uva . but all of the uvb , or you all of it , be dissipate through the thickness of the atmosphere . in the winter , when you be ski in the alp , you may experience ultraviolet radiation . but it be all uva , and , significantly , that uva have no ability to make vitamin d in your skin .     so people inhabit northern hemispheric environment be bereft of the potential to make vitamin d in their skin for most of the year . this have tremendous consequence for the evolution of human skin pigmentation . because what happen , in order to ensure health and well - being , these lineage of people disperse into the northern hemisphere lose their pigmentation . there be natural selection for the evolution of lightly pigment skin .     here we begin to see the evolution of the beautiful sepia rainbow that now characterize all of humanity . lightly pigment skin evolve not just once , not just twice , but probably three time . not just in modern human , but in one of our distant unrelated ancestor , the neanderthal . a remarkable , remarkable testament to the power of evolution . human have be on the move for a long time . and just in the last 5,000 year , in increase rate , over increase distance . here be just some of the big movement of people , voluntary movement , in the last 5,000 year .     look at some of the major latitudinal transgression : people from high uv area go to low uv and vice versa . and not all these move be voluntary . between 1520 and 1867 , 12 million , 500 people be move from high uv to low uv area in the transatlantic slave trade . now this have all sort of invidious social consequence . but it also have deleterious health consequence to people .     so what ? we 've be on the move . we be so clever we can overcome all of these seem biological impediment . well , often we be unaware of the fact that we be live in environment in which our skin be inherently poorly adapt . some of we with lightly pigment skin live in high - uv area . some of we with darkly pigment skin live in low - uv area . these have tremendous consequence for our health .     we have to , if we be lightly pigment , be careful about the problem of skin cancer , and destruction of folate in our body , by lot of sun . epidemiologist and doctor have be very good about tell we about protect our skin . what they have not be so good about instruct people be the problem of darkly pigment people live in high latitude area , or work inside all the time .     because the problem there be just as severe , but it be more sinister , because vitamin d deficiency , from a lack of ultraviolet b radiation , be a major problem . vitamin d deficiency creep up on people , and cause all sort of health problem to their bone , to their gradual decay of their immune system , or loss of immune function , and probably some problem with their mood and health , their mental health .     so we have , in skin pigmentation , one of these wonderful product of evolution that still have consequence for we today . and the social consequence , as we know , be incredibly profound . we live in a world where we have lightly and darkly pigment people live next to one another , but often bring into proximity initially as a result of very invidious social interaction . so how can we overcome this ? how can we begin to understand it ? evolution help we .     200 year after darwin 's birthday , we have the first moderately pigment president of the united states .
