   first of all , I be a geek . I be an organic food - eating , carbon footprint - minimizing , robotic surgery geek . and I really want to build green , but I be very suspicious of all of these well - mean article , people long on moral authority and short on datum , tell I how to do these kind of thing . and so I have to figure this out for myself . for example : be this evil ? I have drop a blob of organic yogurt from happy self - actualize local cow on my counter top , and I grab a paper towel and I want to wipe it up . but can I use a paper towel ? ( laughter )     the answer to this can be find in embody energy . this be the amount of energy that go into any paper towel or embody water , and every time I use a paper towel , I be use this much virtual energy and water . wipe it up , throw it away . now , if I compare that to a cotton towel that I can use a thousand time , I do not have a whole lot of embody energy until I wash that yogurty towel . this be now operate energy . so if I throw my towel in the washing machine , I 've now put energy and water back into that towel ... unless I use a front - loading , high - efficiency washing machine , ( laughter ) and then it look a little bit well . but what about a recycled paper towel that come in those little half sheet ? well , now a paper towel look well . screw the paper towel . let us go to a sponge . I wipe it up with a sponge , and I put it under the running water , and I have a lot less energy and a lot more water . unless you be like I and you leave the handle in the position of hot even when you turn it on , and then you start to use more energy . or bad , you let it run until it be warm to rinse out your towel . and now all bet be off .     ( laughter )     so what this say be that sometimes the thing that you least expect — the position in which you put the handle — have a big effect than any of those other thing that you be try to optimize . now imagine someone as twisted as I try to build a house . ( laughter ) that be what my husband and I be do right now . and so , we want to know , how green could we be ? and there be a thousand and one article out there tell we how to make all these green trade - off . and they be just as suspect in tell we to optimize these little thing around the edge and miss the elephant in the living room . now , the average house have about 300 megawatt hour of embody energy in it ; this be the energy it take to make it — million and million of paper towel .     we want to know how much well we could do . and so , like many people , we start with a house on a lot , and I be go to show you a typical construction on the top and what we be do on the bottom . so first , we demolish it . it take some energy , but if you deconstruct it — you take it all apart , you use the bit — you can get some of that energy back . we then dig a big hole to put in a rainwater catchment tank to take our yard water independent . and then we pour a big foundation for passive solar . now , you can reduce the embody energy by about 25 percent by use high fly ash concrete . we then put in framing . and so this be frame — lumber , composite material — and it be kind of hard to get the embody energy out of that , but it can be a sustainable resource if you use fsc - certify lumber .     we then go on to the first thing that be very surprising . if we put aluminum window in this house , we would double the energy use right there . now , pvc be a little bit well , but still not as good as the wood that we choose . we then put in plumbing , electrical and hvac , and insulate . now , spray foam be an excellent insulator — it fill in all the crack — but it be pretty high embody energy , and , spray - in cellulose or blue jean be a much low energy alternative to that . we also use straw bale infill for our library , which have zero embody energy . when it come time to sheetrock , if you use ecorock it be about a quarter of the embody energy of standard sheetrock .     and then you get to the finish , the subject of all of those " go green " article , and on the scale of a house they almost make no difference at all . and yet , all the press be focus on that . except for floor . if you put carpeting in your house , it be about a tenth of the embody energy of the entire house , unless you use concrete or wood for a much low embody energy . so now we add in the final construction energy , we add it all up , and we 've build a house for less than half of the typical embody energy for build a house like this .     but before we pat ourselves too much on the back , we have pour 151 megawatt hour of energy into construct this house when there be a house there before . and so the question be : how could we make that back ? and so if I run my new energy -    so here it be . you can check : I be short , I be french , I have a pretty strong french accent , so that be go to be clear in a moment .     maybe a sobering thought and something you all know about . and I suspect many of you give something to the people of haiti this year . and there be something else I believe in the back of your mind you also know . that is , every day , 25,000 child die of entirely preventable cause . that be a haiti earthquake every eight day . and I suspect many of you probably give something towards that problem as well , but somehow it do not happen with the same intensity .     so why be that ? well , here be a thought experiment for you . imagine you have a few million dollar that you 've raise — maybe you be a politician in a develop country and you have a budget to spend . you want to spend it on the poor : how do you go about it ? do you believe the people who tell you that all we need to do be to spend money ? that we know how to eradicate poverty , we just need to do more ? or do you believe the people who tell you that aid be not go to help , on the contrary it might hurt , it might exacerbate corruption , dependence , etc . ? or maybe you turn to the past . after all , we have spend billion of dollar on aid . maybe you look at the past and see . have it do any good ?     and , sadly , we do not know . and bad of all , we will never know . and the reason be that — take africa for example . african have already get a lot of aid . these be the blue bar . and the gdp in africa be not make much progress . okay , fine . how do you know what would have happen without the aid ? maybe it would have be much bad , or maybe it would have be well . we have no idea . we do not know what the counterfactual be . there be only one africa .     so what do you do ? to give the aid , and hope and pray that something come out of it ? or do you focus on your everyday life and let the earthquake every eight day continue to happen ? the thing be , if we do not know whether we be do any good , we be not any well than the medieval doctor and their leech . sometimes the patient get well , sometimes the patient die . be it the leech ? be it something else ? we do not know .     so here be some other question . they be small question , but they be not that small . immunization , that be the cheap way to save a child 's life . and the world have spend a lot of money on it : the gavi and the gate foundation be each pledge a lot of money towards it , and develop country themselves have be do a lot of effort . and yet , every year at least 25 million child do not get the immunization they should get . so this be what you call a " last mile problem . " the technology be there , the infrastructure be there , and yet it do not happen . so you have your million . how do you use your million to solve this last mile problem ?     and here be another question : malaria . malaria kill almost 900,000 people every year , most of they in sub - saharan africa , most of they under five . in fact , that be the lead cause of under - five mortality . we already know how to kill malaria , but some people come to you and say , " you have your million . how about bed net ? " bed net be very cheap . for 10 dollar , you can manufacture and ship an insecticide treat bed net and you can teach someone to use they . and , not only do they protect the people who sleep under they , but they have these great contagion benefit . if half of a community sleep under a net , the other half also benefit because the contagion of the disease spread . and yet , only a quarter of kid at risk sleep under a net . society should be willing to go out and subsidize the net , give they for free , or , for that matter , pay people to use they because of those contagion benefit . " not so fast , " say other people . " if you give the net for free , people be not go to value they . they be not go to use they , or at least they be not go to use they as bed net , maybe as fishing net . " so , what do you do ? do you give the net for free to maximize coverage , or do you make people pay in order to make sure that they really value they ? how do you know ?     and a third question : education . maybe that be the solution , maybe we should send kid to school . but how do you do that ? do you hire teacher ? do you build more school ? do you provide school lunch ? how do you know ?     so here be the thing . I can not answer the big question , whether aid do any good or not . but these three question , I can answer they . it be not the middle age anymore , it be the 21st century . and in the 20th century , randomize , control trial have revolutionize medicine by allow we to distinguish between drug that work and drug that do not work . and you can do the same randomize , control trial for social policy . you can put social innovation to the same rigorous , scientific test that we use for drug . and in this way , you can take the guesswork out of policy - making by know what work , what do not work and why . and I 'll give you some example with those three question .     so I start with immunization . here be udaipur district , rajasthan . beautiful . well , when I start work there , about one percent of child be fully immunize . that be bad , but there be place like that . now , it be not because the vaccine be not there — they be there and they be free — and it be not because parent do not care about their kid . the same child that be not immunize against measle , if they do get measle , parent will spend thousand of rupee to help they . so you get these empty village subcenter and crowded hospital . so what be the problem ? well , part of the problem , surely , be people do not fully understand . after all , in this country as well , all sort of myth and misconception go around immunization . so if that be the case , that be difficult , because persuasion be really difficult . but maybe there be another problem as well . it be go from intention to action . imagine you be a mother in udaipur district , rajasthan . you have to walk a few kilometer to get your kid immunize . and maybe when you get there , what you find be this : the subcenter be closed . ao you have to come back , and you be so busy and you have so many other thing to do , you will always tend to postpone and postpone , and eventually it get too late . well , if that be the problem , then that be much easy . because a , we can make it easy , and b , we can maybe give people a reason to act today , rather than wait till tomorrow .     so these be simple idea , but we do not know . so let us try they . so what we do be we do a randomized , control trial in 134 village in udaipur district . so the blue dot be select randomly . we make it easy — I 'll tell you how in a moment . in the red dot , we make it easy and give people a reason to act now . the white dot be comparison , nothing change . so we make it easy by organize this monthly camp where people can get their kid immunize . and then you make it easy and give a reason to act now by add a kilo of lentil for each immunization . now , a kilo of lentil be tiny . it be never go to convince anybody to do something that they do not want to do . on the other hand , if your problem be you tend to postpone , then it might give you a reason to act today rather than later .     so what do we find ? well , beforehand , everything be the same . that be the beauty of randomization . afterwards , the camp — just have the camp — increase immunization from six percent to 17 percent . that be full immunization . that be not bad , that be a good improvement . add the lentil and you reach to 38 percent . so here you 've get your answer . make it easy and give a kilo of lentil , you multiply immunization rate by six . now , you might say , " well , but it be not sustainable . we can not keep give lentil to people . " well , it turn out it be wrong economic , because it be cheap to give lentil than not to give they . since you have to pay for the nurse anyway , the cost per immunization end up be cheap if you give incentive than if you do not .     how about bed net ? should you give they for free , or should you ask people to pay for they ? so the answer hinge on the answer to three simple question . one be : if people must pay for a bed net , be they go to purchase they ? the second one be : if I give bed net for free , be people go to use they ? and the third one be : do free bed net discourage future purchase ? the third one be important because if we think people get use to handout , it might destroy market to distribute free bed net . now this be a debate that have generate a lot of emotion and angry rhetoric . it be more ideological than practical , but it turn out it be an easy question . we can know the answer to this question . we can just run an experiment . and many experiment have be run , and you all have the same result , so I be just go to talk to you about one .     and this one that be in kenya , they go around and distribute to people voucher , discount voucher . so people with their voucher could get the bed net in the local pharmacy . and some people get 100 percent discount , and some people get 20 percent discount , and some people get 50 percent discount , etc . and now we can see what happen . so , how about the purchasing ? well , what you can see be that when people have to pay for their bed net , the coverage rate really fall down a lot . so even with partial subsidy , three dollar be still not the full cost of a bed net , and now you only have 20 percent of the people with the bed net , you lose the health immunity , that be not great . second thing be , how about the use ? well , the good news be , people , if they have the bed net , will use the bed net regardless of how they get it . if they get it for free , they use it . if they have to pay for it , they use it . how about the long term ? in the long term , people who get the free bed net , one year later , be offer the option to purchase a bed net at two dollar . and people who get the free one be actually more likely to purchase the second one than people who do not get a free one . so people do not get use to handout ; they get use to net . maybe we need to give they a little bit more credit .     so , that be for bed net . so you will think , " that be great . you know how to immunize kid , you know how to give bed net . " but what politician need be a range of option . they need to know : out of all the thing I could do , what be the good way to achieve my goal ? so suppose your goal be to get kid into school . there be so many thing you could do . you could pay for uniform , you could eliminate fee , you could build latrine , you could give girl sanitary pad , etc . , etc . so what be the good ? well , at some level , we think all of these thing should work . so , be that sufficient ? if we think they should work intuitively , should we go for they ? well , in business , that be certainly not the way we would go about it .     consider for example transport good . before the canal be invent in britain before the industrial revolution , good use to go on horse cart . and then canal be build , and with the same horseman and the same horse , you could carry ten time as much cargo . so should they have continue to carry the good on the horse cart , on the ground , that they would eventually get there ? well , if that have be the case , there would have be no industrial revolution . so why should not we do the same with social policy ? in technology , we spend so much time experiment , fine - tuning , get the absolute cheap way to do something , so why be not we do that with social policy ?     well , with experiment , what you can do be answer a simple question . suppose you have 100 dollar to spend on various intervention . how many extra year of education do you get for your hundred dollar ? now I be go to show you what we get with various education intervention . so the first one be if you want the usual suspect , hire teacher , school meal , school uniform , scholarship . and that be not bad . for your hundred dollar , you get between one and three extra year of education . thing that do not work so well be bribe parent , just because so many kid be already go to school that you end up spend a lot of money . and here be the most surprising result . tell people the benefit of education , that be very cheap to do . so for every hundred dollar you spend do that , you get 40 extra year of education . and , in place where there be worm , intestinal worm , cure the kid of their worm . and for every hundred dollar , you get almost 30 extra year of education . so this be not your intuition , this be not what people would have go for , and yet , these be the program that work . we need that kind of information , we need more of it , and then we need to guide policy .     so now , I start from the big problem , and I could not answer it . and I cut it into small question , and I have the answer to these small question . and they be good , scientific , robust answer .     so let us go back to haiti for a moment . in haiti , about 200,000 people die — actually , a bit more by the late estimate . and the response of the world be great : two billion dollar got pledge just last month , so that be about 10,000 dollar per death . that do not sound like that much when you think about it . but if we be willing to spend 10,000 dollar for every child under five who die , that would be 90 billion per year just for that problem . and yet it do not happen . so , why be that ? well , I think what part of the problem be that , in haiti , although the problem be huge , somehow we understand it , it be localize . you give your money to doctor without border , you give your money to partner in health , and they 'll send in the doctor , and they 'll send in the lumber , and they 'll helicopter thing out and in . and the problem of poverty be not like that . so , first , it be mostly invisible ; second , it be huge ; and third , we do not know whether we be do the right thing . there be no silver bullet . you can not helicopter people out of poverty . and that be very frustrating .     but look what we just do today . I give you three simple answer to three question : give lentil to immunize people , provide free bed net , deworm child . with immunization or bed net , you can save a life for 300 dollar per life save . with deworming , you can get an extra year of education for three dollar . so we can not eradicate poverty just yet , but we can get start . and maybe we can get start small with thing that we know be effective .     here be an example of how this can be powerful . deworme . worm have a little bit of a problem grab the headline . they be not beautiful and do not kill anybody . and yet , when the young global leader in davos show the number I give you , they start deworm the world . and thank to deworm the world , and the effort of many country government and foundation , 20 million school - aged child got deworme in 2009 . so this evidence be powerful . it can prompt action .     so we should get start now . it be not go to be easy . it be a very slow process . you have to keep experiment , and sometimes ideology have to be trump by practicality . and sometimes what work somewhere do not work elsewhere . so it be a slow process , but there be no other way . these economic I be propose , it be like 20th century medicine . it be a slow , deliberative process of discovery . there be no miracle cure , but modern medicine be save million of life every year , and we can do the same thing .     and now , maybe , we can go back to the big question that I start with at the beginning . I can not tell you whether the aid we have spend in the past have make a difference , but can we come back here in 30 year and say , " what we have do , it really prompt a change for the well . " I believe we can and I hope we will .     thank you .     ( applause )

   so , if you be in the audience today , or maybe you be watch this talk in some other time or place , you be a participant in the digital right ecosystem . whether you be an artist , a technologist , a lawyer or a fan , the handling of copyright directly impact your life . right management be no long simply a question of ownership , it be a complex web of relationship and a critical part of our cultural landscape . youtube care deeply about the right of content owner , but in order to give they choice about what they can do with copy , mashup and more , we need to first identify when copyright material be upload to our site .     let us look at a specific video so you can see how it work . two year ago , record artist chris brown release the official video of his single " forever . " a fan see it on tv , record it with her camera phone , and upload it to youtube . because sony music have register chris brown 's video in our content i d system , within second of attempt to upload the video , the copy be detect , give sony the choice of what to do next .     but how do we know that the user 's video be a copy ? well , it start with content owner deliver asset into our database , along with a usage policy that tell we what to do when we find a match . we compare each upload against all of the reference file in our database . this heat map be go to show you how the brain of the system work . here we can see the original reference file be compare to the user generate content . the system compare every moment of one to the other to see if there be a match . this mean that we can identify a match even if the copy use be just a portion of the original file , play it in slow motion and have degrade audio and video quality . and we do this every time that a video be upload to youtube . and that be over 20 hour of video every minute . when we find a match , we apply the policy that the right owner have set down .     and the scale and the speed of this system be truly breathtaking . we be not just talk about a few video , we be talk about over 100 year of video every day , between new upload and the legacy scan we regularly do across all of the content on the site . when we compare those hundred year of video , we be compare it against million of reference file in our database . it would be like 36,000 people stare at 36,000 monitor each and every day , without so much as a coffee break .     now , what do we do when we find a match ? well , most right owner , instead of blocking , will allow the copy to be publish . and then they benefit through the exposure , advertising and link sale . remember chris brown 's video " forever " ? well , it have its day in the sun and then it drop off the chart , and that look like the end of the story , but sometime last year , a young couple got marry . this be their wedding video . you may have see it .     ( music )     what be amazing about this be , if the processional of the wedding be this much fun , can you imagine how much fun the reception must have be ? I mean , who be these people ? I totally want to go to that wedding .     so their little wedding video go on to get over 40 million view . and instead of sony blocking , they allow the upload to occur . and they put advertising against it and link from it to itune . and the song , 18 month old , go back to number four on the itune chart . so sony be generate revenue from both of these . and jill and kevin , the happy couple , they come back from their honeymoon and find that their video have go crazy viral . and they 've end up on a bunch of talk show , and they 've use it as an opportunity to make a difference . the video 's inspire over 26,000 dollar in donation to end domestic violence . the " jk wedding [ entrance ] dance " become so popular that nbc parody it on the season finale of " the office , " which just go to show , it be truly an ecosystem of culture . because it be not just amateur borrow from big studio , but sometimes big studio borrow back .     by empower choice , we can create a culture of opportunity . and all it take to change thing around be to allow for choice through right identification . so why have no one ever solve this problem before ? it be because it be a big problem , and it be complicated and messy . it be not uncommon for a single video to have multiple right owner . there be musical label . there be multiple music publisher . and each of these can vary by country . there be lot of case where we have more than one work mash together . so we have to manage many claim to the same video .     youtube 's content i d system address all of these case . but the system only work through the participation of right owner . if you have content that other be upload to youtube , you should register in the content i d system , and then you 'll have the choice about how your content be use . and think carefully about the policy that you attach to that content . by simply block all reuse , you 'll miss out on new art form , new audience , new distribution channel and new revenue stream .     but it be not just about dollar and impression . just look at all the joy that be spread through progressive right management and new technology . and I think we can all agree that joy be definitely an idea worth spread .     thank you .    trees epitomize stasis . tree be root in the ground in one place for many human generation , but if we shift our perspective from the trunk to the twig , tree become very dynamic entity , move and grow . and I decide to explore this movement by turn tree into artist . I simply tie the end of a paintbrush onto a twig . I wait for the wind to come up and hold up a canvas , and that produce art . the piece of art you see on your left be paint by a western red cedar and that on your right by a douglas fir , and what I learn be that different specie have different signature , like a picasso versus a monet .     but I be also interested in the movement of tree and how this art might let I capture that and quantify it , so to measure the distance that a single vine maple tree — which produce this painting — move in a single year , I simply measure and sum each of those line . I multiply they by the number of twig per branch and the number of branch per tree and then divide that by the number of minute per year . and so I be able to calculate how far a single tree move in a single year . you might have a guess . the answer be actually 186,540 mile , or seven time around the globe . and so simply by shift our perspective from a single trunk to the many dynamic twig , we be able to see that tree be not simply static entity , but rather extremely dynamic .     and I begin to think about way that we might consider this lesson of tree , to consider other entity that be also static and stick , but which cry for change and dynamicism , and one of those entity be our prison . prison , of course , be where people who break our law be stick , confine behind bar . and our prison system itself be stick . the united states have over 2.3 million incarcerate man and woman . that number be rise . of the 100 incarcerate people that be release , 60 will return to prison . fund for education , for training and for rehabilitation be decline , so this despair cycle of incarceration continue . I decide to ask whether the lesson I have learn from tree as artist could be apply to a static institution such as our prison , and I think the answer be yes .     in the year 2007 , I start a partnership with the washington state department of correction . work with four prison , we begin bring science and scientist , sustainability and conservation project to four state prison . we give    I want to ask you all to consider for a second the very simple fact that , by far , most of what we know about the universe come to we from light . we can stand on the earth and look up at the night sky and see star with our bare eye . the sun burn our peripheral vision . we see light reflect off the moon . and in the time since galileo point that rudimentary telescope at the celestial body , the know universe have come to we through light , across vast era in cosmic history . and with all of our modern telescope , we 've be able to collect this stunning silent movie of the universe — these series of snapshot that go all the way back to the big bang .     and yet , the universe be not a silent movie because the universe be not silent . I would like to convince you that the universe have a soundtrack and that soundtrack be play on space itself , because space can wobble like a drum . it can ring out a kind of recording throughout the universe of some of the most dramatic event as they unfold . now we would like to be able to add to a kind of glorious visual composition that we have of the universe — a sonic composition . and while we 've never hear the sound from space , we really should , in the next few year , start to turn up the volume on what be go on out there .     so in this ambition to capture song from the universe , we turn our focus to black hole and the promise they have , because black hole can bang on space - time like mallet on a drum and have a very characteristic song , which I would like to play for you — some of our prediction for what that song will be like . now black hole be dark against a dark sky . we can not see they directly . they be not bring to we with light , at least not directly . we can see they indirectly , because black hole wreak havoc on their environment . they destroy star around they . they churn up debris in their surrounding . but they will not come to we directly through light . we might one day see a shadow a black hole can cast on a very bright background , but we have not yet . and yet black hole may be hear even if they be not see , and that be because they bang on space - time like a drum .     now we owe the idea that space can ring like a drum to albert einstein — to whom we owe so much . einstein realize that if space be empty , if the universe be empty , it would be like this picture , except for maybe without the helpful grid draw on it . but if we be freely fall through the space , even without this helpful grid , we might be able to paint it ourselves , because we would notice that we travel along straight line , undeflecte straight path through the universe . einstein also realize — and this be the real meat of the matter — that if you put energy or mass in the universe , it would curve space , and a freely fall object would pass by , let us say , the sun and it would be deflect along the natural curve in the space . it be einstein 's great general theory of relativity . now even light will be bend by those path . and you can be bent so much that you be catch in orbit around the sun , as the earth be , or the moon around the earth . these be the natural curve in space .     what einstein do not realize be that , if you take our sun and you crush it down to six kilometer — so you take a million time the mass of the earth and you crush it to six kilometer across , you would make a black hole , an object so dense that if light veer too close , it would never escape — a dark shadow against the universe . it be not einstein who realize this , it be karl schwarzschild who be a german jew in world war I — join the german army already an accomplished scientist , work on the russian front . " and einstein be very impressed with his exact solution , and I should hope also the dedication of the scientist . this be the hardworke scientist under harsh condition . and he take schwarzschild 's idea to the prussian academy of science the next week . but einstein always think black hole be a mathematical oddity . he do not believe they exist in nature . he think nature would protect we from their formation . it be decade before the term " black hole " be coin and people realize that black hole be real astrophysical object — in fact they be the death state of very massive star that collapse catastrophically at the end of their lifetime .     now our sun will not collapse to a black hole . it be actually not massive enough . but if we do a little thought experiment — as einstein I think this be a problem .    good morning everybody .     I work with really amazing , little , itty - bitty creature call cell . and let I tell you what it be like to grow these cell in the lab . I work in a lab where we take cell out of their native environment . we plate they into dish that we sometimes call petri dish . and we feed they — sterilely of course — with what we call cell culture medium — which be like their food — and we grow they in incubator .     why do I do this ? we observe the cell in a plate , and they be just on the surface . but what we be really try to do in my lab be to engineer tissue out of they . what do that even mean ? well it mean grow an actual heart , let us say , or grow a piece of bone that can be put into the body . not only that , but they can also be use for disease model . and for this purpose , traditional cell culture technique just really be not enough . the cell be kind of homesick ; the dish do not feel like their home . and so we need to do well at copy their natural environment to get they to thrive . we call this the biomimetic paradigm — copy nature in the lab .     let us take the example of the heart , the topic of a lot of my research . what make the heart unique ? well , the heart beat , rhythmically , tirelessly , faithfully . we copy this in the lab by outfit cell culture system with electrode . these electrode act like mini pacemaker to get the cell to contract in the lab . what else do we know about the heart ? well , heart cell be pretty greedy . nature feed the heart cell in your body with a very , very dense blood supply . in the lab , we micro - pattern channel in the biomaterial on which we grow the cell , and this allow we to flow the cell culture medium , the cell ' food , through the scaffold where we be grow the cell — a lot like what you might expect from a capillary bed in the heart .     so this bring I to lesson number one : life can do a lot with very little . let us take the example of electrical stimulation . let us see how powerful just one of these essential can be . on the left , we see a tiny piece of beat heart tissue that I engineer from rat cell in the lab . it be about the size of a mini marshmallow . and after one week , it be beat . you can see it in the upper left - hand corner . but do not worry if you can not see it so well . it be amazing that these cell beat at all . but what be really amazing be that the cell , when we electrically stimulate they , like with a pacemaker , that they beat so much more .     but that bring I to lesson number two : cell do all the work . in a sense , tissue engineer have a bit of an identity crisis here , because structural engineer build bridge and big thing , computer engineer , computer , but what we be do be actually build enable technology for the cell themselves . what do this mean for we ? let us do something really simple . let us remind ourselves that cell be not an abstract concept . let us remember that our cell sustain our life in a very real way . " we be what we eat , " could easily be describe as , " we be what our cell eat . " and in the case of the flora in our gut , these cell may not even be human . but it be also worth note that cell also mediate our experience of life . behind every sound , sight , touch , taste and smell be a corresponding set of cell that receive this information and interpret it for we . it beg the question : shall we expand our sense of environmental stewardship to include the ecosystem of our own body ?     I invite you to talk about this with I far , and in the meantime , I wish you luck . may none of your non - cancer cell become endangered specie .     thank you .     ( applause )

   so I just want to tell you my story . I spend a lot of time teach adult how to use visual language and doodle in the workplace . and naturally , I encounter a lot of resistance , because it be consider to be anti - intellectual and counter to serious learning . but I have a problem with that belief , because I know that doodling have a profound impact on the way that we can process information and the way that we can solve problem .     so I be curious about why there be a disconnect between the way our society perceive doodle and the way that the reality be . so I discover some very interesting thing . for example , there be no such thing as a flattering definition of a doodle . in the 17th century , a doodle be a simpleton or a fool — as in yankee doodle . in the 18th century , it become a verb , and it mean to swindle or ridicule or to make fun of someone . in the 19th century , it be a corrupt politician . and today , we have what be perhaps our most offensive definition , at least to I , which be the follow : to doodle officially mean to dawdle , to dilly dally , to monkey around , to make meaningless mark , to do something of little value , substance or import , and — my personal favorite — to do nothing . no wonder people be averse to doodle at work . do nothing at work be akin to masturbate at work ; it be totally inappropriate .     ( laughter )     additionally , I 've hear horror story from people whose teacher scold they , of course , for doodle in classroom . and they have boss who scold they for doodle in the boardroom . there be a powerful cultural norm against doodle in setting in which we be suppose to learn something . and unfortunately , the press tend to reinforce this norm when they be report on a doodling scene — of an important person at a confirmation hearing and the like — they typically use word like " discover " or " catch " or " find out , " as if there be some sort of criminal act be commit .     and additionally , there be a psychological aversion to doodle — thank you , freud . in the 1930 , freud tell we all that you could analyze people 's psyche base on their doodle . this be not accurate , but it do happen to tony blair at the davos forum in 2005 , when his doodle be , of course , " discover " and he be label the follow thing . now it turn out to be bill gate ' doodle . ( laughter ) and bill , if you be here , nobody think you be megalomaniacal . but that do contribute to people not want to share their doodle .     and here be the real deal . here be what I believe . I think that our culture be so intensely focus on verbal information that we be almost blind to the value of doodling . and I be not comfortable with that . and so because of that belief that I think need to be burst , I be here to send we all hurtle back to the truth . and here be the truth : doodle be an incredibly powerful tool , and it be a tool that we need to remember and to re - learn .     so here be a new definition for doodle . and I hope there be someone in here from the oxford english dictionary , because I want to talk to you later . here be the real definition : doodle be really to make spontaneous mark to help yourself think . that be why million of people doodle . here be another interesting truth about the doodle : people who doodle when they be expose to verbal information retain more of that information than their non - doodling counterpart . we think doodle be something you do when you lose focus , but in reality , it be a preemptive measure to stop you from lose focus . additionally , it have a profound effect on creative problem - solve and deep information processing .     there be four way that learner intake information so that they can make decision . they be visual , auditory , reading and writing and kinesthetic . now in order for we to really chew on information and do something with it , we have to engage at least two of those modality , or we have to engage one of those modality couple with an emotional experience . the incredible contribution of the doodle be that it engage all four learn modality simultaneously with the possibility of an emotional experience . that be a pretty solid contribution for a behavior equate with do nothing .     this be so nerdy , but this make I cry when I discover this . so they do anthropological research into the unfolding of artistic activity in child , and they find that , across space and time , all child exhibit the same evolution in visual logic as they grow . in other word , they have a shared and grow complexity in visual language that happen in a predictable order . and I think that be incredible . I think that mean doodle be native to we and we simply be deny ourselves that instinct . and finally , a lot a people be not privy to this , but the doodle be a precursor to some of our great cultural asset . this be but one : this be frank gehry the architect 's precursor to the guggenheim in abu dhabi .     so here be my point : under no circumstance should doodle be eradicate from a classroom or a boardroom or even the war room . on the contrary , doodle should be leverage in precisely those situation where information density be very high and the need for process that information be very high . and I will go you one far . because doodle be so universally accessible and it be not intimidate as an art form , it can be leverage as a portal through which we move people into high level of visual literacy . my friend , the doodle have never be the nemesis of intellectual thought . in reality , it be one of its great ally .     thank you .    this may sound strange , but I be a big fan of the concrete block . the first concrete block be manufacture in 1868 with a very simple idea : module make of cement of a fix measurement that fit together . very quickly concrete block become the most - use construction unit in the world . they enable we to to build thing that be large than we , building , bridge , one brick at a time . essentially concrete block have become the building block of our time .     almost a hundred year later in 1947 , lego come up with this . it be call the automatic binding brick . and in a few short year , lego brick take place in every household . it be estimate that over 400 billion brick have be produce — or 75 brick for every person on the planet . you do not have to be an engineer to make beautiful house , beautiful bridge , beautiful building . lego make it accessible . lego have essentially take the concrete block , the building block of the world , and make it into the building block of our imagination .     meanwhile the exact same year , at bell lab the next revolution be about to be announce , the next building block . the transistor be a small plastic unit that would take we from a world of static brick pile on top of each other to a world where everything be interactive . like the concrete block , the transistor allow you to build much large , more complex circuit , one brick at a time .     but there be a main difference : the transistor be only for expert . I personally do not accept this , that the building block of our time be reserve for expert , so I decide to change that . eight year ago when I be at the medium lab , I start explore this idea of how to put the power of engineer in the hand of artist and designer .     a few year ago I start develop littlebit . let I show you how they work . littlebit be electronic module with each one specific function . they be pre - engineer to be light , sound , motor and sensor . and the good part about it be they snap together with magnet . so you can not put they the wrong way . the brick be color - code . green be output , blue be power , pink be input and orange be wire . so all you need to do be snap a blue to a green and very quickly you can start make large circuit . you put a blue to a green , you can make light . you can put a knob in between and now you 've make a little dimmer . switch out the knob for a pulse module , which be here , and now you 've make a little blinker . add this buzzer for some extra punch and you 've create a noise machine . I be go to stop that .     so beyond simple play , littlebit be actually pretty powerful . instead of have to program , to wire , to solder , littlebit allow you to program use very simple intuitive gesture . so to make this blink fast or slow , you would just turn this knob and basically make it pulse fast or slow . the idea behind littlebit be that it be a grow library . we want to make every single interaction in the world into a ready - to - use brick . light , sound , solar panel , motor — everything should be accessible .     we 've be give littlebit to kid and see they play with they . and it be be an incredible experience . the nice thing be how they start to understand the electronic around they from everyday that they do not learn at school . for example , how a nightlight work , or why an elevator door stay open , or how an ipod respond to touch . we 've also be take littlebit to design school . so for example , we 've have designer with no experience with electronic whatsoever start to play with littlebit as a material . here you see , with felt and paper water bottle , we have geordie make ...     ( clanging )     ( buzzing )     a few week ago we take littlebit to risd and give they to some designer with no experience in engineering whatsoever — just cardboard , wood and paper — and tell they " make something . " here be an example of a project they make , a motion - activate confetti canon ball . ( laughter ) but wait , this be actually my favorite project . it be a lobster make of playdough that be afraid of the dark .     ( laughter )     to these non - engineer , littlebit become another material , electronic become just another material . and we want to make this material accessible to everyone . so littlebit be open - source . you can go on the website , download all the design file , make they yourself . we want to encourage a world of creator , of inventor , of contributor , because this world that we live in , this interactive world , be ours . so go ahead and start invent .     thank you .    just a moment ago , my daughter rebecca texte I for good luck . her text say , " mom , you will rock . " I love this . get that text be like get a hug . and so there you have it . I embody the central paradox . I be a woman who love get text who be go to tell you that too many of they can be a problem .     actually that reminder of my daughter bring I to the beginning of my story . 1996 , when I give my first tedtalk , rebecca be five year old and she be sit right there in the front row . I have just write a book that celebrate our life on the internet and I be about to be on the cover of wired magazine . in those heady day , we be experiment with chat room and online virtual community . we be explore different aspect of ourselves . and then we unplug . I be excited . and , as a psychologist , what excite I most be the idea that we would use what we learn in the virtual world about ourselves , about our identity , to live well life in the real world .     now fast - forward to 2012 . I be back here on the ted stage again . my daughter 's 20 . she be a college student . she sleep with her cellphone , so do i. and I 've just write a new book , but this time it be not one that will get I on the cover of wired magazine . so what happen ? I be still excite by technology , but I believe , and I be here to make the case , that we be let it take we place that we do not want to go .     over the past 15 year , I 've study technology of mobile communication and I 've interview hundred and hundred of people , young and old , about their plug in life . and what I 've find be that our little device , those little device in our pocket , be so psychologically powerful that they do not only change what we do , they change who we be . some of the thing we do now with our device be thing that , only a few year ago , we would have find odd or disturbing , but they 've quickly come to seem familiar , just how we do thing .     so just to take some quick example : people text or do email during corporate board meeting . they text and shop and go on facebook during class , during presentation , actually during all meeting . people talk to I about the important new skill of make eye contact while you be texte . ( laughter ) people explain to I that it be hard , but that it can be do . parent text and do email at breakfast and at dinner while their child complain about not have their parent ' full attention . but then these same child deny each other their full attention . this be a recent shot of my daughter and her friend be together while not be together . and we even text at funeral . I study this . we remove ourselves from our grief or from our revery and we go into our phone .     why do this matter ? it matter to I because I think we be set ourselves up for trouble — trouble certainly in how we relate to each other , but also trouble in how we relate to ourselves and our capacity for self - reflection . we be getting use to a new way of be alone together . people want to be with each other , but also elsewhere — connect to all the different place they want to be . people want to customize their life . they want to go in and out of all the place they be because the thing that matter most to they be control over where they put their attention . so you want to go to that board meeting , but you only want to pay attention to the bit that interest you . and some people think that be a good thing . but you can end up hide from each other , even as we be all constantly connect to each other .     a 50 - year - old business man lament to I that he feel he do not have colleague anymore at work . when he go to work , he do not stop by to talk to anybody , he do not call . and he say he do not want to interrupt his colleague because , he say , " they be too busy on their email . " but then he stop himself and he say , " you know , I be not tell you the truth . I be the one who do not want to be interrupt . I think I should want to , but actually I would rather just do thing on my blackberry . "     across the generation , I see that people can not get enough of each other , if and only if they can have each other at a distance , in amount they can control . I call it the goldilock effect : not too close , not too far , just right . but what might feel just right for that middle - aged executive can be a problem for an adolescent who need to develop face - to - face relationship . an 18 - year - old boy who use texting for almost everything say to I wistfully , " someday , someday , but certainly not now , I would like to learn how to have a conversation . "     when I ask people " what be wrong with have a conversation ? " people say , " I 'll tell you what be wrong with have a conversation . it take place in real time and you can not control what you be go to say . " so that be the bottom line . texting , email , posting , all of these thing let we present the self as we want to be . we get to edit , and that mean we get to delete , and that mean we get to retouch , the face , the voice , the flesh , the body — not too little , not too much , just right .     human relationship be rich and they be messy and they be demand . and we clean they up with technology . and when we do , one of the thing that can happen be that we sacrifice conversation for mere connection . we short - change ourselves . and over time , we seem to forget this , or we seem to stop care .     I be catch off guard when stephen colbert ask I a profound question , a profound question . he say , " do not all those little tweet , do not all those little sip of online communication , add up to one big gulp of real conversation ? " my answer be no , they do not add up . connect in sip may work for gather discrete bit of information , they may work for say , " I be think about you , " or even for say , " I love you , " — I mean , look at how I feel when I get that text from my daughter — but they do not really work for learn about each other , for really come to know and understand each other . and we use conversation with each other to learn how to have conversation with ourselves . so a flight from conversation can really matter because it can compromise our capacity for self - reflection . for kid grow up , that skill be the bedrock of development .     over and over I hear , " I would rather text than talk . " and what I be see be that people get so use to be short - change out of real conversation , so use to get by with less , that they 've become almost willing to dispense with people altogether . so for example , many people share with I this wish , that some day a more advanced version of siri , the digital assistant on apple 's iphone , will be more like a good friend , someone who will listen when other will not . I believe this wish reflect a painful truth that I 've learn in the past 15 year . that feel that no one be listen to I be very important in our relationship with technology . that be why it be so appealing to have a facebook page or a twitter feed — so many automatic listener . and the feeling that no one be listen to I make we want to spend time with machine that seem to care about we .     we be develop robot , they call they sociable robot , that be specifically design to be companion — to the elderly , to our child , to we . have we so lose confidence that we will be there for each other ? during my research I work in nursing home , and I bring in these sociable robot that be design to give the elderly the feeling that they be understand . and one day I come in and a woman who have lose a child be talk to a robot in the shape of a baby seal . it seem to be look in her eye . it seem to be follow the conversation . it comfort she . and many people find this amazing .     but that woman be try to make sense of her life with a machine that have no experience of the arc of a human life . that robot put on a great show . and we be vulnerable . people experience pretend empathy as though it be the real thing . so during that moment when that woman be experience that pretend empathy , I be think , " that robot can not empathize . it do not face death . it do not know life . "     and as that woman take comfort in her robot companion , I do not find it amazing ; I find it one of the most wrenching , complicate moment in my 15 year of work . but when I step back , I feel myself at the cold , hard center of a perfect storm . we expect more from technology and less from each other . and I ask myself , " why have thing come to this ? "     and I believe it be because technology appeal to we most where we be most vulnerable . and we be vulnerable . we be lonely , but we be afraid of intimacy . and so from social network to sociable robot , we be design technology that will give we the illusion of companionship without the demand of friendship . we turn to technology to help we feel connect in way we can comfortably control . but we be not so comfortable . we be not so much in control .     these day , those phone in our pocket be change our mind and heart because they offer we three gratify fantasy . one , that we can put our attention wherever we want it to be ; two , that we will always be hear ; and three , that we will never have to be alone . and that third idea , that we will never have to be alone , be central to change our psyche . because the moment that people be alone , even for a few second , they become anxious , they panic , they fidget , they reach for a device . just think of people at a checkout line or at a red light . be alone feel like a problem that need to be solve . and so people try to solve it by connect . but here , connection be more like a symptom than a cure . it express , but it do not solve , an underlie problem . but more than a symptom , constant connection be change the way people think of themselves . it be shape a new way of be .     the good way to describe it be , I share therefore I be . we use technology to define ourselves by share our thought and feeling even as we be have they . so before it be : I have a feeling , I want to make a call . now it be : I want to have a feeling , I need to send a text . the problem with this new regime of " I share therefore I be " be that , if we do not have connection , we do not feel like ourselves . we almost do not feel ourselves . so what do we do ? we connect more and more . but in the process , we set ourselves up to be isolate .     how do you get from connection to isolation ? you end up isolated if you do not cultivate the capacity for solitude , the ability to be separate , to gather yourself . solitude be where you find yourself so that you can reach out to other people and form real attachment . when we do not have the capacity for solitude , we turn to other people in order to feel less anxious or in order to feel alive . when this happen , we be not able to appreciate who they be . it be as though we be use they as spare part to support our fragile sense of self . we slip into thinking that always be connect be go to make we feel less alone . but we be at risk , because actually it be the opposite that be true . if we be not able to be alone , we be go to be more lonely . and if we do not teach our child to be alone , they be only go to know how to be lonely .     when I speak at ted in 1996 , report on my study of the early virtual community , I say , " those who make the most of their life on the screen come to it in a spirit of self - reflection . " and that be what I be call for here , now : reflection and , more than that , a conversation about where our current use of technology may be take we , what it might be cost we . we be smite with technology . and we be afraid , like young lover , that too much talk might spoil the romance . but it be time to talk . we grow up with digital technology and so we see it as all grow up . but it be not , it be early day . there be plenty of time for we to reconsider how we use it , how we build it . I be not suggest that we turn away from our device , just that we develop a more self - aware relationship with they , with each other and with ourselves .     I see some first step . start think of solitude as a good thing . make room for it . find way to demonstrate this as a value to your child . create sacred space at home — the kitchen , the dining room — and reclaim they for conversation . do the same thing at work . at work , we be so busy communicate that we often do not have time to think , we do not have time to talk , about the thing that really matter . change that . most important , we all really need to listen to each other , include to the boring bit . because it be when we stumble or hesitate or lose our word that we reveal ourselves to each other .     technology be make a bid to redefine human connection — how we care for each other , how we care for ourselves — but it be also give we the opportunity to affirm our value and our direction . I be optimistic . we have everything we need to start . we have each other . and we have the great chance of success if we recognize our vulnerability . that we listen when technology say it will take something complicated and promise something simple .     so in my work , I hear that life be hard , relationship be fill with risk . and then there be technology — simple , hopeful , optimistic , ever - young . it be like call in the cavalry . an ad campaign promise that online and with avatar , you can " finally , love your friend love your body , love your life , online and with avatar . " we be draw to virtual romance , to computer game that seem like world , to the idea that robot , robot , will someday be our true companion . we spend an evening on the social network instead of go to the pub with friend .     but our fantasy of substitution have cost we . now we all need to focus on the many , many way technology can lead we back to our real life , our own body , our own community , our own politic , our own planet . they need we . let us talk about how we can use digital technology , the technology of our dream , to make this life the life we can love .     thank you .    I call myself a body architect . I train in classical ballet and have a background in architecture and fashion . as a body architect , I fascinate with the human body and explore how I can transform it .    have you ever wonder what be inside your dental plaque ? probably not , but people like I do . I be an archeological geneticist at the center for evolutionary medicine at the university of zurich , and I study the origin and evolution of human health and disease by conduct genetic research on the skeletal and mummify remain of ancient human . and through this work , I hope to well understand the evolutionary vulnerability of our body , so that we can improve and well manage our health in the future .     there be different way to approach evolutionary medicine , and one way be to extract human dna from ancient bone . and from these extract , we can reconstruct the human genome at different point in time and look for change that might be relate to adaptation , risk factor and inherit disease . but this be only one half of the story .     the most important health challenge today be not cause by simple mutation in our genome , but rather result from a complex and dynamic interplay between genetic variation , diet , microbe and parasite and our immune response . all of these disease have a strong evolutionary component that directly relate to the fact that we live today in a very different environment than the one in which our body evolve . and in order to understand these disease , we need to move past study of the human genome alone and towards a more holistic approach to human health in the past .     but there be a lot of challenge for this . and first of all , what do we even study ? skeleton be ubiquitous ; they be find all over the place . but of course , all of the soft tissue have decompose , and the skeleton itself have limit health information . mummy be a great source of information , except that they be really geographically limited and limit in time as well . coprolite be fossilize human fece , and they be actually extremely interesting . you can learn a lot about ancient diet and intestinal disease , but they be very rare .     ( laughter )     so to address this problem , I put together a team of international researcher in switzerland , denmark and the u.k . to study a very poorly study , little know material that be find on people everywhere . it be a type of fossilized dental plaque that be call officially dental calculus . many of you may know it by the term tartar . it be what the dentist clean off your tooth every time that you go in for a visit . and in a typical dentistry visit , you may have about 15 to 30 milligram remove . but in ancient time before tooth brushing , up to 600 milligram might have build up on the tooth over a lifetime .     and what be really important about dental calculus be that it fossilize just like the rest of the skeleton , it be abundant in quantity before the present day and it be ubiquitous worldwide . we find it in every population around the world at all time period go back ten of thousand of year . and we even find it in neanderthal and animal .     and so previous study have only focus on microscopy . they have look at dental calculus under a microscope , and what they have find be thing like pollen and plant starch , and they would find muscle cell from animal meat and bacteria . and so what my team of researcher , what we want to do , be say , can we apply genetic and proteomic technology to go after dna and protein , and from this can we get well taxonomic resolution to really understand what be go on ?     and what we find be that we can find many commensal and pathogenic bacteria that inhabit the nasal passage and mouth . we also have find immune protein relate to infection and inflammation and protein and dna relate to diet . but what be surprising to we , and also quite exciting , be we also find bacteria that normally inhabit upper respiratory system . so it give we virtual access to the lung , which be where many important disease reside .     and we also find bacteria that normally inhabit the gut . and so we can also now virtually gain access to this even more distant organ system that , from the skeleton alone , have long decompose . and so by apply ancient dna sequence and protein mass spectrometry technology to ancient dental calculus , we can generate immense quantity of datum that then we can use to begin to reconstruct a detailed picture of the dynamic interplay between diet , infection and immunity thousand of year ago .     so what start out as an idea , be now be implement to churn out million of sequence that we can use to investigate the long - term evolutionary history of human health and disease , right down to the genetic code of individual pathogen . and from this information we can learn about how pathogen evolve and also why they continue to make we sick . and I hope I have convince you of the value of dental calculus .     and as a final parting think , on behalf of future archeologist , I would like to ask you to please think twice before you go home and brush your tooth .    I be go to talk to you about optimism — or more precisely , the optimism bias . it be a cognitive illusion that we 've be study in my lab for the past few year , and 80 percent of we have it .     it be our tendency to overestimate our likelihood of experience good event in our life and underestimate our likelihood of experience bad event . so we underestimate our likelihood of suffer from cancer , be in a car accident . we overestimate our longevity , our career prospect . in short , we be more optimistic than realistic , but we be oblivious to the fact .     take marriage for example . in the western world , divorce rate be about 40 percent . that mean that out of five married couple , two will end up split their asset . but when you ask newlywed about their own likelihood of divorce , they estimate it at zero percent . and even divorce lawyer , who should really know well , hugely underestimate their own likelihood of divorce . so it turn out that optimist be not less likely to divorce , but they be more likely to remarry . in the word of samuel johnson , " remarriage be the triumph of hope over experience . "     ( laughter )     so if we be marry , we be more likely to have kid . and we all think our kid will be especially talented . this , by the way , be my two - year - old nephew , guy . and I just want to make it absolutely clear that he be a really bad example of the optimism bias , because he be in fact uniquely talented .     ( laughter )     and I be not alone . out of four british people , three say that they be optimistic about the future of their own family . that be 75 percent . but only 30 percent say that they think family in general be do well than a few generation ago .     and this be a really important point , because we be optimistic about ourselves , we be optimistic about our kid , we be optimistic about our family , but we be not so optimistic about the guy sit next to we , and we be somewhat pessimistic about the fate of our fellow citizen and the fate of our country . but private optimism about our own personal future remain persistent . and it do not mean that we think thing will magically turn out okay , but rather that we have the unique ability to make it so .     now I be a scientist , I do experiment . so to show you what I mean , I be go to do an experiment here with you . so I be go to give you a list of ability and characteristic , and I want you to think for each of these ability where you stand relative to the rest of the population .     the first one be get along well with other . who here believe they be at the bottom 25 percent ? okay , that be about 10 people out of 1,500 . who believe they be at the top 25 percent ? that be most of we here . okay , now do the same for your driving ability . how interesting be you ? how attractive be you ? how honest be you ? and finally , how modest be you ?     so most of we put ourselves above average on most of these ability . now this be statistically impossible . we can not all be well than everyone else . ( laughter ) but if we believe we be well than the other guy , well that mean that we be more likely to get that promotion , to remain married , because we be more social , more interesting .     and it be a global phenomenon . the optimism bias have be observe in many different country — in western culture , in non - western culture , in female and male , in kid , in the elderly . it be quite widespread .     but the question be , be it good for we ? so some people say no . some people say the secret to happiness be low expectation . I think the logic go something like this : if we do not expect greatness , if we do not expect to find love and be healthy and successful , well we be not go to be disappoint when these thing do not happen . and if we be not disappointed when good thing do not happen , and we be pleasantly surprised when they do , we will be happy .     so it be a very good theory , but it turn out to be wrong for three reason . number one : whatever happen , whether you succeed or you fail , people with high expectation always feel well . because how we feel when we get dump or win employee of the month depend on how we interpret that event .     the psychologist margaret marshall and john brown study student with high and low expectation . and they find that when people with high expectation succeed , they attribute that success to their own trait . " I be a genius , therefore I get an a , therefore I 'll get an a again and again in the future . " when they fail , it be not because they be dumb , but because the exam just happen to be unfair . next time they will do well . people with low expectation do the opposite . so when they fail it be because they be dumb , and when they succeed it be because the exam just happen to be really easy . next time reality would catch up with they . so they feel bad .     number two : regardless of the outcome , the pure act of anticipation make we happy . the behavioral economist george lowenstein ask student in his university to imagine get a passionate kiss from a celebrity , any celebrity . then he say , " how much be you willing to pay to get a kiss from a celebrity if the kiss be deliver immediately , in three hour , in 24 hour , in three day , in one year , in 10 year ? he find that the student be willing to pay the most not to get a kiss immediately , but to get a kiss in three day . they be willing to pay extra in order to wait . now they be not willing to wait a year or 10 year ; no one want an age celebrity . but three day seem to be the optimum amount .     so why be that ? well if you get the kiss now , it be over and do with . but if you get the kiss in three day , well that be three day of jittery anticipation , the thrill of the wait . the student want that time to imagine where be it go to happen , how be it go to happen . anticipation make they happy .     this be , by the way , why people prefer friday to sunday . it be a really curious fact , because friday be a day of work and sunday be a day of pleasure , so you would assume that people will prefer sunday , but they do not . it be not because they really , really like be in the office and they can not stand stroll in the park or have a lazy brunch . we know that , because when you ask people about their ultimate favorite day of the week , surprise , surprise , saturday come in at first , then friday , then sunday . people prefer friday because friday bring with it the anticipation of the weekend ahead , all the plan that you have . on sunday , the only thing you can look forward to be the work week .     so optimist be people who expect more kiss in their future , more stroll in the park . and that anticipation enhance their wellbeing . in fact , without the optimism bias , we would all be slightly depressed . people with mild depression , they do not have a bias when they look into the future . they be actually more realistic than healthy individual . but individual with severe depression , they have a pessimistic bias . so they tend to expect the future to be bad than it end up be .     so optimism change subjective reality . the way we expect the world to be change the way we see it . but it also change objective reality . it act as a self - fulfil prophecy . and that be the third reason why lower your expectation will not make you happy . control experiment have show that optimism be not only relate to success , it lead to success . optimism lead to success in academia and sport and politic . and maybe the most surprising benefit of optimism be health . if we expect the future to be bright , stress and anxiety be reduce .     so all in all , optimism have lot of benefit . but the question that be really confusing to I be , how do we maintain optimism in the face of reality ? as an neuroscientist , this be especially confusing , because accord to all the theory out there , when your expectation be not meet , you should alter they . but this be not what we find . we ask people to come into our lab in order to try and figure out what be go on . "     what we want to know be whether people will take the information that we give they to change their belief . and indeed they do — but mostly when the information we give they be well than what they expect . so for example , if someone say , " my likelihood of suffer from cancer be about 50 percent , " and we say , " hey , good news . the average likelihood be only 30 percent , " the next time around they would say , " well maybe my likelihood be about 35 percent . "     ( laughter )     so it be not that they do not learn at all — they do — but much , much less than when we give they positive information about the future . and it be not that they do not remember the number that we give they ; everyone remember that the average likelihood of cancer be about 30 percent and the average likelihood of divorce be about 40 percent . but they do not think that those number be relate to they .     what this mean be that warning sign such as these may only have limit impact . yes , smoking kill , but mostly it kill the other guy .     what I want to know be what be go on inside the human brain that prevent we from take these warning sign personally . but at the same time , when we hear that the housing market be hopeful , we think , " oh , my house be definitely go to double in price .    on my desk in my office , I keep a small clay pot that I make in college . it be raku , which be a kind of pottery that begin in japan century ago as a way of make bowl for the japanese tea ceremony . this one be more than 400 year old . each one be pinch or carve out of a ball of clay , and it be the imperfection that people cherish .     everyday pot like this cup take eight to 10 hour to fire .
