   the kraken , a beast so terrify it be say to devour man and ship and whale , and so enormous it could be mistake for an island . in assess the merit of such tale , it be probably wise to keep in mind that old sailor 's see that the only difference between a fairytale and a sea story be a fairytale begin , " once upon a time , " and a sea story begin , " this be not no shit . " ( laughter )     every fish that get away grow with every telling of the tale . nevertheless , there be giant in the ocean , and we now have video proof , as those of you that see the discovery channel documentary be no doubt aware .     I be one of the three scientist on this expedition that take place last summer off japan . I be the short one . the other two be dr . tsunemi kubodera and dr . steve o'shea .     I owe my participation in this now - historic event to ted . in 2010 , there be a ted event call mission blue hold aboard the lindblad explorer in the galapagos as part of the fulfillment of sylvia earle 's ted wish . I speak about a new way of explore the ocean , one that focus on attract animal instead of scare they away . mike degruy be also invite , and he speak with great passion about his love of the ocean , and he also talk to I about apply my approach to something he be be involve with for a very long time , which be the hunt for the giant squid . it be mike that get I invite to the squid summit , a gathering of squid expert at the discovery channel that summer during shark week . ( laughter )     I give a talk on unobtrusive view and optical luring of deep sea squid in which I emphasize the importance of use quiet , unobtrusive platform for exploration . this come out of hundred of dive I have make , fart around in the dark use these platform , and my impression that I see more animal work from the submersible than I do with either of the remote - operate vehicle . but that could just be because the submersible have a wide field of view . but I also feel like I see more animal work with the tiburon than the ventana , two vehicle with the same field of view but different propulsion system .     so my suspicion be that it might have something to do with the amount of noise they make . so I set up a hydrophone on the bottom of the ocean , and I have each of these fly by at the same speed and distance and record the sound they make . the johnson sea - link — ( whirring noise ) — which you can probably just barely hear here , use electric thruster — very , very quiet . the tiburon also use electric powered thruster . it be also pretty quiet , but a bit noisier . ( loud whirring noise ) but most deep - diving rovs these day use hydraulics and they sound like the ventana . ( loud beeping noise ) I think that be get to be scare a lot of animal away .     so for the deep sea squid hunt , I propose use an optical lure attach to a camera platform with no thruster , no motor , just a battery - power camera , and the only illumination come from red light that be invisible to most deep - sea animal that be adapt to see primarily blue . that be visible to our eye , but it be the equivalent of infrared in the deep sea . so this camera platform , which we call the medusa , could just be throw off the back of the ship , attach to a float at the surface with over 2,000 foot of line , it would just float around passively carry by the current , and the only light visible to the animal in the deep would be the blue light of the optical lure , which we call the electronic jellyfish , or e - jelly , because it be design to imitate the bioluminescent display of the common deep sea jellyfish atolla .     now , this pinwheel of light that the atolla produce be know as a bioluminescent burglar alarm and be a form of defense . the reason that the electronic jellyfish work as a lure be not because giant squid eat jellyfish , but it be because this jellyfish only resort to produce this light when it be be chew on by a predator and its only hope for escape may be to attract the attention of a large predator that will attack its attacker and thereby afford it an opportunity for escape . it be a scream for help , a last - ditch attempt for escape , and a common form of defense in the deep sea .     the approach work . whereas all previous expedition have fail to garner a single video glimpse of the giant , we manage six , and the first trigger wild excitement .     edith widder ( on video ): oh my god . oh my god !    when I be little , I think my country be the good on the planet . and I grow up singe a song call " nothing to envy . " and I be very proud . in school , we spend a lot of time study the history of kim il - sung , but we never learn much about the outside world , except that america , south korea , japan be the enemy . although I often wonder about the outside world , I think I would spend my entire life in north korea , until everything suddenly change .     when I be seven year old , I see my first public execution . but I think my life in north korea be normal . my family be not poor , and myself , I have never experience hunger .     but one day , in 1995 , my mom bring home a letter from a coworker 's sister . it read , " when you read this , our five family member will not exist in this world , because we have not eat for the past three week . we be lie on the floor together , and our body be so weak , we be wait to die . "     I be so shocked . this be the first time I hear that people in my country be suffer . soon after , when I be walk past a train station , I see something terrible that to this day I can not erase from my memory . a lifeless woman be lie on the ground , while an emaciated child in her arm just stare helplessly at his mother 's face . but nobody help they , because they be so focused on take care of themselves and their family .     a huge famine hit north korea in the mid-1990 . ultimately , more than a million north korean die during the famine , and many only survive by eat grass , bug and tree bark . power outage also become more and more frequent , so everything around I be completely dark at night , except for the sea of light in china , just across the river from my home . I always wonder why they have light , but we do not . this be a satellite picture show north korea at night , compare to neighbor .     this be the amnok river , which serve as a part of the border between north korea and china . as you can see , the river can be very narrow at certain point , allow north koreans to secretly cross . but many die . sometimes , I see dead body float down the river . I can not reveal many detail about how I leave north korea , but I only can say that during the ugly year of the famine , I be send to china to live with distant relative . but I only think that I would be separate from my family for a short time . I could have never imagine that it would take 14 year to live together .     in china , it be hard live as a young girl without my family . I have no idea what life be go to be like as a north korean refugee . but I soon learn it be not only extremely difficult , it be also very dangerous , since north korean refugee be consider in china as illegal migrant . so I be live in constant fear that my identity could be reveal , and I would be repatriate to a horrible fate , back in north korea .     one day , my bad nightmare come true , when I be catch by the chinese police , and bring to the police station for interrogation . someone have accuse I of be north korean , so they test my chinese language ability , and ask I ton of question . I be so scared . I think my heart be go to explode . if anything seem unnatural , I could be imprison and repatriate . I think my life be over . but I manage to control all the emotion inside I , and answer the question . after they finish question I , one official say to another , " this be a false report . she be not north korean . " and they let I go . it be a miracle .     some north koreans in china seek asylum in foreign embassy . but many can be catch by the chinese police , and repatriate . these girl be so lucky . even though they be catch , they be eventually release , after heavy international pressure . these north koreans be not so lucky . every year , countless north koreans be catch in china and repatriate to north korea , where they can be torture , imprison , or publicly execute .     even though I be really fortunate to get out , many other north koreans have not be so lucky . it be tragic that north koreans have to hide their identity and struggle so hard just to survive . even after learn a new language and get a job , their whole world can be turn upside down in an instant . that be why , after 10 year of hide my identity , I decide to risk go to south korea . and I start a new life yet again .     settle down in south korea be a lot more challenging than I have expect . english be so important in south korea , so I have to start learn my third language . also , I realize there be a wide gap between north and south . we be all korean , but inside , we have become very different , due to 67 year of division . I even go through an identity crisis . be I south korean or north korean ? where be I from ? who be I ? suddenly , there be no country I could proudly call my own .     even though adjust to life in south korea be not easy , I make a plan — I start study for the university entrance exam .     just as I be start to get use to my new life , I receive a shocking phone call . the north korean authority intercept some money that I send to my family , and , as a punishment , my family be go to be forcibly remove to a desolate location in the countryside . they have to get out quickly . so I start plan how to help they escape .     north koreans have to travel incredible distance on the path to freedom . it be almost impossible to cross the border between north korea and south korea . so , ironically , I take a flight back to china and head toward the north korean border . since my family could not speak chinese , I have to guide they somehow through more than 2,000 mile in china , and then into southeast asia . the journey by bus take one week , and we be almost catch several time . one time , our bus be stop and board by a chinese police officer . he take everyone 's i.d . card , and he start ask they question . since my family could not understand chinese , I think my family be go to be arrest . as the chinese officer approach my family , I impulsively stand up , and I tell he that these be deaf and dumb people that I be chaperone . he look at I suspiciously , but luckily , he believe I .     we make it all the way to the border of laos . but I have to spend almost all my money to bribe the border guard in laos . but even after we get past the border , my family be arrest and jail for illegal border crossing . after I pay the fine and bribe , my family be release in one month . but soon after , my family be arrest and jail again , in the capital of laos .     this be one of the low point in my life . I do everything to get my family to freedom , and we come so close , but my family be throw in jail , just a short distance from the south korean embassy . I go back and forth between the immigration office and the police station , desperately try to get my family out . but I do not have enough money to pay a bribe or fine anymore . I lose all hope .     at that moment , I hear one man 's voice ask I , " what be wrong ? " I be so surprised that a total stranger care enough to ask . in my broken english , and with a dictionary , I explain the situation , and without hesitate , the man go to the atm , and he pay the rest of the money for my family , and two other north koreans to get out of jail .    well , now we be go to the bahama to meet a remarkable group of dolphin that I 've be work with in the wild for the last 28 year .     now I be interested in dolphin because of their large brain and what they might be do with all that brainpower in the wild . and we know they use some of that brainpower for just live complicated life , but what do we really know about dolphin intelligence ?     well , we know a few thing . we know that their brain - to - body ratio , which be a physical measure of intelligence , be second only to human . cognitively , they can understand artificially - create language . and they pass self - awareness test in mirror . and in some part of the world , they use tool , like sponge to hunt fish . but there be one big question leave : do they have a language , and if so , what be they talk about ?     so decade ago , not year ago , I set out to find a place in the world where I could observe dolphin underwater to try to crack the code of their communication system . now in most part of the world , the water 's pretty murky , so it be very hard to observe animal underwater , but I find a community of dolphin that live in these beautiful , clear , shallow sandbank of the bahama which be just east of florida . and they spend their daytime resting and socialize in the safety of the shallow , but at night , they go off the edge and hunt in deep water .     now , it be not a bad place to be a researcher , either . so we go out for about five month every summer in a 20 - meter catamaran , and we live , sleep and work at sea for week at a time . my main tool be an underwater video with a hydrophone , which be an underwater microphone , and this be so I can correlate sound and behavior . and most of our work 's pretty non - invasive . we try to follow dolphin etiquette while we be in the water , since we be actually observe they physically in the water . now , atlantic spot dolphin be a really nice specie to work with for a couple of reason . they be bear without spot , and they get spot with age , and they go through pretty distinct developmental phase , so that be fun to track their behavior . and by about the age of 15 , they be fully spot black and white .     now the mother you see here be mugsy . she be 35 year old in this shot , but dolphin can actually live into their early 50 . and like all the dolphin in our community , we photograph mugsy and track her little spot and nick in her dorsal fin , and also the unique spot pattern as she mature over time .     now , young dolphin learn a lot as they be grow up , and they use their teenage year to practice social skill , and at about the age of nine , the female become sexually mature , so they can get pregnant , and the male mature quite a bit later , at around 15 year of age . and dolphin be very promiscuous , and so we have to determine who the father be , so we do paternity test by collect fecal material out of the water and extract dna . so what that mean be , after 28 year , we be track three generation , include grandmother and grandfather . now , dolphin be natural acoustician . they make sound 10 time as high and hear sound 10 time as high as we do . but they have other communication signal they use . they have good vision , so they use body posture to communicate . they have taste , not smell . and they have touch . and sound can actually be feel in the water , because the acoustic impedance of tissue and water 's about the same . so dolphin can buzz and tickle each other at a distance .     now , we do know some thing about how sound be use with certain behavior . now , the signature whistle be a whistle that be specific to an individual dolphin , and it be like a name . ( dolphin whistle noise ) and this be the well - study sound , because it be easy to measure , really , and you would find this whistle when mother and calf be reunite , for example .     another well studied sound be echolocation click . this be the dolphin 's sonar . ( dolphin echolocation noise ) and they use these click to hunt and feed . but they can also tightly pack these click together into buzz and use they socially . for example , male will stimulate a female during a courtship chase . you know , I 've be buzz in the water . ( laughter ) do not tell anyone . it be a secret . and you can really feel the sound . that be my point with that . ( dolphin noises ) and they use these burst - pulse sound as well as their head - to - head behavior when they be fight . and these be very unstudied sound because they be hard to measure .     now this be some video of a typical dolphin fight . ( dolphin noises ) so you be go to see two group , and you be go to see the head - to - head posturing , some open mouth , lot of squawking . there be a bubble . and basically , one of these group will kind of back off and everything will resolve fine , and it do not really escalate into violence too much .     now , in the bahama , we also have resident bottlenose that interact socially with the spot dolphin . for example , they babysit each other 's calf . the male have dominance display that they use when they be chase each other 's female . and the two specie actually form temporary alliance when they be chase shark away . and one of the mechanism they use to communicate their coordination be synchrony . they synchronize their sound and their body posture to look big and sound strong . pulse sound be a bit of a mystery .     now , these be three spectragram . two be human word , and one be a dolphin vocalize . so just take a guess in your mind which one be the dolphin . now , it turn out burst -    everything be interconnect . as a shinnecock indian , I be raise to know this . we be a small fishing tribe situate on the southeastern tip of long island near the town of southampton in new york .     when I be a little girl , my grandfather take I to sit outside in the sun on a hot summer day . there be no cloud in the sky . and after a while I begin to perspire . and he point up to the sky , and he say , " look , do you see that ? that be part of you up there . that be your water that help to make the cloud that become the rain that feed the plant that feed the animal . miranda wang : we be here to talk about accident . how do you feel about accident ? when we think about accident , we usually consider they to be harmful , unfortunate or even dangerous , and they certainly can be . but be they always that bad ? the discovery that have lead to penicillin , for example , be one of the most fortunate accident of all time . without biologist alexander fleming 's moldy accident , cause by a neglected workstation , we would not be able to fight off so many bacterial infection . jeanny yao : miranda and I be here today because we would like to share how our accident have lead to discovery . in 2011 , we visit the vancouver waste transfer station and see an enormous pit of plastic waste . we realize that when plastic get to the dump , it be difficult to sort they because they have similar density , and when they be mix with organic matter and construction debris , it be truly impossible to pick they out and environmentally eliminate they . mw : however , plastic be useful because they be durable , flexible , and can be easily mold into so many useful shape . the downside of this convenience be that there be a high cost to this . plastic cause serious problem , such as the destruction of ecosystem , the pollution of natural resource , and the reduction of available land space . this picture you see here be the great pacific gyre . when you think about plastic pollution and the marine environment , we think about the great pacific gyre , which be suppose to be a float island of plastic waste . but that be no long an accurate depiction of plastic pollution in the marine environment . right now , the ocean be actually a soup of plastic debris , and there be nowhere you can go in the ocean where you would not be able to find plastic particle . jy : in a plastic - dependent society , cut down production be a good goal , but it be not enough . and what about the waste that be already be produce ? plastic take hundred to thousand of year to biodegrade . so we think , you know what ? instead of wait for that garbage to sit there and pile up , let us find a way to break they down with bacteria . sound cool , right ? audience : yeah . jy : thank you . but we have a problem . you see , plastic have very complex structure and be difficult to biodegrade . anyhow , we be curious and hopeful and still want to give it a go . mw : with this idea in mind , jeanny and I read through some hundred of scientific article on the internet , and we draft a research proposal in the beginning of our grade 12 year . we aim to find bacteria from our local fraser river that can degrade a harmful plasticizer call phthalate . phthalate be additive use in everyday plastic product to increase their flexibility , durability and transparency . although they be part of the plastic , they be not covalently bond to the plastic backbone . as a result , they easily escape into our environment . not only do phthalate pollute our environment , but they also pollute our body . to make the matter bad , phthalate be find in product to which we have a high exposure , such as baby ' toy , beverage container , cosmetic , and even food wrap . phthalate be horrible because they be so easily take into our body . they can be absorb by skin contact , ingest , and inhale . jy : every year , at least 470 million pound of phthalate contaminate our air , water and soil . the environmental protection agency even classify this group as a top - priority pollutant because it be be show to cause cancer and birth defect by act as a hormone disruptor . we read that each year , the vancouver municipal government monitor phthalate concentration level in river to assess their safety . so we figure , if there be place along our fraser river that be contaminate with phthalate , and if there be bacteria that be able to live in these area , then perhaps , perhaps these bacteria could have evolve to break down phthalate . mw : so we present this good idea to dr . lindsay eltis at the university of british columbia , and surprisingly , he actually take we into his lab and ask his graduate student adam and james to help we . little do we know at that time that a trip to the dump and some research on the internet and pluck up the courage to act upon inspiration would take we on a life - change journey of accident and discovery . jy : the first step in our project be to collect soil sample from three different site along the fraser river . out of thousand of bacteria , we want to find one that could break down phthalate , so we enrich our culture with phthalate as the only carbon source . this imply that , if anything grow in our culture , then they must be able to live off of phthalate . everything go well from there , and we become amazing scientist . ( laughter ) mw : um ... uh , jeanny . jy : I be just joke . mw : okay . well , it be partially my fault . you see , I accidentally crack the flask that have contain our third enrichment culture , and as a result , we have to wipe down the incubator room with bleach and ethanol twice . and this be only one of the example of the many accident that happen during our experimentation . but this mistake turn out to be rather serendipitous . we notice that the unharmed culture come from place of opposite contamination level , so this mistake actually lead we to think that perhaps we can compare the different degradative potential of bacteria from site of opposite contamination level . jy : now that we grow the bacteria , we want to isolate strain by streak onto mediate plate , because we think that would be less accident - prone , but we be wrong again . we poke hole in our agar while streak and contaminate some sample and funghi . as a result , we have to streak and restreak several time . then we monitor phthalate utilization and bacterial growth , and find that they share an inverse correlation , so as bacterial population increase , phthalate concentration decrease . this mean that our bacteria be actually live off of phthalate . mw : so now that we find bacteria that could break down phthalate , we wonder what these bacteria be . so jeanny and I take three of our most efficient strain and then perform gene amplification sequence on they and match our datum with an online comprehensive database . we be happy to see that , although our three strain have be previously identify bacteria , two of they be not previously associate with phthalate degradation , so this be actually a novel discovery . jy : to well understand how this biodegradation work , we want to verify the catabolic pathway of our three strain . to do this , we extract enzyme from our bacteria and react with an intermediate of phthalic acid . mw : we monitor this experiment with spectrophotometry and obtain this beautiful graph . this graph show that our bacteria really do have a genetic pathway to biodegrade phthalate . our bacteria can transform phthalate , which be a harmful toxin , into end product such as carbon dioxide , water and alcohol . I know some of you in the crowd be think , well , carbon dioxide be horrible , it be a greenhouse gas . but if our bacteria do not evolve to break down phthalate , they would have use some other kind of carbon source , and aerobic respiration would have lead it to have end product such as carbon dioxide anyway . we be also interested to see that , although we 've obtain great diversity of bacteria biodegrader from the bird habitat site , we obtain the most efficient degrader from the landfill site . so this fully show that nature evolve through natural selection . jy : so miranda and I share this research at the sanofi biogeneius challenge competition and be recognize with the great commercialization potential . although we be not the first one to find bacteria that can break down phthalate , we be the first one to look into our local river and find a possible solution to a local problem . we have not only show that bacteria can be the solution to plastic pollution , but also that be open to uncertain outcome and take risk create opportunity for unexpected discovery . throughout this journey , we have also discover our passion for science , and be currently continue research on other fossil fuel chemical in university . we hope that in the near future , we 'll be able to create model organism that can break down not only phthalate but a wide variety of different contaminant . we can apply this to wastewater treatment plant to clean up our river and other natural resource . and perhaps one day we 'll be able to tackle the problem of solid plastic waste . mw : I think our journey have truly transform our view of microorganism , and jeanny and I have show that even mistake can lead to discovery . einstein once say , " you can not solve problem by use the same kind of thinking you use when you create they . " if we be make plastic synthetically , then we think the solution would be to break they down biochemically . thank you . jy : thank you . ( applause )

   the day I leave home for the first time to go to university be a bright day brim with hope and optimism .    I feel so fortunate that my first job be work at the museum of modern art on a retrospective of painter elizabeth murray . I learn so much from she . after the curator robert storr select all the painting from her lifetime body of work , I love look at the painting from the 1970 . there be some motif and element that would come up again later in her life . I remember ask she what she think of those early work . if you do not know they be her , you might not have be able to guess . she tell I that a few do not quite meet her own mark for what she want they to be . one of the work , in fact , so do not meet her mark , she have set it out in the trash in her studio , and her neighbor have take it because she see its value .     in that moment , my view of success and creativity change . I realize that success be a moment , but what we be always celebrate be creativity and mastery . but this be the thing : what get we to convert success into mastery ? this be a question I 've long ask myself . I think it come when we start to value the gift of a near win .     I start to understand this when I go on one cold may day to watch a set of varsity archer , all woman as fate would have it , at the northern tip of manhattan at columbia 's baker athletics complex . I want to see what be call archer 's paradox , the idea that in order to actually hit your target , you have to aim at something slightly skew from it . I stand and watch as the coach drive up these woman in this gray van , and they exit with this kind of relaxed focus . one hold a half - eat ice cream cone in one hand and arrow in the left with yellow fletching . and they pass I and smile , but they size I up as they make their way to the turf , and speak to each other not with word but with number , degree , I think , position for how they might plan to hit their target . I stand behind one archer as her coach stand in between we to maybe assess who might need support , and watch she , and I do not understand how even one be go to hit the ten ring . the ten ring from the standard 75 - yard distance , it look as small as a matchstick tip hold out at arm 's length . and this be while hold 50 pound of draw weight on each shot . she first hit a seven , I remember , and then a nine , and then two ten , and then the next arrow do not even hit the target . and I see that give she more tenacity , and she go after it again and again . for three hour this go on . at the end of the practice , one of the archer be so tax that she lie out on the ground just star - fish , her head look up at the sky , try to find what t.s . eliot might call that still point of the turn world .     it be so rare in american culture , there be so little that be vocational about it anymore , to look at what doggedness look like with this level of exactitude , what it mean to align your body posture for three hour in order to hit a target , pursue a kind of excellence in obscurity . but I stay because I realize I be witness what be so rare to glimpse , that difference between success and mastery .     so success be hit that ten ring , but mastery be know that it mean nothing if you can not do it again and again . mastery be not just the same as excellence , though . it be not the same as success , which I see as an event , a moment in time , and a label that the world confer upon you . mastery be not a commitment to a goal but to a constant pursuit . what get we to do this , what get we to forward thrust more be to value the near win . how many time have we designate something a classic , a masterpiece even , while its creator consider it hopelessly unfinished , riddle with difficulty and flaw , in other word , a near win ? elizabeth murray surprise I with her admission about her early painting . painter paul cézanne so often think his work be incomplete that he would deliberately leave they aside with the intention of pick they back up again , but at the end of his life , the result be that he have only sign 10 percent of his painting . his favorite novel be " the [ unknown ] masterpiece " by honoré de balzac , and he feel the protagonist be the painter himself . franz kafka see incompletion when other would find only work to praise , so much so that he want all of his diary , manuscript , letter and even sketch burn upon his death . his friend refuse to honor the request , and because of that , we now have all the work we now do by kafka : " america , " " the trial " and " the castle , " a work so incomplete it even stop mid - sentence .     the pursuit of mastery , in other word , be an ever - onward almost . " lord , grant that I desire more than I can accomplish , " michelangelo implore , as if to that old testament god on the sistine chapel , and he himself be that adam with his finger outstretche and not quite touching that god 's hand .     mastery be in the reach , not the arriving . it be in constantly want to close that gap between where you be and where you want to be . mastery be about sacrifice for your craft and not for the sake of craft your career . how many inventor and untold entrepreneur live out this phenomenon ? we see it even in the life of the indomitable arctic explorer ben saunder , who tell I that his triumph be not merely the result of a grand achievement , but of the propulsion of a lineage of near win .     we thrive when we stay at our own leading edge . it be a wisdom understand by duke ellington , who say that his favorite song out of his repertoire be always the next one , always the one he have yet to compose . part of the reason that the near win be inbuilt to mastery be because the great our proficiency , the more clearly we might see that we do not know all that we think we do . it be call the dun – kruger effect . the paris review get it out of james baldwin when they ask he , " what do you think increase with knowledge ? " and he say , " you learn how little you know . "     success motivate we , but a near win can propel we in an ongoing quest . one of the most vivid example of this come when we look at the difference between olympic silver medalist and bronze medalist after a competition . thomas gilovich and his team from cornell study this difference and find that the frustration silver medalist feel compare to bronze , who be typically a bit more happy to have just not receive fourth place and not medale at all , give silver medalist a focus on follow - up competition . we see it even in the gambling industry that once pick up on this phenomenon of the near win and create these scratch - off ticket that have a high than average rate of near win and so compel people to buy more ticket that they be call heart - stopper , and be set on a gambling industry set of abuse in britain in the 1970 . the reason the near win have a propulsion be because it change our view of the landscape and put our goal , which we tend to put at a distance , into more proximate vicinity to where we stand . if I ask you to envision what a great day look like next week , you might describe it in more general term . but if I ask you to describe a great day at ted tomorrow , you might describe it with granular , practical clarity . and this be what a near win do . it get we to focus on what , right now , we plan to do to address that mountain in our sight . it be jackie joyner - kersee , who in 1984 miss take the gold in the heptathlon by one third of a second , and her husband predict that would give she the tenacity she need in follow - up competition . in 1988 , she win the gold in the heptathlon and set a record of 7,291 point , a score that no athlete have come very close to since .     we thrive not when we 've do it all , but when we still have more to do . I stand here think and wonder about all the different way that we might even manufacture a near win in this room , how your life might play this out , because I think on some gut level we do know this . we know that we thrive when we stay at our own leading edge , and it be why the deliberate incomplete be inbuilt into creation myth . in navajo culture , some craftsman and woman would deliberately put an imperfection in textile and ceramic . it be what be call a spirit line , a deliberate flaw in the pattern to give the weaver or maker a way out , but also a reason to continue make work . master be not expert because they take a subject to its conceptual end . they be master because they realize that there be not one .     now it occur to I , as I think about this , why the archery coach tell I at the end of that practice , out of earshot of his archer , that he and his colleague never feel they can do enough for their team , never feel there be enough visualization technique and posture drill to help they overcome those constant near win . it do not sound like a complaint , exactly , but just a way to let I know , a kind of tender admission , to remind I that he know he be give himself over to a voracious , unfinished path that always require more .     we build out of the unfinished idea , even if that idea be our former self . this be the dynamic of mastery . come close to what you think you want can help you attain more than you ever dream you could . it be what I have to imagine elizabeth murray be think when I see she smile at those early painting one day in the gallery . even if we create utopias , I believe we would still have the incomplete . completion be a goal , but we hope it be never the end .     thank you .    " why ? " " why ? " be a question that parent ask I all the time . " why do my child develop autism ?    I study ant in the desert , in the tropical forest and in my kitchen , and in the hill around silicon valley where I live . I 've recently realize that ant be use interaction differently in different environment , and that get I think that we could learn from this about other system , like brain and datum network that we engineer , and even cancer .     so what all these system have in common be that there be no central control . an ant colony consist of sterile female worker — those be the ant you see walk around — and then one or more reproductive female who just lie the egg . they do not give any instruction . even though they be call queen , they do not tell anybody what to do . so in an ant colony , there be no one in charge , and all system like this without central control be regulate use very simple interaction . ant interact use smell . they smell with their antennae , and they interact with their antennae , so when one ant touch another with its antennae , it can tell , for example , if the other ant be a nestmate and what task that other ant have be do . so here you see a lot of ant move around and interact in a lab arena that be connect by tube to two other arena . so when one ant meet another , it do not matter which ant it meet , and they be actually not transmit any kind of complicated signal or message . all that matter to the ant be the rate at which it meet other ant . and all of these interaction , take together , produce a network . so this be the network of the ant that you just see move around in the arena , and it be this constantly shift network that produce the behavior of the colony , like whether all the ant be hide inside the nest , or how many be go out to forage . a brain actually work in the same way , but what be great about ant be that you can see the whole network as it happen .     there be more than 12,000 specie of ant , in every conceivable environment , and they be use interaction differently to meet different environmental challenge . so one important environmental challenge that every system have to deal with be operate cost , just what it take to run the system . and another environmental challenge be resource , find they and collect they . in the desert , operating cost be high because water be scarce , and the seed - eat ant that I study in the desert have to spend water to get water . so an ant outside forage , search for seed in the hot sun , just lose water into the air . but the colony get its water by metabolize the fat out of the seed that they eat . so in this environment , interaction be use to activate forage . an outgoing forager do not go out unless it get enough interaction with return forager , and what you see be the return forager go into the tunnel , into the nest , and meet outgoing forager on their way out . this make sense for the ant colony , because the more food there be out there , the more quickly the forager find it , the fast they come back , and the more forager they send out . the system work to stay stop , unless something positive happen .     so interaction function to activate forager . and we 've be study the evolution of this system . first of all , there be variation . it turn out that colony be different . on dry day , some colony forage less , so colony be different in how they manage this trade - off between spend water to search for seed and get water back in the form of seed . and we be try to understand why some colony forage less than other by think about ant as neuron , use model from neuroscience . so just as a neuron add up its stimulation from other neuron to decide whether to fire , an ant add up its stimulation from other ant to decide whether to forage . and what we be look for be whether there might be small difference among colony in how many interaction each ant need before it be willing to go out and forage , because a colony like that would forage less .     and this raise an analogous question about brain . we talk about the brain , but of course every brain be slightly different , and maybe there be some individual or some condition in which the electrical property of neuron be such that they require more stimulus to fire , and that would lead to difference in brain function .     so in order to ask evolutionary question , we need to know about reproductive success . this be a map of the study site where I have be track this population of harvester ant colony for 28 year , which be about as long as a colony live . each symbol be a colony , and the size of the symbol be how many offspring it have , because we be able to use genetic variation to match up parent and offspring colony , that be , to figure out which colony be found by a daughter queen produce by which parent colony . and this be amazing for I , after all these year , to find out , for example , that colony 154 , whom I 've know well for many year , be a great - grandmother . here be her daughter colony , here be her granddaughter colony , and these be her great - granddaughter colony . and by do this , I be able to learn that offspring colony resemble parent colony in their decision about which day be so hot that they do not forage , and the offspring of parent colony live so far from each other that the ant never meet , so the ant of the offspring colony can not be learn this from the parent colony . and so our next step be to look for the genetic variation underlie this resemblance .     so then I be able to ask , okay , who be do well ? over the time of the study , and especially in the past 10 year , there be be a very severe and deepening drought in the southwestern u.s . , and it turn out that the colony that conserve water , that stay in when it be really hot outside , and thus sacrifice get as much food as possible , be the one more likely to have offspring colony . so all this time , I think that colony 154 be a loser , because on really dry day , there would be just this trickle of foraging , while the other colony be out forage , get lot of food , but in fact , colony 154 be a huge success . she be a matriarch . she be one of the rare great - grandmother on the site . to my knowledge , this be the first time that we 've be able to track the ongoing evolution of collective behavior in a natural population of animal and find out what be actually work well .     now , the internet use an algorithm to regulate the flow of datum that be very similar to the one that the harvester ant be use to regulate the flow of forager . and guess what we call this analogy ? the anternet be come . ( applause ) so data do not leave the source computer unless it get a signal that there be enough bandwidth for it to travel on . in the early day of the internet , when operating cost be really high and it be really important not to lose any datum , then the system be set up for interaction to activate the flow of datum . it be interesting that the ant be use an algorithm that be so similar to the one that we recently invent , but this be only one of a handful of ant algorithm that we know about , and ant have have 130 million year to evolve a lot of good one , and I think it be very likely that some of the other 12,000 specie be go to have interesting algorithm for datum network that we have not even think of yet .     so what happen when operating cost be low ? operating cost be low in the tropic , because it be very humid , and it be easy for the ant to be outside walk around . but the ant be so abundant and diverse in the tropic that there be a lot of competition . whatever resource one specie be use , another species be likely to be use that at the same time . so in this environment , interaction be use in the opposite way . the system keep go unless something negative happen , and one specie that I study make circuit in the tree of forage ant go from the nest to a food source and back , just round and round , unless something negative happen , like an interaction with ant of another specie . so here be an example of ant security . in the middle , there be an ant plug the nest entrance with its head in response to interaction with another specie . those be the little one run around with their abdomen up in the air . but as soon as the threat be pass , the entrance be open again , and maybe there be situation in computer security where operating cost be low enough that we could just block access temporarily in response to an immediate threat , and then open it again , instead of try to build a permanent firewall or fortress .     so another environmental challenge that all system have to deal with be resource , find and collect they . and to do this , ant solve the problem of collective search , and this be a problem that be of great interest right now in robotic , because we 've understand that , rather than send a single , sophisticated , expensive robot out to explore another planet or to search a burn building , that instead , it may be more effective to get a group of cheap robot exchange only minimal information , and that be the way that ant do it . so the invasive argentine ant make expandable search network . they be good at deal with the main problem of collective search , which be the trade - off between search very thoroughly and cover a lot of ground . and what they do be , when there be many ant in a small space , then each one can search very thoroughly because there will be another ant nearby search over there , but when there be a few ant in a large space , then they need to stretch out their path to cover more ground . I think they use interaction to assess density , so when they be really crowd , they meet more often , and they search more thoroughly . different ant specie must use different algorithm , because they 've evolve to deal with different resource , and it could be really useful to know about this , and so we recently ask ant to solve the collective search problem in the extreme environment of microgravity in the international space station . when I first see this picture , I think , oh no , they 've mount the habitat vertically , but then I realize that , of course , it do not matter . so the idea here be that the ant be work so hard to hang on to the wall or the floor or whatever you call it that they be less likely to interact , and so the relationship between how crowded they be and how often they meet would be mess up . we be still analyze the datum . I do not have the result yet . but it would be interesting to know how other specie solve this problem in different environment on earth , and so we be set up a program to encourage kid around the world to try this experiment with different specie . it be very simple . it can be do with cheap material . and that way , we could make a global map of ant collective search algorithm . and I think it be pretty likely that the invasive specie , the one that come into our building , be go to be really good at this , because they be in your kitchen because they be really good at find food and water .     so the most familiar resource for ant be a picnic , and this be a clustered resource . when there be one piece of fruit , there be likely to be another piece of fruit nearby , and the ant that specialize on cluster resource use interaction for recruitment . so when one ant meet another , or when it meet a chemical deposit on the ground by another , then it change direction to follow in the direction of the interaction , and that be how you get the trail of ant share your picnic .     now this be a place where I think we might be able to learn something from ant about cancer . I mean , first , it be obvious that we could do a lot to prevent cancer by not allow people to spread around or sell the toxin that promote the evolution of cancer in our body , but I do not think the ant can help we much with this because ant never poison their own colony . but we might be able to learn something from ant about treat cancer . there be many different kind of cancer . each one originate in a particular part of the body , and then some kind of cancer will spread or metastasize to particular other tissue where they must be get resource that they need . so if you think from the perspective of early metastatic cancer cell as they be out search around for the resource that they need , if those resource be cluster , they be likely to use interaction for recruitment , and if we can figure out how cancer cell be recruit , then maybe we could set trap to catch they before they become establish .     so ant be use interaction in different way in a huge variety of environment , and we could learn from this about other system that operate without central control . use only simple interaction , ant colony have be perform amazing feat for more than 130 million year . we have a lot to learn from they .     thank you .    as a little girl , I always imagine I would one day run away . from the age of six on , I keep a pack bag with some clothe and can of food tuck away in the back of a closet . there be a deep restlessness in I , a primal fear that I would fall prey to a life of routine and boredom . and so , many of my early memory involve intricate daydream where I would walk across border , forage for berry , and meet all kind of strange people live unconventional life on the road .     year have pass , but many of the adventure I fantasize about as a child — travel and weave my way between world other than my own — have become reality through my work as a documentary photographer . but no other experience have feel as true to my childhood dream as live amongst and document the life of fellow wanderer across the united states . this be the nomadic dream , a different kind of american dream live by young hobo , traveler , hitchhiker , vagrant and tramp .     in most of our mind , the vagabond be a creature from the past . the word " hobo " conjure up an old black and white image of a weather old man cover in coal , leg dangle out of a boxcar , but these photograph be in color , and they portray a community swirl across the country , fiercely alive and creatively free , see side of america that no one else get to see .     like their predecessor , today 's nomad travel the steel and asphalt artery of the united states . by day , they hop freight train , stick out their thumb , and ride the highway with anyone from trucker to soccer mom . by night , they sleep beneath the star , huddle together with their pack of dog , cat and pet rat between their body .     some traveler take to the road by choice , renounce materialism , traditional job and university degree in exchange   for a glimmer of adventure . other come from the underbelly of society , never give a chance to mobilize upwards : foster care dropout , teenage runaway escape abuse and unforgiving home .     where other see story of privation and economic failure , traveler view their own existence through the prism of liberation and freedom . they would rather live off of the excess of what they view as a wasteful consumer society than slave away at an unrealistic chance at the traditional american dream . they take advantage of the fact that in the united states , up to 40 percent of all food end up in the garbage by scavenge for perfectly good produce in dumpster and trash can . they sacrifice material comfort in exchange for the space and the time to explore a creative interior , to dream ,    as a scientist , and also as a human being , I 've be try to make myself susceptible to wonder . I think jason webley last night call it " conspire to be part of the magic . " so it be fortunate that my career as a biologist let I dive deeply into the life of some truly wondrous creature that share our planet : firefly .     now , for many of you , I know that firefly might conjure up some really great memory : childhood , summertime , even other ted talk . maybe something like this .     my seduction into the world of firefly begin when I be back in graduate school . one evening , I be sit out in my backyard in north carolina , and suddenly , these silent spark rise up all around I , and I begin to wonder : how do these creature make light , and what be with all this flash ? be they talk to one another ? and what happen after the light go out ? I 've be lucky enough to answer some of these question as I 've explore this nocturnal world .     now if you 've ever see or even hear about firefly , then you 'll know how magically they can transform our everyday landscape into something ethereal and otherworldly , and this happen around the globe , like this hillside in the smoky mountain that I see transform into a living cascade of light by the eerie glow of these blue ghost firefly , or a roadside river that I visit in japan as it be give birth to the slow , float flash of these genji firefly , or in malaysia , the mangrove tree that I watch blossom nightly not with flower but with the light of a thousand —   ( bleep ! bleep ! ) — firefly , all blink together in stunning synchrony . these luminous landscape still fill I with wonder , and they keep I connected to the magic of the natural world .     and I find it amazing that they be create by these tiny insect . in person , firefly be charming . they be charismatic . they 've be celebrate in art and in poetry for century . as I 've travel around the world , I 've meet many thoughtful people who have tell I that god put firefly on earth for human to enjoy . other creature can enjoy they too . I think these graceful insect be truly miraculous because they so beautifully illuminate the creative improvisation of evolution . they 've be shape by two powerful evolutionary force : natural selection , the struggle for survival , and sexual selection , the struggle for reproductive opportunity . as a firefly junkie , the past 20 year have be quite an exciting ride . together with my student at tuft university and other colleague , we 've make lot of new discovery about firefly : their courtship and sex life , their treachery and murder . so today I would like to share with you just a couple of tale that we 've bring back from our collective adventure into this hidden world .     firefly belong to a very beautiful and diverse group of insect , the beetle . worldwide , there be more than 2,000 firefly specie , and these have evolve remarkably diverse courtship signal , that is , different way to find and attract mate . around 150 million year ago , the very first firefly probably look like this . they fly during the daytime and they do not light up . instead , male use their fantastic antennae to sniff out perfume give off by their female . in other firefly , it be only the female who light up . they be attractively plump and wingless , so every night , they climb up onto perch and they glow brightly for hour to attract their fly but unlit male . in still other firefly , both sex use quick , bright flash to find their mate . here in north america , we have more than 100 different kind of firefly that have the remarkable ability to shine energy out from their body in the form of light . how do they do that ? it seem totally magical , but these bioluminescent signal arise from carefully orchestrate chemical reaction that happen inside the firefly lantern . the main star be an enzyme call luciferase , which in the course of evolution have figure out a way to wrap its tiny arm around an even small molecule call luciferin , in the process get it so excited that it actually give off light . incredible .     but how could these bright light have benefit some proto - firefly ? to answer this question , we need to flip back in the family album to some baby picture . firefly completely reinvent their body as they grow . they spend the vast majority of their lifetime , up to two year , in this larval form . their main goal here , like my teenager , be to eat and grow . and firefly light first originate in these juvenile . every single firefly larva can light up , even when their adult can not .     but what be the point to be so conspicuous ? well , we know that these juvenile make nasty - taste chemical that help they survive their extended childhood , so we think these light first evolve as a warning , a neon sign that say , " toxic ! stay away ! " to any would - be predator . it take many million of year before these bright light evolve into a smart communication tool that could be use not just to ward off potential predator but to bring in potential mate . drive now by sexual selection , some adult firefly like this proud male evolve a shiny new glow - in - the - dark lantern that would let they take courtship to a whole new level . these adult only live a few week , and now they be single - mindedly focus on sex , that is , on propel their gene into the next firefly generation . so we can follow this male out into the field as he join hundred of other male who be all show off their new courtship signal . it be amazing to think that the luminous display we admire here and in fact everywhere around the world be actually the silent love song of male firefly . they be fly and flash their heart out . I still find it very romantic .     but meanwhile , where be all the female ? well , they be lounge down below survey their option . they have plenty of male to choose from , and these female turn out to be very picky . when a female see a flash from an especially attractive male , she 'll aim her lantern in his direction , and give he a flash back . it be she " come hither " sign . so he fly close and he flash again . if she still like he , they 'll strike up a conversation . these creature speak their love in the language of light .     so what exactly do these female consider sexy ? we decide to conduct some firefly opinion poll to find out . when we test female use blink lead light , we discover they prefer male who give long - last flash . ( laughter ) ( applause ) I know you be wonder , what give these male their sex appeal ? now we get to see what happen when the light go out .     the first thing we discover be that once a male and female hook up like this , they stay together all night long , and when we look inside to see what might be happen , we discover a surprising new twist to firefly sex . while they be mate , the male be busy give the female not just his sperm but also a nutrient - fill package call a nuptial gift . we can zoom in to look more closely inside this mating pair . we can actually see the gift — it be show here in red — as it be be pass from the male to the female . what make this gift so valuable be that it be pack with protein that the female will use to provision her egg . so female be keep their eye on this prize as they size up potential mate . we discover that female use male flash signal to try to predict which male have the big gift to offer , because this bling help the female lay more egg and ultimately launch more of her own offspring into the next generation .     so it be not all sweetness and light . firefly romance be risky . for the most part , these adult firefly do not get eat because like their juvenile they can manufacture toxin that be repellent to bird and other insectivore , but somewhere along the line , one particular group of firefly somehow lose the metabolic machinery need to make their own protective toxin . this evolutionary flaw , which be discover by my colleague tom eisner , have drive these firefly to take their bright light out into the night with treacherous intent . dub " femme fatale " by jim lloyd , another colleague , these female have figure out how to target the male of other firefly specie . so the hunt begin with the predator — she be show here in the low left — where she be sit quietly and eavesdrop on the courtship conversation of her intended prey , and here be how it might go . first the prey male flash , " do you love I ?    what do you think of when I say the word " design " ? you probably think of thing like this , finely craft object that you can hold in your hand , or maybe logo and poster and map that visually explain thing , classic icon of timeless design . but I be not here to talk about that kind of design . I want to talk about the kind that you probably use every day and may not give much thought to , design that change all the time and that live inside your pocket . I be talk about the design of digital experience and specifically the design of system that be so big that their scale can be hard to comprehend . consider the fact that google process over one billion search query every day , that every minute , over 100 hour of footage be upload to youtube . that be more in a single day than all three major u.s . network broadcast in the last five year combine . and facebook transmit the photo , message and story of over 1.23 billion people . that be almost half of the internet population , and a sixth of humanity .     these be some of the product that I 've help design over the course of my career , and their scale be so massive that they 've produce unprecedented design challenge . but what be really hard about design at scale be this : it be hard in part because it require a combination of two thing , audacity and humility — audacity to believe that the thing that you be make be something that the entire world want and need , and humility to understand that as a designer , it be not about you or your portfolio , it be about the people that you be design for , and how your work just might help they live well life . now , unfortunately , there be no school that offer the course design for humanity 101 . I and the other designer who work on these kind of product have have to invent it as we go along , and we be teach ourselves the emerge good practice of design at scale , and today I would like share some of the thing that we 've learn over the year .     now , the first thing that you need to know about design at scale be that the little thing really matter . here be a really good example of how a very tiny design element can make a big impact . the team at facebook that manage the facebook " like " button decide that it need to be redesign . the button have kind of get out of sync with the evolution of our brand and it need to be modernize . now you might think , well , it be a tiny little button , it probably be a pretty straightforward , easy design assignment , but it be not . turn out , there be all kind of constraint for the design of this button . you have to work within specific height and width parameter . you have to be careful to make it work in a bunch of different language , and be careful about use fancy gradient or border because it have to degrade gracefully in old web browser . the truth be , design this tiny little button be a huge pain in the butt .     now , this be the new version of the button , and the designer who lead this project estimate that he spend over 280 hour redesign this button over the course of month . now , why would we spend so much time on something so small ? it be because when you be design at scale , there be no such thing as a small detail . this innocent little button be see on average 22 billion time a day and on over 7.5 million website . it be one of the single most view design element ever create . now that be a lot of pressure for a little button and the designer behind it , but with these kind of product , you need to get even the tiny thing right .     now , the next thing that you need to understand be how to design with datum . now , when you be work on product like this , you have incredible amount of information about how people be use your product that you can then use to influence your design decision , but it be not just as simple as follow the number . let I give you an example so that you can understand what I mean . facebook have have a tool for a long time that allow people to report photo that may be in violation of our community standard , thing like spam and abuse . and there be a ton of photo report , but as it turn out , only a small percentage be actually in violation of those community standard . most of they be just your typical party photo . now , to give you a specific hypothetical example , let us say my friend laura hypothetically upload a picture of I from a drunken night of karaoke . this be purely hypothetical , I can assure you . ( laughter ) now , incidentally , you know how some people be kind of worried that their boss or employee be go to discover embarrassing photo of they on facebook ? do you know how hard that be to avoid when you actually work at facebook ? so anyway , there be lot of these photo be erroneously report as spam and abuse , and one of the engineer on the team have a hunch . he really think there be something else go on and he be right , because when he look through a bunch of the case , he find that most of they be from people who be request the takedown of a photo of themselves . now this be a scenario that the team never even take into account before . so they add a new feature that allow people to message their friend to ask they to take the photo down . but it do not work . only 20 percent of people send the message to their friend . so the team go back at it . they consult with expert in conflict resolution . they even study the universal principle of polite language , which I do not even actually know exist until this research happen . and they find something really interesting . they have to go beyond just help people ask their friend to take the photo down . they have to help people express to their friend how the photo make they feel .     here be how the experience work today . so I find this hypothetical photo of myself , and it be not spam , it be not abuse , but I really wish it be not on the site . so I report it and I say , " I be in this photo and I do not like it , " and then we dig deeply . why do not you like this photo of yourself ? and I select " it be embarrassing . " and then I be encourage to message my friend , but here be the critical difference . I be provide specific suggested language that help I communicate to laura how the photo make I feel . now the team find that this relatively small change have a huge impact . before , only 20 percent of people be send the message , and now 60 percent be , and survey show that people on both side of the conversation feel well as a result . that same survey show that 90 percent of your friend want to know if they 've do something to upset you . now I do not know who the other 10 percent be , but maybe that be where our " unfriend " feature can come in handy .     so as you can see , these decision be highly nuanced . of course we use a lot of datum to inform our decision , but we also rely very heavily on iteration , research , testing , intuition , human empathy . it be both art and science . now , sometimes the designer who work on these product be call " data - drive , " which be a term that totally drive we bonker . the fact be , it would be irresponsible of we not to rigorously test our design when so many people be count on we to get it right , but datum analytic will never be a substitute for design intuition . datum can help you make a good design great , but it will never make a bad design good .     the next thing that you need to understand as a principle be that when you introduce change , you need to do it extraordinarily carefully . now I often have joke that I spend almost as much time design the introduction of change as I do the change itself , and I be sure that we can all relate to that when something that we use a lot change and then we have to adjust . the fact be , people can become very efficient at use bad design , and so even if the change be good for they in the long run , it be still incredibly frustrating when it happen , and this be particularly true with user - generate content platform , because people can rightfully claim a sense of ownership . it be , after all , their content .     now , year ago , when I be work at youtube , we be look for way to encourage more people to rate video , and it be interesting because when we look into the datum , we find that almost everyone be exclusively use the high five - star rating , a handful of people be use the low one - star , and virtually no one be use two , three or four star . so we decide to simplify into an up - down kind of vote binary model . it be go to be much easy for people to engage with . but people be very attached to the five - star rating system . video creator really love their rating . million and million of people be accustomed to the old design . so in order to help people prepare themselves for change and acclimate to the new design more quickly , we actually publish the data graph share with the community the rationale for what we be go to do , and it even engage the large industry in a conversation , which result in my favorite techcrunch headline of all time : " youtube come to a 5 - star realization : its rating be useless . "     now , it be impossible to completely avoid change aversion when you be make change to product that so many people use . even though we try to do all the right thing , we still receive our customary flood of video protest and angry email and even a package that have to be scan by security , but we have to remember people care intensely about this stuff , and it be because these product , this work , really , really matter to they .     now , we know that we have to be careful about pay attention to the detail , we have to be cognizant about how we use datum in our design process , and we have to introduce change very , very carefully . now , these thing be all really useful . they be good good practice for design at scale . but they do not mean anything if you do not understand something much more fundamental . you have to understand who you be design for .     now , when you set a goal to design for the entire human race , and you start to engage in that goal in earnest , at some point you run into the wall of the bubble that you be live in . now , in san francisco , we get a little miffed when we hit a dead cell zone because we can not use our phone to navigate to the new hipst coffee shop . but what if you have to drive four hour to charge your phone because you have no reliable source of electricity ? what if you have no access to public library ? what if your country have no free press ? what would these product start to mean to you ? this be what google , youtube and facebook look like to most of the world , and it be what they 'll look like to most of the next five billion people to come online . design for low - end cell phone be not glamorous design work , but if you want to design for the whole world , you have to design for where people be , and not where you be .     so how do we keep this big , big picture in mind ? we try to travel outside of our bubble to see , hear and understand the people we be design for . we use our product in non - english language to make sure that they work just as well . and we try to use one of these phone from time to time to keep in touch with their reality .     so what do it mean to design at a global scale ? it mean difficult and sometimes exasperate work to try to improve and evolve product . find the audacity and the humility to do right by they can be pretty exhausting , and the humility part , it be a little tough on the design ego . because these product be always change , everything that I 've design in my career be pretty much go , and everything that I will design will fade away . but here be what remain : the never - end thrill of be a part of something that be so big , you can hardly get your head around it , and the promise that it just might change the world .     thank you . mediate endocytosis . it be a process by which a molecule can get from the outside of the cell to the inside by getting capture in a bubble or a vesicle that then gets internalize by the cell . there be a problem with this drawing , though , and it be mainly in what it do not show . from lot of experiment , from lot of different scientist , we know a lot about what these molecule look like , how they move around in the cell , and that this be all take place in an incredibly dynamic environment .     so in collaboration with a clathrin expert tomas kirchhausen , we decide to create a new kind of model figure that show all of that . so we start outside of the cell . now we be look inside . clathrin be these three - I believe that animation can change biology . it can change the way that we communicate with one another , how we explore our datum and how we teach our student . but for that change to happen , we need more researcher create animation , and toward that end , I bring together a team of biologist , animator and programmer to create a new , free , open - source software — we call it molecular flipbook — that be create just for biologist just to create molecular animation . from our testing , we 've find that it only take 15 minute for a biologist who have never touch animation software before to create her first molecular animation of her own hypothesis . we be also build an online database where anyone can view , download and contribute their own animation . we be really excited to announce that the beta version of the molecular animation software toolkit will be available for download today . we be really excited to see what biologist will create with it and what new insight they be able to gain from finally be able to animate their own model figure .     thank you .    I would like to share with you today a project that have change how I approach and practice architecture : the fez river rehabilitation project .     my hometown of fez , morocco , boast one of the large walled medieval city in the world , call the medina , nestle in a river valley . the entire city be a unesco world heritage site . since the 1950 , as the population of the medina grow , basic urban infrastructure such as green open space and sewage quickly change and get highly stressed . one of the big casualty of the situation be the fez river , which bisect the medina in its middle and have be consider for many century as the city 's very soul . in fact , one can witness the presence of the river 's extensive water network all throughout the city , in place such as private and public fountain .     unfortunately , because of the pollution of the river , it have be cover little by little by concrete slab since 1952 . this process of erasure be couple with the destruction of many house along the river bank to be able to make machinery enter the narrow pedestrian network of the medina . those urban void quickly become illegal parking or trash yard . actually , the state of the river before enter the medina be pretty healthy . then pollution take its toll , mainly due to untreated sewage and chemical dumping from craft such as tan . at some point , I could not bear the desecration of the river , such an important part of my city , and I decide to take action , especially after I hear that the city receive a grant to divert sewage water and to treat it .     with clean water , suddenly the uncovering of the river become possible , and with luck and actually a lot of push , my partner takako tajima and I be commission by the city to work with a team of engineer to uncover the river . however , we be sneaky , and we propose more : to convert riverbank into pedestrian pathway , and then to connect these pathway back to the city fabric , and finally to convert the urban void along the riverbank into public space that be lack in the medina of fez . I will show you briefly now two of these public space .     the first one be the rcif plaza , which sit actually right on top of the river , which you can see here in dotted line . this plaza use to be a chaotic transportation hub that actually compromise the urban integrity of the medina , that have the large pedestrian network in the world . and right beyond the historic bridge that you can see here , right next to the plaza , you can see that the river look like a river of trash . instead , what we propose be to make the plaza entirely pedestrian , to cover it with recycled leather canopy , and to connect it to the bank of the river .     the second site of intervention be also an urban void along the river bank , and it use to be an illegal parking , and we propose to transform it into the first playground in the medina . the playground be construct use recycled tire and also be couple with a construct wetland that not only clean the water of the river but also retain it when flood occur .     as the project progress and receive several design award , new stakeholder intervene and change the project goal and design . the only way for we to be able to bring the main goal of the project ahead be for we to do something very unusual that usually architect do not do . it be for we to take our design ego and our sense of authorship and put it in the backseat and to focus mainly on be activist and on try to coalesce all of the agenda of stakeholder and focus on the main goal of the project : that be , to uncover the river , treat its water , and provide public space for all . we be actually very lucky , and many of those goal happen or be in the process of happen . like , you can see here in the rcif plaza . this be how it look like about six year ago . this be how it look like today . it be still under construction , but actually it be heavily use by the local population . and finally , this be how the rcif plaza will look like when the project be complete . this be the river , cover , use as a trash yard . then after many year of work , the river with clean water , uncover . and finally , you can see here the river when the project will be complete .     so for sure , the fez river rehabilitation will keep on change and adapt to the sociopolitical landscape of the city , but we strongly believe that by reimagine the role and the agency of the architect , we have set up the core idea of the project into motion ; that be , to transform the river from sewage to public space for all , thereby make sure that the city of fez will remain a live city for its inhabitant rather than a mummified heritage .     thank you very much .    today I want to tell you about a project be carry out by scientist all over the world to paint a neural portrait of the human mind . and the central idea of this work be that the human mind and brain be not a single , general - purpose processor , but a collection of highly specialized component , each solve a different specific problem , and yet collectively make up who we be as human being and thinker . to give you a feel for this idea ,     imagine the following scenario : you walk into your child 's day care center . as usual , there be a dozen kid there wait to get pick up , but this time , the child 's face look weirdly similar , and you can not figure out which child be yours . do you need new glass ?
