" you may ask . camera can take picture like this one by convert light into a two - dimensional array of number know as pixel , but these be just lifeless number . they do not carry meaning in themselves . just like to hear be not the same as to listen , to take picture be not the same as to see , and by see , we really mean understanding . in fact , it take mother nature 540 million year of hard work to do this task , and much of that effort go into develop the visual processing apparatus of our brain , not the eye themselves . so vision begin with the eye , but it truly take place in the brain .     so for 15 year now , start from my ph.d . at caltech and then lead stanford 's vision lab , I 've be work with my mentor , collaborator and student to teach computer to see . our research field be call computer vision and machine learning . it be part of the general field of artificial intelligence . so ultimately , we want to teach the machine to see just like we do : name object , identify people , infer 3d geometry of thing , understand relation , emotion , action and intention . you and I weave together entire story of people , place and thing the moment we lay our gaze on they .     the first step towards this goal be to teach a computer to see object , the building block of the visual world . in its simple term , imagine this teaching process as show the computer some training image of a particular object , let us say cat , and design a model that learn from these training image . how hard can this be ? after all , a cat be just a collection of shape and color , and this be what we do in the early day of object modeling . we would tell the computer algorithm in a mathematical language that a cat have a round face , a chubby body , two pointy ear , and a long tail , and that look all fine . but what about this cat ? ( laughter ) it be all curl up . now you have to add another shape and viewpoint to the object model . but what if cat be hide ? what about these silly cat ? now you get my point . even something as simple as a household pet can present an infinite number of variation to the object model , and that be just one object .     so about eight year ago , a very simple and profound observation change my thinking . no one tell a child how to see , especially in the early year . they learn this through real - world experience and example . if you consider a child 's eye as a pair of biological camera , they take one picture about every 200 millisecond , the average time an eye movement be make . so by age three , a child would have see hundred of million of picture of the real world . that be a lot of training example . so instead of focus solely on well and well algorithm , my insight be to give the algorithm the kind of training datum that a child be give through experience in both quantity and quality .     once we know this , we know we need to collect a data set that have far more image than we have ever have before , perhaps thousand of time more , and together with professor kai li at princeton university , we launch the imagenet project in 2007 . luckily , we do not have to mount a camera on our head and wait for many year . we go to the internet , the big treasure trove of picture that human have ever create . we download nearly a billion image and use crowdsource technology like the amazon mechanical turk platform to help we to label these image . at its peak , imagenet be one of the big employer of the amazon mechanical turk worker : together , almost 50,000 worker from 167 country around the world help we to clean , sort and label nearly a billion candidate image . that be how much effort it take to capture even a fraction of the imagery a child 's mind take in in the early developmental year .     in hindsight , this idea of use big datum to train computer algorithm may seem obvious now , but back in 2007 , it be not so obvious . we be fairly alone on this journey for quite a while . some very friendly colleague advise I to do something more useful for my tenure , and we be constantly struggle for research funding . once , I even joke to my graduate student that I would just reopen my dry cleaner 's shop to fund imagenet . after all word . in both quantity and quality , this be an unprecedented scale . as an example , in the case of cat , we have more than 62,000 cat of all kind of look and pose and across all specie of domestic and wild cat . we be thrill to have put together imagenet , and we want the whole research world to benefit from it , so in the ted fashion , we open up the entire datum set to the worldwide research community for free . ( applause )     now that we have the datum to nourish our computer brain , we be ready to come back to the algorithm themselves . as it turn out , the wealth of information provide by imagenet be a perfect match to a particular class of machine learning algorithm call convolutional neural network , pioneer by kunihiko fukushima , geoff hinton , and yann lecun back in the 1970 and ' 80 . just like the brain consist of billion of highly connect neuron , a basic operate unit in a neural network be a neuron - like node . it take input from other node and send output to other . moreover , these hundred of thousand or even million of node be organize in hierarchical layer , also similar to the brain . in a typical neural network we use to train our object recognition model , it have 24 million node , 140 million parameter , and 15 billion connection . that be an enormous model . power by the massive datum from imagenet and the modern cpus and gpus to train such a humongous model , the convolutional neural network blossom in a way that no one expect . it become the win architecture to generate exciting new result in object recognition . this be a computer tell we this picture contain a cat and where the cat be . of course there be more thing than cat , so here be a computer algorithm tell we the picture contain a boy and a teddy bear ; a dog , a person , and a small kite in the background ; or a picture of very busy thing like a man , a skateboard , railing , a lampost , and so on . sometimes , when the computer be not so confident about what it see , we have teach it to be smart enough to give we a safe answer instead of commit too much , just like we would do , but other time our computer algorithm be remarkable at tell we what exactly the object be , like the make , model , year of the car .     we apply this algorithm to million of google street view image across hundred of american city , and we have learn something really interesting : first , it confirm our common wisdom that car price correlate very well with household income . but surprisingly , car price also correlate well with crime rate in city , or voting pattern by zip code .     so wait a minute . be that it ? have the computer already match or even surpass human capability ? not so fast . so far , we have just teach the computer to see object . this be like a small child learn to utter a few noun . it be an incredible accomplishment , but it be only the first step . soon , another developmental milestone will be hit , and child begin to communicate in sentence . so instead of say this be a cat in the picture , you already hear the little girl tell we this be a cat lie on a bed .     so to teach a computer to see a picture and generate sentence , the marriage between big datum and machine learn algorithm have to take another step . now , the computer have to learn from both picture as well as natural language sentence generate by human . just like the brain integrate vision and language , we develop a model that connect part of visual thing like visual snippet with word and phrase in sentence .     about four month ago , we finally tie all this together and produce one of the first computer vision model that be capable of generate a human - like sentence when it see a picture for the first time . now , I be ready to show you what the computer say when it    on the path that american child   travel to adulthood , two institution oversee the journey . the first be the one we hear   a lot about : college . some of you may remember the excitement that you feel when you first set off for college . some of you may be in college right now and you be feel this excitement at this very moment .     college have some shortcoming . it be expensive ; it leave young people in debt . but all in all , it be a pretty good path . young people emerge from college with pride and with great friend and with a lot of knowledge   about the world . and perhaps most importantly , a well chance in the labor market than they have before they get there .     today I want to talk about the second institution oversee the journey from childhood to adulthood in the united states . and that institution be prison . young people on this journey be meet with probation officer instead of with teacher . they be go to court date instead of to class . their junior year abroad be instead a trip to a state correctional facility . and they be emerge from their 20 not with degree in business and english , but with criminal record .     this institution be also cost we a lot , about 40,000 dollar a year to send a young person to prison in new jersey . but here , taxpayer be foot the bill and what kid be get be a cold prison cell and a permanent mark against they when they come home and apply for work .     there be more and more kid on this journey to adulthood than ever before in the united states and that be because in the past 40 year , our incarceration rate   have grow by 700 percent . I have one slide for this talk . here it be . here be our incarceration rate , about 716 people per 100,000 in the population . here be the oecd country .     what be more , it be poor kid that we be send to prison , too many draw from african - american and latino community so that prison now stand firmly between the young people try to make it and the fulfillment of the american dream . the problem 's actually   a bit bad than this 'cause we be not just send   poor kid to prison , we be saddle poor kid with court fee , with probation and parole restriction , with low - level warrant , we be ask they to live   in halfway house and on house arrest , and we be ask they   to negotiate a police force that be enter poor community of color , not for the purpose   of promote public safety , but to make arrest count , to line city coffer .     this be the hidden underside to our historic experiment in punishment : young people worry that at any moment , they will be stop , search and seize . not just in the street ,   but in their home , at school and at work .     I get interested in this   other path to adulthood when I be myself a college student attend the university of pennsylvania in the early 2000s . penn sit within a historic   african - american neighborhood . so you 've get these two parallel journey go on simultaneously : the kid attend   this elite , private university , and the kid from   the adjacent neighborhood , some of whom be make it to college , and many of whom   be be ship to prison .     in my sophomore year , I start tutor a young woman who be in high school who live about 10 minute away from the university . soon , her cousin come home   from a juvenile detention center . he be 15 , a freshman in high school . I begin to get to know he   and his friend and family , and I ask he what he think   about I write about his life for my senior thesis in college . this senior thesis become a dissertation at princeton and now a book .     by the end of my sophomore year , I move into the neighborhood and I spend the next six year     try to understand what young people be face as they come of age . the first week I spend in this neighborhood , I see two boy , five and seven year old , play this game of chase , where the old boy run after the other boy . he play the cop . when the cop catch up to the young boy , he push he down , handcuff he with imaginary handcuff , take a quarter out of   the other child 's pocket , say , " I be seize that . " he ask the child if   he be carry any drug or if he have a warrant . many time , I see this game repeat , sometimes child would   simply give up run , and stick their body flat   against the ground with their hand above their head , or flat up against a wall . child would yell at each other , " I be go to lock you up , I be go to lock you up and you be never come home ! " once I see a six - year - old child pull another child 's pant down and try to do a cavity search .     in the first 18 month that I live in this neighborhood , I write down every time I see any contact between police and people that be my neighbor . so in the first 18 month , I watch the police stop   pedestrian or people in car , search people , run people 's name , chase people through the street , pull people in for questioning , or make an arrest every single day , with five exception . fifty - two time , I watch the police break down door , chase people through house or make an arrest of someone in their home . fourteen time in this first year and a half , I watch the police punch , choke , kick , stomp on or beat young man after they have catch they .     bit by bit , I get to know two brother , chuck and tim . chuck be 18 when we meet , a senior in high school . he be play on the basketball team and make c 's and b 's . his young brother , tim , be 10 . and tim love chuck ; he follow he around a lot , look to chuck to be a mentor . they live with their mom and grandfather in a two - story row home   with a front lawn and a back porch . their mom be struggle with addiction all while the boy be grow up . she never really be able   to hold down a job for very long . it be their grandfather 's pension that support the family , not really enough to pay for food and clothe and school supply for grow boy . the family be really struggle .     so when we meet , chuck be a senior in high school . he have just turn 18 . that winter , a kid in the schoolyard call chuck 's mom a crack whore . chuck push the kid 's face into the snow and the school cop charge he   with aggravate assault . the other kid be fine the next day , I think it be his pride that be injure more than anything .     but anyway , since chuck be 18 , this agg . assault case send he   to adult county jail on state road in northeast philadelphia , where he sit , unable to pay the bail — he could not afford it — while the trial date   drag on and on and on through almost his entire senior year . finally , near the end of this season , the judge on this assault case throw out most of the charge and chuck come home with only a few hundred dollar ' worth of court fee hang over his head . tim be pretty happy that day .     the next fall , chuck try   to re - state , let alone to california . but anyway , the cop down at the precinct charge chuck with   receive steal property . and then a juvenile judge ,   a few day later , charge tim , age 11 , with accessory to receive a steal property and then he be place on   three year of probation . with this probation sentence   hang over his head ,     chuck sit his little brother down and begin teach he how to run from the police . they would sit side by side   on their back porch look out into the shared alleyway and chuck would coach tim how to spot undercover car , how to negotiate a late - I want you to imagine for a second what chuck and tim 's life would be like if they be live in a neighborhood where kid be go to college , not prison . a neighborhood like the one   I get to grow up in . okay , you might say . but chuck and tim , kid like they , they be commit crime ! do not they deserve to be in prison ? do not they deserve to be   live in fear of arrest ? well , my answer would be no . they do not . and certainly not for the same thing   that other young people with more privilege be do with impunity . if chuck have go to my high school , that schoolyard fight   would have end there , as a schoolyard fight . it never would have become an aggravate assault case . not a single kid that I go to college with have a criminal record right now . not a single one . but can you imagine how many might have if the police have stop those kid and search their pocket for drug as they walk to class ? or have raid their frat party in the middle of the night ?     okay , you might say . but do not this high incarceration rate partly account for our   really low crime rate ? crime be down . that be a good thing . totally , that be a good thing . crime be down . it drop precipitously in the ' 90 and through the 2000s . but accord to a committee of academic convene by the national academy of science last year , the relationship between our historically high incarceration rate and our low crime rate be pretty shaky . it turn out that the crime rate go up and down irrespective of how many young people we send to prison .     we tend to think about justice in a pretty narrow way : good and bad , innocent and guilty . injustice be about be   wrongfully convict . so if you be convict   of something you do do , you should be punish for it . there be innocent and guilty people , there be victim and   there be perpetrator . maybe we could think a little bit more broadly than that .     right now , we be ask kid who live in the most disadvantaged neighborhood , who have the least amount of family resource , who be attend   the country 's bad school , who be face the tough time in the labor market , who be live in neighborhood where violence be an everyday problem , we be ask these kid to walk the thin possible line — to basically never do anything wrong .     why be we not provide support to young kid face these challenge ? why be we offer only handcuff , jail time and this fugitive existence ? can we imagine something well ?   can we imagine a criminal justice system that prioritize recovery , prevention , civic inclusion , rather than punishment ? ( applause ) a criminal justice system   that acknowledge the legacy of exclusion that poor people of color in the u.s . have face and that do not promote and perpetuate those exclusion . ( applause ) and finally , a criminal justice system that believe in black young people , rather than treat black young people   as the enemy to be round up . ( applause )     the good news be that we already be . a few year ago , michelle alexander write " the new jim crow , " which get americans to see   incarceration as a civil right issue of historic proportion in a way they have not see it before . president obama and attorney general   eric holder have come out very strongly on sentencing reform , on the need to address   racial disparity in incarceration . we be see state throw out stop and frisk as the civil right violation that it be . we be see city and state decriminalize possession of marijuana . new york , new jersey and california have be drop their   prison population , closing prison , while also see a big drop in crime . texas have get into the game now , also close prison ,   invest in education . this curious coalition be build   from the right and the left , make up of former prisoner and fiscal conservative , of civil right activist and libertarian , of young people take to the street to protest police violence against unarmed black teenager , and old , wealthy people — some of you be here in the audience — pump big money into   decarceration initiative in a deeply divide congress , the work of reform   our criminal justice system be just about the only thing that the right and the left be come together on .     I do not think I would see this political moment in my lifetime . I think many of the people who have be work tirelessly to write about the cause and consequence of our historically   high incarceration rate do not think we would see this moment in our lifetime . the question for we now be , how much can we make of it ? how much can we change ?     I want to end with a call to young people , the young people attend college and the young people struggle to stay out of prison or to make it through prison and return home . it may seem like these path to adulthood be world apart , but the young people participate in these two institution convey we to adulthood , they have one thing in common : both can be leader in the work of reform our criminal justice system . young people have always be leader in the fight for equal right , the fight for more people   to be grant dignity and a fighting chance at freedom . the mission for the generation   of young people come of age in this , a sea - change moment , potentially , be to end mass incarceration and   build a new criminal justice system , emphasis on the word justice .     thank .    I be a plant geneticist . "     well , we can , and it be not difficult , because we have the same goal . we want to help nourish the grow population without far destroy the environment . I believe this be the great challenge of our time .     now , genetic modification be not new ; virtually everything we eat have be genetically modify in some manner . let I give you a few example . on the left be an image of the ancient ancestor of modern corn . you see a single roll of grain that be cover in a hard case . unless you have a hammer , teosinte be not good for make tortillas . now , take a look at the ancient ancestor of banana . you can see the large seed . and unappetize brussel sprout , and eggplant , so beautiful .     now , to create these variety , breeder have use many different genetic technique over the year . some of they be quite creative , like mix two different specie together use a process call graft to create this variety that be half tomato and half potato . breeder have also use other type of genetic technique , such as random mutagenesis , which induce uncharacterized mutation into the plant . the rice in the cereal that many of we feed our baby be develop use this approach .     now , today , breeder have even more option to choose from . some of they be extraordinarily precise .     I want to give you a couple example from my own work . I work on rice , which be a staple food for more than half the world 's people . each year , 40 percent of the potential harvest be lose to pest and disease . for this reason , farmer plant rice variety that carry gene for resistance . this approach have be use for nearly 100 year . yet , when I start graduate school , no one know what these gene be . it be not until the 1990 that scientist finally uncover the genetic basis of resistance . in my laboratory , we isolate a gene for immunity to a very serious bacterial disease in asia and africa . we find we could engineer the gene into a conventional rice variety that be normally susceptible , and you can see the two leave on the bottom here be highly resistant to infection .     now , the same month that my laboratory publish our discovery on the rice immunity gene , my friend and colleague dave mackill stop by my office . he say , " seventy million rice farmer be have trouble grow rice . " that be because their field be flood , and these rice farmer be live on less than two dollar a day . although rice grow well in stand water , most rice variety will die if they be submerge for more than three day . flooding be expect to be increasingly problematic as the climate change . he tell I that his graduate student kenong xu and himself be study an ancient variety of rice that have an amazing property . it could withstand two week of complete submergence . he ask if I would be willing to help they isolate this gene . " why would you do that ? the reason be that sometimes it be the cheap , safest , and most effective technology for enhance food security and advance sustainable agriculture . I be go to give you three example .     first , take a look at papaya . it be delicious , right ? but now , look at this papaya . this papaya be infect with papaya ringspot virus . in the 1950 , this virus . dennis ' pioneer work be credit with rescue the papaya industry . today , 20 year later , there be still no other method to control this disease . there be no organic method . there be no conventional method . eighty percent of hawaiian papaya be genetically engineer .     now , some of you may still feel a little queasy about viral gene in your food , but consider this : the to reduce malnutrition . in less develop country , 500,000 child go blind every year because of lack of vitamin a. more than half will die . for this reason , scientist support by the rockefeller    in june of 1998 , tori murden mcclure leave nag head , north carolina for france .     that be her boat , the american pearl . it be 23 foot long and just six foot across at its widest point . the deck be the size of a cargo bed of a ford f-150 pickup truck . tori and her friend build it by hand , and it weigh about 1,800 pound . her plan be to row it alone across the atlantic ocean — no motor , no sail — something no woman and no american have ever do before . this would be her route : over 3,600 mile across the open north atlantic ocean .     professionally , tori work as a project administrator for the city of louisville , kentucky , her hometown , but her real passion be explore . this be not her first big expedition . several year early , she would become the first woman to ski to the south pole . she be an accomplished rower in college , even compete for a spot on the 1992 u.s . olympic team , but this , this be different .    when I be nine year old , my mom ask I what I would want my house to look like , and I draw this fairy mushroom . and then she actually build it . ( laughter )     I do not think I realize this be so unusual at the time , and maybe I still have not , because I be still design house . this be a six - story bespoke home on the island of bali . it be build almost entirely from bamboo . the living room overlook the valley from the fourth floor . you enter the house by a bridge . it can get hot in the tropic , so we make big curve roof to catch the breeze . but some room have tall window to keep the air conditioning in and the bug out . this room we leave open . we make an air - condition , tent bed . and one client want a tv room in the corner of her living room . box off an area with tall wall just do not feel right , so instead , we make this giant woven pod .     now , we do have all the necessary luxury , like bathroom . this one be a basket in the corner of the living room , and I 've got tell you , some people actually hesitate to use it . we have not quite figured out our acoustic insulation . ( laughter ) so there be lot of thing that we be still work on , but one thing I have learn   be that bamboo will treat you well if you use it right .     it be actually a wild grass . it grow on otherwise unproductive land — deep ravine , mountainside . it live off of rainwater , spring water , sunlight , and of the 1,450 specie of bamboo that grow across the world , we use just seven of they .     that be my dad . he be the one who get I build with bamboo , and he be stand in a clump of dendrocalamus asper niger that he plant just seven year ago . each year , it send up a new generation of shoot . that shoot , we watch it grow a meter in three day just last week , so we be talk about sustainable timber in three year .     now , we harvest from hundred of family - own clump . betung , as we call it , it be really long , up to 18 meter of usable length . try get that truck down the mountain . and it be strong : it have the tensile strength of steel , the compressive strength of concrete . slam four ton straight down on a pole , and it can take it . because it be hollow , it be lightweight , light enough to be lift by just a few man , or , apparently , one woman .     ( laughter ) ( applause )     and when my father build green school in bali , he choose bamboo for all of the building on campus , because he see it as a promise . it be a promise to the kid . it be one sustainable material that they will not run out of . and when I first see these structure under construction about six year ago , I just think , this make perfect sense . it be grow all around we . it be strong . it be elegant . it be earthquake - resistant . why have not this happen soon , and what can we do with it next ?     so along with some of the original builder of green school , I found ibuku . ibu mean " mother , " and ku mean " mine , " so it represent my mother earth , and at ibuku , we be a team of artisan , architect and designer , and what we be do together be create a new way of building . over the past five year together , we have build over 50 unique structure , most of they in bali . nine of they be at green village — you 've just see inside some of these home — and we fill they with bespoke furniture , we surround they with veggie gardens , we would love to invite you all to come visit someday . and while you be there , you can also see green school — we keep build classroom there each year — as well as an update fairy mushroom house .     we be also work on a little house for export . this be a traditional sumbanese home that we replicate , right down to the detail and textile . a restaurant with an open - air kitchen . it look a lot like a kitchen , right ? and a bridge that span 22 meter across a river .     now , what we be do , it be not entirely new . from little hut to elaborate bridge like this one in java , bamboo have be in use across the tropical region of the world for literally ten of thousand of year . there be island and even continent that be first reach by bamboo raft . but until recently , it be almost impossible to reliably protect bamboo from insect , and so , just about everything that be ever build out of bamboo be go . unprotected bamboo weather . untreated bamboo gets eat to dust . and so that be why most people , especially in asia , think that you could not be poor enough or rural enough to actually want to live in a bamboo house .     and so we think , what will it take to change their mind , to convince people that bamboo be worth build with , much less worth aspire to ?     first , we need safe treatment solution . borax be a natural salt . it turn bamboo into a viable building material . treat it properly , design it carefully , and a bamboo structure can last a lifetime .     second , build something extraordinary out of it . inspire people . fortunately , balinese culture foster craftsmanship . it value the artisan . so combine those with the adventurous outlier from new generation of locally train architect and designer and engineer , and always remember that you be design for curving , tapering , hollow pole . no two pole alike , no straight line , no two - by - four here . the try - and - true , well - craft formula and vocabulary of architecture do not apply here . we have have to invent our own rule . we ask the bamboo what it be good at , what it want to become , and what it say be : respect it , design for its strength , protect it from water , and to make the most of its curve .     so we design in real 3d , make scale structural model out of the same material that we 'll later use to build the house . and bamboo model - making , it be an art , as well as some hardcore engineering .     so that be the blueprint of the house .     ( laughter )     and we bring it to site , and with tiny ruler , we measure each pole , and consider each curve , and we choose a piece of bamboo from the pile to replicate that house on site .     when it come down to the detail , we consider everything . why be door so often rectangular ? why not round ? how could you make a door well ? well , its hinge battle with gravity , and gravity will always win in the end , so why not have it pivot on the center where it can stay balanced ? and while you be at it , why not door shape like teardrop ?     to reap the selective benefit and work within the constraint of this material , we have really have to push ourselves , and within that constraint , we have find space for something new . it be a challenge : how do you make a ceiling if you do not have any flat board to work with ? let I tell you , sometimes I dream of sheet rock and plywood . ( laughter ) but if what you 've get be skilled craftsman and itsy bitsy little split , weave that ceiling together , stretch a canvas over it , lacquer it . how do you design durable kitchen countertop that do justice to this curving structure you 've just build ? slice up a boulder like a loaf of bread , hand - carve each to fit the other , leave the crust on , and what we be do , it be almost entirely handmade . the structural connection of our building be reinforce by steel joint , but we use a lot of hand - whittle bamboo pin . there be thousand of pin in each floor . this floor be make of glossy and durable bamboo skin . you can feel the texture under bare foot .     and the floor that you walk on , can it affect the way that you walk ? can it change the footprint that you 'll ultimately leave on the world ? I remember be nine year old and feel wonder , and possibility , and a little bit of idealism . and we 've get a really long way to go , there be a lot leave to learn , but one thing I know be that with creativity and commitment , you can create beauty and comfort and safety and even luxury out of a material that will grow back .     thank you .    why do we cheat ? and why do happy people cheat ? and when we say " infidelity , " what exactly do we mean ? be it a hookup , a love story , pay sex , a chat room , a massage with a happy ending ? why do we think that man cheat out of boredom and fear of intimacy , but woman cheat out of loneliness and hunger for intimacy ? and be an affair always the end of a relationship ?     for the past 10 year , I have travel the globe and work extensively with hundred of couple who have be shatter by infidelity . there be one simple act of transgression that can rob a couple of their relationship , their happiness and their very identity : an affair . and yet , this extremely common act be so poorly understand . so this talk be for anyone who have ever love .     adultery have exist since marriage be invent , and so , too , the taboo against it . in fact , infidelity have a tenacity that marriage can only envy , so much so , that this be the only commandment that be repeat twice in the bible : once for do it , and once just for think about it .    mark twain sum up what I take to be one of the fundamental problem of cognitive science with a single witticism . he say , " there be something fascinating about science . one get such wholesale return of conjecture out of such a trifling investment in fact . " ( laughter )     twain mean it as a joke , of course , but he be right : there be something fascinating about science . from a few bone , we infer the existence of dinosuar . from spectral line , the composition of nebulae . from fruit fly , the mechanism of heredity , and from reconstructed image of blood flow through the brain , or in my case , from the behavior of very young child , we try to say something about the fundamental mechanism of human cognition . in particular , in my lab in the department of brain and cognitive science at mit , I have spend the past decade try to understand the mystery of how child learn so much from so little so quickly . because , it turn out that the fascinating thing about science be also a fascinating thing about child , which , to put a gentler spin on mark twain , be precisely their ability to draw rich , abstract inference rapidly and accurately from sparse , noisy datum . I be go to give you just two example today . one be about a problem of generalization , and the other be about a problem of causal reasoning . and although I be go to talk about work in my lab , this work be inspire by and indebte to a field . I be grateful to mentor , colleague , and collaborator around the world .     let I start with the problem of generalization . generalize from small sample of datum be the bread and butter of science . we poll a tiny fraction of the electorate and we predict the outcome of national election . we see how a handful of patient respond to treatment in a clinical trial , and we bring drug to a national market . but this only work if our sample be randomly draw from the population . if our sample be cherry - pick in some way — say , we poll only urban voter , or say , in our clinical trial for treatment for heart disease , we include only man — the result may not generalize to the broad population .     so scientist care whether evidence be randomly sample or not , but what do that have to do with baby ? well , baby have to generalize from small sample of datum all the time . they see a few rubber duck and learn that they float , or a few ball and learn that they bounce . and they develop expectation about duck and ball that they be go to extend to rubber duck and ball for the rest of their life . and the kind of generalization baby have to make about duck and ball they have to make about almost everything : shoe and ship and seal wax and cabbage and king .     so do baby care whether the tiny bit of evidence they see be plausibly representative of a large population ? let us find out .    in 2011 , during the final six month of kim jong - il 's life , I live undercover in north korea .     I be bear and raise in south korea , their enemy . I live in america , their other enemy .     since 2002 , I have visit north korea a few time . and I have come to realize that to write about it with any meaning , or to understand the place beyond the regime 's propaganda , the only option be total immersion . so I pose as a teacher and a missionary at an all - male university in pyongyang .     the pyongyang university of science and technology be found by evangelical christian who cooperate with the regime to educate the son of the north korean elite , without proselytizing , which be a capital crime there . the student be 270 young man , expect to be the future leader of the most isolated and brutal dictatorship in existence . when I arrive , they become my student .     2011 be a special year , mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of north korea 's original great leader , kim il - sung . to celebrate the occasion , the regime shut down all university , and send student off to the field to build the dprk 's much - herald ideal as the world 's most powerful and prosperous nation . my student be the only one spare from that fate .     north korea be a gulag pose as a nation . everything there be about the great leader . every book , every newspaper article , every song , every tv program — there be just one subject . the flower be name after he , the mountain be carve with his slogan . every citizen wear the badge of the great leader at all time . even their calendar system begin with the birth of kim il - sung .     the school be a heavily guard prison , pose as a campus . teacher could only leave on group outing accompany by an official minder . even then , our trip be limit to sanctioned national monument celebrate the great leader . the student be not allow to leave the campus , or communicate with their parent . their day be meticulously map out , and any free time they have be devote to honor their great leader . lesson plan have to meet the approval of north korean staff , every class be record and report on , every room be bug , and every conversation , overhear . every blank space be cover with the   portrait of kim il - sung and kim jong - il , like everywhere else in north korea .     we be never allow to discuss the outside world . as student of science and technology , many of they be computer major but they do not know the existence of the internet . they have never hear of mark zuckerberg or steve job . facebook , twitter — none of those thing would have mean a thing . and I could not tell they .     I go there look for truth . but where do you even start when an entire nation 's ideology , my student ' day - to - day reality , and even my own position at the university , be all build on lie ?     I start with a game . we play " truth and lie . " a volunteer would write a sentence on the chalkboard , and the other student have to guess whether it be a truth or a lie . once a student write , " I visit china last year on vacation , " and everyone shout , " lie ! " you all know this be not possible . virtually no north korean be allow to leave the country . even travel within their own country require a travel pass .     I have hope that this game would reveal some truth about my student , because they lie so often and so easily , whether about the mythical accomplishment of their great leader , or the strange claim that they clone a rabbit as fifth grader . the difference between truth and lie seem at time hazy to they . it take I a while to understand the different type of lie ; they lie to shield their system from the world , or they be teach lie , and be just regurgitate they . or , at moment , they lie out of habit . but if all they have ever know be lie , how could we expect they to be otherwise ?     next , I try to teach they essay writing . but that turn out to be nearly impossible . essay be about come up with one 's own thesis , and make an evidence - base argument to prove it . these student , however , be simply tell what to think , and they obey . in their world , critical thinking be not allow .     I also give they the weekly assignment of write a personal letter , to anybody . it take a long time , but eventually some of they begin to write to their mother , their friend , their girlfriend . although those be just homework , and would never reach their intend recipient , my student slowly begin to reveal their true feeling in they . they write that they be feed up with the sameness of everything . they be worried about their future . in those letter , they rarely ever mention their great leader .     I be spend all of my time with these young man . we all eat meal together , play basketball together . I often call they gentleman , which make they giggle . they blush at the mention of girl . and I come to adore they . and watch they open up even in the tiny of way , be deeply move .     but something also feel wrong . during those month of live in their world , I often wonder if the truth would , in fact , improve their life . I want so much to tell they the truth , of their country and of the outside world , where arab youth be turn their rotten regime inside out , use the power of social medium , where everyone except they be connect through the world wide web , which be not worldwide after all . but for they , the truth be dangerous . by encourage they to run after it , I be put they at risk — of persecution , of heartbreak .     when you be not allow to express anything in the open , you become good at read what be unspoken . in one of their personal letter to I , a student write that he understand why I always call they gentleman . it be because I be wish they to be gentle in life , he say .     on my last day in december of 2011 , the day kim jong - il 's death be announce , their world shatter . I have to leave without a proper goodbye . but I think they know how sad I be for they .     once , toward the end of my stay , a student say to I , " professor , we never think of you as be different from we . our circumstance be different , but you be the same as we . we want you to know that we truly think of you as be the same . "     today , if I could respond to my student with a letter of my own , which be of course impossible , I would tell they this : " my dear gentleman , it be be a bit over three year since I last see you . and now , you must be 22 — maybe even as old as 23 . at our final class , I ask you if there be anything you want . the only wish you express , the only thing you ever ask of I in all those month we spend together , be for I to speak to you in korean . just once .    along the ancient path of the monongahela river , braddock , pennsylvania sit in the eastern region of allegheny county , approximately nine mile outside of pittsburgh .     an industrial suburb , braddock be home to andrew carnegie 's first steel mill , the edgar thomson work . operate since 1875 , it be the last functioning steel mill in the region . for 12 year , I have produce collaborative portrait , still life , landscape and aerial view in order to build a visual archive to address the intersection of the steel industry , the environment , and the health care system 's impact on the body of my family and community .     the tradition and grand narrative of braddock be mostly comprise of story of industrialist and trade union . currently , the new narrative about braddock , a poster child for rust belt revitalization , be a story of urban pioneer discover a new frontier . mass medium have omit the fact that braddock be predominantly black . our existence have be co - opt , silence and erase .     fourth generation in a lineage of woman , I be raise under the protection and care of grandma ruby , off 8th street at 805 washington avenue . she work as a manager for goodwill . mom be a nurse 's aid . she watch the steel mill close and white flight to suburban development . by the time my generation walk the street , disinvestment at the local , state and federal level , erode infrastructure , and the war on drug dismantle my family and community .     grandma ruby 's stepfather gramp be one of few black man to retire from carnegie 's mill with his pension . he work in high temperature , tear down and rebuild furnace , clean up spilt metal and slag . the history of a place be write on the body and the landscape . area of heavy truck traffic , exposure to benzene and atomize metal , risk cancer and lupus . one hundred twenty - three licensed bed , 652 employee , rehabilitation program decimate . a housing discrimination lawsuit against allegheny county remove where the project talbot tower once stand . recent rezoning for more light industry have since appear . google map and google earth pixelation conceal the flammable waste be use to squeeze the bunn family off their home and land . in 2013 , I charter a helicopter with my camera to document this aggressive dispossession . in flight , my observation reveal thousand of plastic white bundle own by a conservation industry that claim it be eco - friendly and recycle million of tire to preserve people 's life and to improve people 's life .     my work spiral from the micro to the macro level , excavate hide history . recently , at the seattle art museum , isaac bunn and I mount this exhibition , and the exhibition be use as a platform to launch his voice . through reclamation of our narrative , we will continue to fight historic erasure and socioeconomic inequality .     thank you .    this be my great uncle , my father 's father 's young brother . his name be joe mckenna . he be a young husband and a semi - pro basketball player and a fireman in new york city . family history say he love be a fireman , and so in 1938 , on one of his day off , he elect to hang out at the firehouse . to make himself useful that day , he start polish all the brass , the railing on the fire truck , the fitting on the wall , and one of the fire hose nozzles , a giant , heavy piece of metal , topple off a shelf and hit he . a few day later , his shoulder start to hurt . two day after that , he spike a fever . the fever climb and climb . his wife be take care of he , but nothing she do make a difference , and when they get the local doctor in , nothing he do matter either .     they flag down a cab and take he to the hospital . the nurse there recognize right away that he have an infection , what at the time they would have call " blood poisoning , " and though they probably do not say it , they would have know right away that there be nothing they could do .     there be nothing they could do because the thing we use now to cure infection do not exist yet . the first test of penicillin , the first antibiotic , be three year in the future . people who get infection either recover , if they be lucky , or they die . my great uncle be not lucky . he be in the hospital for a week , shake with chill , dehydrate and delirious , sink into a coma as his organ fail . his condition grow so desperate that the people from his firehouse line up to give he transfusion hope to dilute the infection surge through his blood .     nothing work . he die . he be 30 year old .     if you look back through history , most people die the way my great uncle die . most people do not die of cancer or heart disease , the lifestyle disease that afflict we in the west today . they do not die of those disease because they do not live long enough to develop they . they die of injury — be gore by an ox , shoot on a battlefield , crush in one of the new factory of the industrial revolution — and most of the time from infection , which finish what those injury begin .     all of that change when antibiotic arrive . suddenly , infection that have be a death sentence become something you recover from in day . it seem like a miracle , and ever since , we have be live inside the golden epoch of the miracle drug .     and now , we be come to an end of it . my great uncle die in the last day of the pre - antibiotic era . we stand today on the threshold of the post - antibiotic era , in the early day of a time when simple infection such as the one joe have will kill people once again .     in fact , they already be . people be die of infection again because of a phenomenon call antibiotic resistance . briefly , it work like this . bacteria compete against each other for resource , for food , by manufacture lethal compound that they direct against each other . other bacteria , to protect themselves , evolve defense against that chemical attack . when we first make antibiotic , we take those compound into the lab and make our own version of they , and bacteria respond to our attack the way they always have .     here be what happen next : penicillin be distribute in 1943 , and widespread penicillin resistance arrive by 1945 . vancomycin arrive in 1972 , vancomycin resistance in 1988 . imipenem in 1985 , and resistance to in 1998 . daptomycin , one of the most recent drug , in 2003 , and resistance to it just a year later in 2004 .     for 70 year , we play a game of leapfrog — our drug and their resistance , and then another drug , and then resistance again — and now the game be end . bacteria develop resistance so quickly that pharmaceutical company have decide make antibiotic be not in their good interest , so there be infection move across the world for which , out of the more than 100 antibiotic available on the market , two drug might work with side effect , or one drug , or none .     this be what that look like . in 2000 , the center for disease control and prevention , the cdc , identify a single case in a hospital in north carolina of an infection resistant to all but two drug . today , that infection , know as kpc , have spread to every state but three , and to south america , europe and the middle east . in 2008 , doctor in sweden diagnose a man from india with a different infection resistant to all but one drug that time . the gene that create that resistance , know as ndm , have now spread from india into china , asia , africa , europe and canada , and the united states .     it would be natural to hope that these infection be extraordinary case , but in fact , in the united states and europe , 50,000 people a year die of infection which no drug can help . a project charter by the british government know as the review on antimicrobial resistance estimate that the worldwide toll right now be 700,000 death a year .     that be a lot of death , and yet , the chance be good that you do not feel at risk , that you imagine these people be hospital patient in intensive care unit or nursing home resident near the end of their life , people whose infection be remote from we , in situation we can not identify with .     what you do not think about , none of we do , be that antibiotic support almost all of modern life .     if we lose antibiotic , here be what else we would lose : first , any protection for people with weakened immune system — cancer patient , aid patient , transplant recipient , premature baby .     next , any treatment that install foreign object in the body : stent for stroke , pump for diabetes , dialysis , joint replacement . how many athletic baby boomer need new hip and knee ? a recent study estimate that without antibiotic , one out of ever six would die .     next , we would probably lose surgery . many operation be precede by prophylactic dose of antibiotic . without that protection , we would lose the ability to open the hide space of the body . so no heart operation , no prostate biopsy , no cesarean section . we would have to learn to fear infection that now seem minor . strep throat use to cause heart failure . skin infection lead to amputation . give birth kill , in the clean hospital , almost one woman out of every 100 . pneumonia take three child out of every 10 .     more than anything else , we would lose the confident way we live our everyday life . if you know that any injury could kill you , would you ride a motorcycle , bomb down a ski slope , climb a ladder to hang your christmas light , let your kid slide into home plate ? after all , the first person to receive penicillin , a british policeman name albert alexander , who be so ravage by infection that his scalp ooze pus and doctor have to take out an eye , be infect by do something very simple . he walk into his garden and scratch his face on a thorn . that british project I mention which estimate that the worldwide toll right now be 700,000 death a year also predict that if we can not get this under control by 2050 , not long , the worldwide toll will be 10 million death a year .     how do we get to this point where what we have to look forward to be those terrifying number ? the difficult answer be , we do it to ourselves . resistance be an inevitable biological process , but we bear the responsibility for accelerate it . we do this by squander antibiotic with a heedlessness that now seem shocking . penicillin be sell over the counter until the 1950 . in much of the develop world , most antibiotic still be . in the united states , 50 percent of the antibiotic give in hospital be unnecessary . forty - five percent of the prescription write in doctor 's office be for condition that antibiotic can not help . and that be just in healthcare . on much of the planet , most meat animal get antibiotic every day of their life , not to cure illness , but to fatten they up and to protect they against the factory farm condition they be raise in . in the united states , possibly 80 percent of the antibiotic sell every year go to farm animal , not to human , create resistant bacteria that move off the farm in water , in dust , in the meat the animal become . aquaculture depend on antibiotic too , particularly in asia , and fruit grow relie on antibiotic to protect apple , pear , citrus , against disease . and because bacteria can pass their dna to each other like a traveler hand off a suitcase at an airport , once we have encourage that resistance into existence , there be no know where it will spread .     this be predictable . in fact , it be predict by alexander fleming , the man who discover penicillin . he be give the nobel prize in 1945 in recognition , and in an interview shortly after , this be what he say :     " the thoughtless person play with penicillin treatment be morally responsible for the death of a man who succumb to infection with a pencillin - resistant organism . " he add , " I hope this evil can be avert . "     can we avert it ? there be company work on novel antibiotic , thing the superbug have never see before . we need those new drug badly , and we need incentive : discovery grant , extend patent , prize , to lure other company into make antibiotic again .     but that probably will not be enough . here be why : evolution always win . bacteria birth a new generation every 20 minute . it take pharmaceutical chemistry 10 year to derive a new drug . every time we use an antibiotic , we give the bacteria billion of chance to crack the code of the defense we 've construct . there have never yet be a drug they could not defeat .     this be asymmetric warfare , but we can change the outcome . we could build system to harvest datum to tell we automatically and specifically how antibiotic be be use . we could build gatekeepe into drug order system so that every prescription get a second look . we could require agriculture to give up antibiotic use . we could build surveillance system to tell we where resistance be emerge next .     those be the tech solution . they probably be not enough either , unless we help . antibiotic resistance be a habit . we all know how hard it be to change a habit . but as a society , we 've do that in the past . people use to toss litter into the street , use to not wear seatbelt , use to smoke inside public building . we do not do those thing anymore . we do not trash the environment or court devastating accident or expose other to the possibility of cancer , because we decide those thing be expensive , destructive , not in our good interest . we change social norm . we could change social norm around antibiotic use too .     I know that the scale of antibiotic resistance seem overwhelming , but if you 've ever buy a fluorescent lightbulb because you be concern about climate change , or read the label on a box of cracker because you think about the deforestation from palm oil , you already know what it feel like to take a tiny step to address an overwhelming problem . we could take those kind of step for antibiotic use too . we could forgo give an antibiotic if we be not sure it be the right one . we could stop insist on a prescription for our kid 's ear infection before we be sure what cause it . we could ask every restaurant , every supermarket , where their meat come from . we could promise each other never again to buy chicken or shrimp or fruit raise with routine antibiotic use , and if we do those thing , we could slow down the arrival of the post - antibiotic world .     but we have to do it soon . penicillin begin the antibiotic era in 1943 . in just 70 year , we walk ourselves up to the edge of disaster . we will not get 70 year to find our way back out again .     thank you very much .    when you be a child , anything and everything be possible . the challenge , so often , be hang on to that as we grow up . and as a four - year - old , I have the opportunity to sail for the first time .     I will never forget the excitement as we close the coast . I will never forget the feeling of adventure as I climb on board the boat and stare into her tiny cabin for the first time . but the most amazing feeling be the feeling of freedom , the feeling that I feel when we hoist her sail . as a four - year - old child , it be the great sense of freedom that I could ever imagine . ( laughter ) ( applause ) you could imagine it would be quite difficult to sleep in that situation , even as a passenger . but you be not a passenger . you be alone on a boat you can barely stand up in , and you have to make every single decision on board . I be absolutely exhausted , physically and mentally . eight sail change in 12 hour . the mainsail weigh three time my body weight , and after each change , I would collapse on the floor soak with sweat with this freeze southern ocean air burn the back of my throat .     but out there , those low of the low be so often contrast with the high of the high . a few day later , we come out of the back of the low . against all odd , we would be able to drive ahead of the record within that depression . the sky clear , the rain stop , and our heartbeat , the monstrous sea around we be transform into the most beautiful moonlit mountain .     it be hard to explain , but you enter a different mode when you head out there . your boat be your entire world , and what you take with you when you leave be all you have . if I say to you all now , " go off into vancouver and find everything you will need for your survival for the next three month , " that be quite a task . that be food , fuel , clothe , even toilet roll and toothpaste . that be what we do , and when we leave we manage it down to the last drop of diesel and the last packet of food . no experience in my life could have give I a well understanding of the definition of the word " finite . " what we have out there be all we have . there be no more .     and never in my life have I ever translate that definition of finite that I would feel on board to anything outside of sailing until I step off the boat at the finish line having break that record .     ( applause )     suddenly I connect the dot . our global economy be no different . it be entirely dependent on finite material we only have once in the history of humanity . and it be a bit like see something you be not expect under a stone and have two choice : I either put that stone to one side and learn more about it , or I put that stone back and I carry on with my dream job of sail around the world . " and I think to myself , well , that be well outside my lifetime , and a much great figure than the prediction for oil . but I do the math , and I realize that my great - grandfather have be bear exactly 118 year before that year , and I sit on his knee until I be 11 year old , and I realize it be nothing in time , nor in history . and it make I make a decision I never think I would make : to leave the sport of solo sailing behind I and focus on the great challenge I would ever come across : the future of our global economy .     and I quickly realize it be not just about energy . it be also material . in 2008 , I pick up a scientific study look at how many year we have of valuable material to extract from the ground : copper , 61 ; tin , zinc , 40 ; silver , 29 . these figure could not be exact , but we know those material be finite . we only have they once . and yet , our speed that we 've use these material have increase rapidly , exponentially . with more people in the world with more stuff , we 've effectively see 100 year of price decline in those basic commodity erase in just 10 year . and this affect all of we . it be bring huge volatility in price , so much so that in 2011 , your average european car manufacturer see a raw material price increase of 500 million euro , wipe away half their operating profit through something they have absolutely no control over .     and the more I learn , the more I start to change my own life . I start travel less , do less , use less . it feel like actually do less be what we have to do . but it sit uneasy with I . it do not feel right . it feel like we be buy ourselves time . we be eke thing out a bit long . even if everybody change , it would not solve the problem . it would not fix the system . it be vital in the transition , but what fascinate I be , in the transition to what ? what could actually work ?     it strike I that the system itself , the framework within which we live , be fundamentally flaw , and I realize ultimately that our operating system , the way our economy function , the way our economy be be build , be a system in itself . at sea , I have to understand complex system . I have to take multiple input , I have to process they , and I have to understand the system to win . I have to make sense of it . and as I look at our global economy , I realize it too be that system , but it be a system that effectively can not run in the long term .     and I realize we 've be perfect what be effectively a linear economy for 150 year , where we take a material out of the ground , we make something out of it , and then ultimately that product gets throw away , and yes , we do recycle some of it , but more an attempt to get out what we can at the end , not by design . it be an economy that fundamentally can not run in the long term , and if we know that we have finite material , why would we build an economy that would effectively use thing up , that would create waste ? life itself have exist for billion of year and have continually adapt to use material effectively . it be a complex system , but within it , there be no waste . everything be metabolize . it be not a linear economy at all , but circular .     and I feel like the child in the garden . for the first time on this new journey , I could see exactly where we be head . if we could build an economy that would use thing rather than use they up , we could build a future that really could work in the long term . I be excited . this be something to work towards . we know exactly where we be head . we just have to work out how to get there , and it be exactly with this in mind that we create the ellen macarthur foundation in september 2010 .     many school of thought feed our thinking and point to this model : industrial symbiosis , performance economy , share economy , biomimicry , and of course , cradle - to - cradle design . material would be define as either technical or biological , waste would be design out entirely , and we would have a system that could function absolutely in the long term .     so what could this economy look like ? maybe we would not buy light fitting , but we would pay for the service of light , and the manufacturer would recover the material and change the light fitting when we have more efficient product . what if packaging be so nontoxic it could dissolve in water and we could ultimately drink it ? it would never become waste . what if engine be re - manufacturable , and we could recover the component material and significantly reduce energy demand . what if we could recover component from circuit board , reutilize they , and then fundamentally recover the material within they through a second stage ? what if we could collect food waste , human waste ? what if we could turn that into fertilizer , heat , energy , ultimately reconnecte nutrient system and rebuild natural capital ? and car — what we want be to move around . we do not need to own the material within they . could car become a service and provide we with mobility in the future ? all of this sound amazing , but these be not just idea , they be real today , and these lie at the forefront of the circular economy . what lie before we be to expand they and scale they up .     so how would you shift from linear to circular ? well , the team and I at the foundation think you might want to work with the top university in the world , with lead business within the world , with the big convening platform in the world , and with government . we think you might want to work with the good analyst and ask they the question , " can the circular economy decouple growth from resource constraint ? be the circular economy able to rebuild natural capital ? could the circular economy replace current chemical fertilizer use ? " yes be the answer to the decoupling , but also yes , we could replace current fertilizer use by a staggering 2.7 time . but what inspire I most about the circular economy be its ability to inspire young people . when young people see the economy through a circular lens , they see brand new opportunity on exactly the same horizon . they can use their creativity and knowledge to rebuild the entire system , and it be there for the taking right now , and the fast we do this , the well .     so could we achieve this in their lifetime ? be it actually possible ? I believe yes . when you look at the lifetime of my great - grandfather , anything be possible . when he be bear , there be only 25 car in the world ; they have only just be invent . when he be 14 , we fly for the first time in history . now there be 100,000 charter flight every single day . when he be 45 , we build the first computer . many say it would not catch on , but it do , and just 20 year later we turn it into a microchip of which there will be thousand in this room here today . ten year before he die , we build the first mobile phone . it be not that mobile , to be fair , but now it really be , and as my great - grandfather leave this earth , the internet arrive . now we can do anything , but more importantly , now we have a plan .     thank you .
