I be a journalist , and I 've be write and research human trafficking for the past eight year or so , and even so , I never put together this personal story with my professional life until pretty recently . I think this profound disconnect actually symbolize most of our understanding about human trafficking . because human trafficking be far more prevalent , complex and close to home than most of we realize .     I spend time in jail and brothel , interview hundred of survivor and law enforcement , ngo worker . and when I think about what we 've do about human trafficking , I be hugely disappointed . partly because we do not even talk about the problem right at all . when I say " human trafficking , " most of you probably do not think about someone like my auntie . you probably think about a young girl or woman , who be be brutally force into prostitution by a violent pimp . that be real suffering , and that be a real story . that story make I angry for far more than just the reality of that situation , though .     as a journalist , I really care about how we relate to each other through language , and the way we tell that story , with all the gory , violent detail , the salacious aspect — I call that " look at her scar " journalism . we use that story to convince ourselves that human trafficking be a bad man do a bad thing to an innocent girl . that story let we off the hook . it take you all the societal context that we might be indict for , for the structural inequality , or the poverty , or the barrier to migration . we let ourselves think that human trafficking be only about force prostitution , when in reality , human trafficking be embed in our everyday life .     let I show you what I mean . force prostitution account for 22 percent of human trafficking . ten percent be in state- impose force labor . but a whopping 68 percent be for the purpose of create the good and deliver the service that most of we rely on every day , in sector like agricultural work , domestic work and construction . that be food and care and shelter . and somehow , these most essential worker be also among the world 's most underpaid and exploit today . human trafficking be the use of force , fraud or coercion to compel another person 's labor . and it be find in cotton field , and coltan mine , and even car wash in norway and england . it be find in u.s . military basis in iraq and afghanistan .     it be find in thailand 's fishing industry . that country have become the large exporter of shrimp in the world . but what be the circumstance behind all that cheap and plentiful shrimp ? thai military be catch sell burmese and cambodian migrant onto fishing boat . those fishing boat be take out , the man put to work , and they be throw overboard if they make the mistake of fall sick , or try to resist their treatment . those fish be then use to feed shrimp , the shrimp be then sell to four major global retailer : costco , tesco , walmart and carrefour .     human trafficking be find on a small scale than just that , and in place you would never even imagine . trafficker have force young people to drive ice cream truck , or to sing in tour boy ' choir . trafficking have even be find in a hair braid salon in new jersey .     the scheme in that case be incredible . the trafficker find young family who be from ghana and togo , and they tell these family that " your daughter be go to get a fine education in the united states . " they then locate winner of the green card lottery , and they tell they , " we 'll help you out . we 'll get you a plane ticket . we 'll pay your fee . all you have to do be take this young girl with you , say that she be your sister or your spouse . once everyone arrive in new jersey , the young girl be take away , and put to work for 14 - hour day , seven day a week , for five year . they make their trafficker nearly four million dollar .     this be a huge problem . so what have we do about it ? we 've mostly turn to the criminal justice system . but keep in mind , most victim of human trafficking be poor and marginalize . they be migrant , people of color . sometimes they be in the sex trade . and for population like these , the criminal justice system be too often part of the problem , rather than the solution . in study after study , in country range from bangladesh to the united states , between 20 and 60 percent of the people in the sex trade who be survey say that they have be rape or assault by the police in the past year alone . people in prostitution , include people who have be traffic into it , regularly receive multiple conviction for prostitution . have that criminal record make it so much more difficult to leave poverty , leave abuse , or leave prostitution , if that person so desire . worker outside of the sex sector — if they try and resist their treatment , they risk deportation . in case after case I 've study , employer have no problem call on law enforcement to try and threaten or deport their striking traffic worker . if those worker run away , they risk become part of the great mass of undocumented worker who be also subject to the whim of law enforcement if they be catch .     law enforcement be suppose to identify victim and prosecute trafficker . but out of an estimate 21 million victim of human trafficking in the world , they have help and identify few than 50,000 people . that be like compare the population of the world to the population of los angeles , proportionally speak . as for conviction , out of an estimate 5,700 conviction in 2013 , few than 500 be for labor trafficking . keep in mind that labor trafficking account for 68 percent of all trafficking , but few than 10 percent of the conviction .     I 've hear one expert say that trafficking happen where need meet greed . I would like to add one more element to that . trafficking happen in sector where worker be exclude from protection , and deny the right to organize . trafficking do not happen in a vacuum . it happen in systematically degraded work environment . you might be think , oh , she be talk about fail state , or war - tear state , or — I be actually talk about the united states . let I tell you what that look like .     I spend many month research a trafficking case call global horizon , involve hundred of thai farm worker . they be send all over the state , to work in hawaii pineapple plantation , and washington apple orchard , and anywhere the work be need . they be promise three year of solid agricultural work . so they make a calculated risk . they sell their land , they sell their wife ' jewelry , to make thousand in recruitment fee for this company , global horizon . but once they be bring over , their passport be confiscate . some of the man be beat and hold at gunpoint . they work so hard they faint in the field . this case hit I so hard .     after I come back home , I be wander through the grocery store , and I freeze in the produce department . I be remember the over - the - top meal the global horizon survivor would make for I every time I show up to interview they . they finish one meal with this plate of perfect , long - stem strawberry , and as they hand they to I , they say , " be not these the kind of strawberry you eat with somebody special in the state ? and do not they taste so much well when you know the people whose hand pick they for you ? "     as I stand in that grocery store week later , I realize I have no idea of who to thank for this plenty , and no idea of how they be be treat . so , like the journalist I be , I start dig into the agricultural sector . and I find there be too many field , and too few labor inspector . I find multiple layer of plausible deniability between grower and distributor and processor , and god know who else . the global horizon survivor have be bring to the state on a temporary guest worker program . that guest worker program tie a person 's legal status to his or her employer , and deny that worker the right to organize . mind you , none of what I be describe about this agricultural sector or the guest worker program be actually human trafficking . it be merely what we find legally tolerable . and I would argue this be fertile ground for exploitation . and all of this have be hide to I , before I have try to understand it .     I be not the only person grapple with these issue . pierre omidyar , founder of ebay , be one of the big anti - trafficking philanthropist in the world . and even he wind up accidentally invest nearly 10 million dollar in the pineapple plantation cite as have the bad working condition in that global horizon case . when he find out , he and his wife be shock and horrified , and they wound up write an op - ed for a newspaper , say that it be up to all of we to learn everything we can about the labor and supply chain of the product that we support . I totally agree .     what would happen if each one of we decide that we be no long go to support company if they do not eliminate exploitation from their labor and supply chain ? if we demand law call for the same ? if all the ceo out there decide that they be go to go through their business and say , " no more " ? if we end recruitment fee for migrant worker ? if we decide that guest worker should have the right to organize without fear of retaliation ? these would be decision hear around the world . this be not a matter of buy a fair - trade peach and call it a day , buy a guilt - free zone with your money . that be not how it work . this be the decision to change a system that be break , and that we have unwittingly but willingly allow ourselves to profit from and benefit from for too long .     we often dwell on human trafficking survivor ' victimization . but that be not my experience of they . over all the year that I 've be talk to they , they have teach I that we be more than our bad day . each one of we be more than what we have live through . especially traffic survivor . these people be the most resourceful and resilient and responsible in their community . they be the people that you would take a gamble on . you would say , I be gong to sell my ring , because I have the chance to send you off to a well future . they be the emissary of hope .     these survivor do not need saving . they need solidarity , because they be behind some of the most exciting social justice movement out there today . the nanny and housekeeper who march with their family and their employer ' family — their activism get we an international treaty on domestic worker ' right . the nepali woman who be traffic into the sex trade — they come together , and they decide that they be go to make the world 's first anti - trafficking organization actually head and run by traffic survivor themselves . these indian shipyard worker be traffic to do post - hurricane katrina reconstruction . they be threaten with deportation , but they break out of their work compound and they march from new orleans to washington , d.c . , to protest labor exploitation . they cofounde an organization call the national guest worker alliance , and through this organization , they have wind up help other worker bring to light exploitation and abuse in supply chain in walmart and hershey 's factory . and although the department of justice decline to take their case , a team of civil right lawyer win the first of a dozen civil suit this february , and get their client 14 million dollar .     these survivor be fight for people they do not even know yet , other worker , and for the possibility of a just world for all of we . this be our chance to do the same . this be our chance to make the decision that tell we who we be , as a people and as a society ; that our prosperity be no long prosperity , as long as it be pin to other people 's pain ; that our life be inextricably weave together ; and that we have the power to make a different choice .     I be so reluctant to share my story of my auntie with you . before I start this ted process and climb up on this stage , I have tell literally a handful of people about it , because , like many a journalist , I be far more interested in learn about your story than share much , if anything , about my own .    for the past decade , I 've be study non - state armed group : armed organization like terrorist , insurgent or militia . I document what these group do when they be not shoot . my goal be to well understand these violent actor and to study way to encourage transition from violent engagement to nonviolent confrontation . I work in the field , in the policy world and in the library .     understand non - state armed group be key to solve most ongoing conflict , because war have change . it use to be a contest between state . no long . it be now a conflict between state and non - state actor . for example , of the 216 peace agreement sign between 1975 and 2011 , 196 of they be between a state and a non - state actor . so we need to understand these group ; we need to either engage they or defeat they in any conflict resolution process that have to be successful .     so how do we do that ? we need to know what make these organization tick . we know a lot about how they fight , why they fight , but no one look at what they be do when they be not fight . yet , armed struggle and unarmed politic be relate . it be all part of the same organization . we can not understand these group , let alone defeat they , if we do not have the full picture .     and armed group today be complex organization . take the lebanese hezbollah , know for its violent confrontation against israel . but since its creation in the early 1980s , hezbollah have also set up a political party , a social - service network , and a military apparatus . similarly , the palestinian hamas , know for its suicide attack against israel , also run the gaza strip since 2007 . so these group do way more than just shoot . they multi - task . they set up complex communication machine — radio station , tv channel , internet website and social medium strategy . and up here , you have the isis magazine , print in english and publish to recruit . armed group also invest in complex fund - raising — not loot , but set up profitable business ; for example , construction company . now , these activity be key . they allow these group to increase their strength , increase their fund , to well recruit and to build their brand .     armed group also do something else : they build strong bond with the population by invest in social service . they build school , they run hospital , they set up vocational - training program or micro - loan program . hezbollah offer all of these service and more . armed group also seek to win the population over by offer something that the state be not provide : safety and security . the initial rise of the taliban in war - tear afghanistan , or even the beginning of the ascent of isis , can be understand also by look at these group ' effort to provide security . now , unfortunately , in these case , the provision of security come at an unbearably high price for the population . but in general , provide social service fill a gap , a governance gap leave by the government , and allow these group to increase their strength and their power . for example , the 2006 electoral victory of the palestinian hamas can not be understand without acknowledge the group 's social work .     now , this be a really complex picture , yet in the west , when we look at armed group , we only think of the violent side . but that be not enough to understand these group ' strength , strategy or long - term vision . these group be hybrid . they rise because they fill a gap leave by the government , and they emerge to be both armed and political , engage in violent struggle and provide governance .     and the more these organization be complex and sophisticated , the less we can think of they as the opposite of a state . now , what do you call a group like hezbollah ? they run part of a territory , they administer all their function , they pick up the garbage , they run the sewage system . be this a state ? be it a rebel group ? or maybe something else , something different and new ? and what about isis ? the line be blur . we live in a world of state , non - state , and in - between , and the more state be weak , like in the middle east today , the more non - state actor step in and fill that gap . this matter for government , because to counter these group , they will have to invest more in non - military tool . fill that governance gap have to be at the center of any sustainable approach . this also matter very much for peacemaking and peacebuilding . if we well understand armed group , we will well know what incentive to offer to encourage the transition from violence to nonviolence .     so in this new contest between state and non - state , military power can win some battle , but it will not give we peace nor stability . to achieve these objective , what we need be a long - term investment in fill that security gap , in fill that governance gap that allow these group to thrive in the first place .     thank you .    what do you do when you have a headache ? you swallow an aspirin . but for this pill to get to your head , where the pain be , it go through your stomach , intestine and various other organ first .     swallow pill be the most effective and painless way of deliver any medication in the body . the downside , though , be that swallow any medication lead to its dilution . and this be a big problem , particularly in hiv patient . when they take their anti - hiv drug , these drug be good for lower the virus in the blood , and increase the cd4 cell count . but they be also notorious for their adverse side effect , but mostly bad , because they get dilute by the time they get to the blood , and bad , by the time they get to the site where it matter most : within the hiv viral reservoir . these area in the body — such as the lymph node , the nervous system , as well as the lung — where the virus be sleep , and will not readily get deliver in the blood of patient that be under consistent anti - hiv drug therapy . however , upon discontinuation of therapy , the virus can awake and infect new cell in the blood .     now , all this be a big problem in treat hiv with the current drug treatment , which be a life - long treatment that must be swallow by patient . one day , I sit and think , " can we deliver anti - hiv directly within its reservoir site , without the risk of drug dilution ?    we be at a tipping point in human history , a specie poise between gain the star and lose the planet we call home .     even in just the past few year , we 've greatly expand our knowledge of how earth fit within the context of our universe . nasa 's kepler mission have discover thousand of potential planet around other star , indicate that earth be but one of billion of planet in our galaxy . kepler be a space telescope that measure the subtle dimming of star as planet pass in front of they , block just a little bit of that light from reach we . kepler 's datum reveal planet ' size as well as their distance from their parent star . together , this help we understand whether these planet be small and rocky , like the terrestrial planet in our own solar system , and also how much light they receive from their parent sun . in turn , this provide clue as to whether these planet that we discover might be habitable or not .     unfortunately , at the same time as we be discover this treasure trove of potentially habitable world , our own planet be sag under the weight of humanity . 2014 be the hot year on record . glacier and sea ice that have be with we for millennium be now disappear in a matter of decade . these planetary - scale environmental   change that we have set in motion be rapidly outpace our ability to alter their course .     but I be not a climate scientist , I be an astronomer . I study planetary habitability as influence by star with the hope of find the place in the universe where we might discover life beyond our own planet . you could say that I look for choice alien real estate .     now , as somebody who be deeply embed in the search for life in the universe , I can tell you that the more you look for planet like earth , the more you appreciate our own planet itself . each one of these new world invite a comparison between the newly discover planet and the planet we know well : those of our own solar system .     consider our neighbor , mars . mars be small and rocky , and though it be a bit far from the sun , it might be consider a potentially habitable world if find by a mission like kepler . indeed , it be possible that mar be habitable in the past , and in part , this be why we study mar so much . our rover , like curiosity , crawl across its surface , scratch for clue as to the origin of life as we know it . orbiter like the maven mission sample the martian atmosphere , try to understand how mar might have lose its past habitability . private spaceflight company now offer not just a short trip to near space but the tantalizing possibility of live our life on mar .     but though these martian vista resemble the desert of our own home world , place that be tie in our imagination to idea about pioneer and frontier , compare to earth mar be a pretty terrible place to live . consider the extent to which we have not colonize the desert of our own planet , place that be lush by comparison with mar . even in the driest , high place on earth , the air be sweet and thick with oxygen exhale from thousand of mile away by our rainforest .     I worry — I worry that this excitement about colonize mar and other planet carry with it a long , dark shadow : the implication and belief by some that mar will be there to save we from the self - inflict destruction of the only truly habitable planet we know of , the earth . as much as I love interplanetary exploration , I deeply disagree with this idea . there be many excellent reason to go to mar , but for anyone to tell you that mar will be there to back up humanity be like the captain of the titanic tell you that the real party be happen later on the lifeboat . ( laughter ) ( applause )     thank you .     but the goal of interplanetary exploration and planetary preservation be not opposed to one another . no , they be in fact two side of the same goal : to understand , preserve and improve life into the future . the extreme environment of our own world be alien vista . they be just close to home . if we can understand how to create and maintain habitable space out of hostile , inhospitable space here on earth , perhaps we can meet the need of both preserve our own environment and move beyond it .     I leave you with a final thought experiment : fermi 's paradox . many year ago , the physicist enrico fermi ask that , give the fact that our universe have be around for a very long time and we expect that there be many planet within it , we should have find evidence for alien life by now . so where be they ? well , one possible solution to fermi 's paradox be that , as civilization become technologically advanced enough to consider live amongst the star , they lose sight of how important it be to safeguard the home world that foster that advancement to begin with . it be hubris to believe that interplanetary colonization alone will save we from ourselves , but planetary preservation and interplanetary exploration can work together .     if we truly believe in our ability to bend the hostile environment of mar for human habitation , then we should be able to surmount the far easy task of preserve the habitability of the earth .     thank you .     ( applause )  
   I be in search of another planet in the universe where life exist . I can not see this planet with my naked eye or even with the most powerful telescope we currently possess . but I know that it be there . and understand contradiction that occur in nature will help we find it .     on our planet , where there be water , there be life . so we look for planet that orbit at just the right distance from their star . at this distance , show in blue on this diagram for star of different temperature , planet could be warm enough for water to flow on their surface as lake and ocean where life might reside . some astronomer focus their time and energy on find planet at these distance from their star . what I do pick up where their job end . I model the possible climate of exoplanet . and here be why that be important : there be many factor besides distance from its star that control whether a planet can support life .     take the planet venus . it be name after the roman goddess of love and beauty , because of its benign , ethereal appearance in the sky . but spacecraft measurement reveal a different story . the surface temperature be close to 900 degree fahrenheit , 500 celsius . that be hot enough to melt lead . its thick atmosphere , not its distance from the sun , be the reason . it cause a greenhouse effect on steroid , trap heat from the sun and scorch the planet 's surface . the reality totally contradict initial perception of this planet . from these lesson from our own solar system , we 've learn that a planet 's atmosphere be crucial to its climate and potential to host life .     we do not know what the atmosphere of these planet be like because the planet be so small and dim compare to their star and so far away from we . for example , one of the close planet that could support surface water — it be call gliese 667 cc — such a glamorous name , right , nice phone number for a name — it be 23 light year away . so that be more than 100 trillion mile . try to measure the atmospheric composition of an exoplanet pass in front of its host star be hard . it be like try to see a fruit fly pass in front of a car 's headlight . ok , now imagine that car be 100 trillion mile away , and you want to know the precise color of that fly .     so I use computer model to calculate the kind of atmosphere a planet would need to have a suitable climate for water and life .     here be an artist 's concept of the planet kepler-62f , with the earth for reference . it be 1,200 light year away , and just 40 percent large than earth . our nsf - fund work find that it could be warm enough for open water from many type of atmosphere and orientation of its orbit . so I would like future telescope to follow up on this planet to look for sign of life .     ice on a planet 's surface be also important for climate . ice absorb long , red wavelength of light , and reflect short , bluer light . that be why the iceberg in this photo look so blue . the red light from the sun be absorb on its way through the ice . only the blue light make it all the way to the bottom . then it gets reflect back to up to our eye and we see blue ice . my model show that planet orbit cooler star could actually be warm than planet orbit hotter star . there be another contradiction — that ice absorb the long wavelength light from cooler star , and that light , that energy , heat the ice .     use climate model to explore how these contradiction can affect planetary climate be vital to the search for life elsewhere .     and it be no surprise that this be my specialty . I be an african - american female astronomer and a classically train actor who love to wear makeup and read fashion magazine , so I be uniquely positioned to appreciate contradiction in nature —     ( laughter )     ( applause )     ... and how they can inform our search for the next planet where life exist .     my organization , rise stargirl , teach astronomy to middle - school girl of color , use theater , writing and visual art . that be another contradiction — science and art do not often go together , but interweave they can help these girl bring their whole self to what they learn , and maybe one day join the rank of astronomer who be full of contradiction , and use their background to discover , once and for all , that we be truly not alone in the universe .     thank you . I 've tell you a little bit about how islamophobia affect I and my family . but how do it impact ordinary american ? how do it impact everyone else ? how do consume fear 24 hour a day affect the health of our democracy , the health of our free thought ?     well , one study — actually , several study in neuroscience — show that when we be afraid , at least three thing happen . we become more accepting of authoritarianism , conformity and prejudice . one study show that when subject be expose to news story that be negative about muslim , they become more accepting of military attack on muslim country and policy that curtail the right of american muslims .     now , this be not just academic . when you look at when anti - muslim sentiment spike between 2001 and 2013 , it happen three time , but it be not around terrorist attack . it be in the run up to the iraq war and during two election cycle . so islamophobia be not just the natural response to muslim terrorism as I would have expect . it can actually be a tool of public manipulation , erode the very foundation of a free society , which be rational and well - inform citizen . muslims be like canary in the coal mine . we might be the first to feel it , but the toxic air of fear be harm we all .    so a few year ago , I do something really brave , or some would say really stupid .    hannah be excited to be go to college . she could not wait to get out of her parent ' house , to prove to they that she be an adult , and to prove to her new friend that she belong .     she head to a campus party where she see a guy that she have a crush on . let us call he mike . the next day , hannah wake up with a pound headache . she can only remember the night in flash . but what she do remember be throw up in the hall outside mike 's room and stare at the wall silently while he be inside she , want it to stop , then shakily stumble home . she do not feel good about what happen , but she think , " maybe this be just what sex in college be ? "     one in five woman and one in 13 man will be sexually assault at some point during their college career in the united states . less than 10 percent will ever report their assault to their school or to the police . and those who do , on average , wait 11 month to make the report .     hannah initially just feel like deal with what happen on her own . but when she see mike take girl home from party , she be worried about they .     after graduation , hannah learn that she be one of five woman who mike do the exact same thing to . and this be not an unlikely scenario because 90 percent of sexual assault be commit by repeat offender . but with such low reporting rate , it be fairly unlikely that even repeat perpetrator will be report , much less anything happen if they be .     in fact , only six percent of assault report to the police end with the assailant spend a single day in prison . mean , there be a 99 percent chance that they 'll get away with it . this mean there be practically no deterrent to assault in the united states .     now , I be an infectious disease epidemiologist by training . I be interested in system and network and where we can concentrate our resource to do the most good . so this , to I , be a tragic but a solvable problem .     so when the issue of campus assault start hit the news a few year ago , it feel like a unique opportunity to make a change . and so we do . we start by talk to college survivor . and what they wish they would have in college be pretty simple ; they want a website , one they could use at the time and place that feel safe to they with clearly write information about their reporting option , with the ability to electronically report their assault , rather than have the first step to go in and talk to someone who may or may not believe they . with the option to create a secure , timestampe document of what happen to they , preserve evidence even if they do not want to report yet . and lastly , and perhaps most critically , with the ability to report their assault only if someone else report the same assailant . you see , know that you be not the only one change everything . it change the way you frame your own experience , it change the way you think about your perpetrator , it mean that if you do come forward , you 'll have someone else 's back and they 'll have your .     we create a website that actually do this and we launch it [ ... ] in august , on two college campus .     and we include a unique matching system where if mike 's first victim have come forward , save her record , enter into the matching system and name mike , and mike 's second victim have do the same thing a few month later , they would have match and the verify contact information of both survivor would have be send to the authority at the same time for investigation and follow up .     if a system like this have exist for hannah and her peer , it be more likely that they would have report , that they would have be believe , and that mike would have be kick off campus , go to jail , or at least get the help that he need . and if we be able to stop repeat offender like mike after just their second assault follow a match , survivor like hannah would never even be assault in the first place . we could prevent 59 percent of sexual assault just by stop repeat perpetrator early on . and because we be create a real deterrent to assault , for perhaps the first time , maybe the mike of the world would never even try to assault anyone .     the type of system I be describe , the type of system that survivor want be a type of information escrow , mean an entity that hold on to information for you and only release it to a third party when certain pre - agree upon condition be meet , such as a match . the application that we build be for college campus . but the same type of system could be use in the military or even the workplace .     we do not have to live in a world where 99 percent of rapist get away with it . we can create one where those who do wrong be hold accountable , where survivor get the support and justice they deserve , where the authority get the information they need , and where there be a real deterrent to violate the right of another human being .     thank you .    extraordinary claim require extraordinary evidence , and it be my job , my responsibility , as an astronomer to remind people that alien hypothesis should always be a last resort .     now , I want to tell you a story about that . it involve datum from a nasa mission , ordinary people and one of the most extraordinary star in our galaxy .     it begin in 2009 with the launch of nasa 's kepler mission . kepler 's main scientific objective be to find planet outside of our solar system . it do this by stare at a single field in the sky , this one , with all the tiny box . and in this one field , it monitor the brightness of over 150,000 star continuously for four year , take a data point every 30 minute . it be look for what astronomer call a transit . this be when the planet 's orbit be align in our line of sight , just so that the planet crosse in front of a star . and when this happen , it block out a tiny bit of starlight , which you can see as a dip in this curve .     and so the team at nasa have develop very sophisticated computer to search for transit in all the kepler datum .     at the same time of the first data release , astronomer at yale be wonder an interesting thing : what if computer miss something ?     and so we launch the citizen science project call planet hunter to have people look at the same datum . the human brain have an amazing ability for pattern recognition , sometimes even well than a computer . however , there be a lot of skepticism around this . my colleague , debra fischer , founder of the planet hunter project , say that people at the time be say , " you be crazy . there be no way that a computer will miss a signal .    how much do you need to know about a person before you would feel comfortable make a loan ?     suppose you want to lend 1,000 dollar to the person sit two row behind you . what would you need to know about that person before you would feel comfortable ?     my mom come to the us from india in her late thirty . she be a doctor in brooklyn , and she often let friend and neighbor come to see she for health service , whether they can pay right away or not . I remember run into her patient with she at the grocery store or on the sidewalk , and sometimes they would come and pay she right on the spot for previous appointment . she would thank they , and ask they about their family and their health . she give they credit because she trust they .     most of we be like my mom . we would give credit to someone we know or that we live next to . but most of we be probably not go to lend to a stranger unless we know a little something about they .     bank , credit card company and other financial institution do not know we on a personal level , but they do have a way of trust we , and that be through our credit score . our credit score have be create through an aggregation and analysis of our public consumer credit datum . and because of they , we have pretty much easy access to all of the good and service that we need , from get electricity to buy a home , or take a risk and start a business .     but ... there be 2.5 billion people around the world that do not have a credit score . that be a third of the world 's population . they do not have a score because there be no formal public record on they — no bank account , no credit history and no social security number . and because they do not have a score , they do not have access to the credit or financial product that can improve their life . they be not trust .     so we want to find a way to build trust and to open up financial access for these 2.5 billion . so we create a mobile application that build credit score for they use mobile datum . there be currently over one billion smartphone in emerge market . and people be use they the same way that we do . they be texte their friend , they be look up direction , they be browse the internet and they be even make financial transaction .     over time , this data be getting capture on our phone , and it provide a really rich picture of a person 's life . our customer give we access to this datum and we capture it through our mobile application . it help we understand the creditworthiness of people like jenipher , a small - business owner in nairobi , kenya . jenipher be 65 year old , and for decade have be run a food stall in the central business district . she have three son who she put through vocational school , and she be also the leader of her local chama , or saving group .     jenipher 's food stall do well . she make just enough every day to cover her expense . but she be not financially secure . any emergency could force she into debt . and she have no discretionary income to improve her family 's way of living , for emergency , or for invest into grow her business . if jenipher want credit , her option be limited . she could get a microloan , but she would have to form a group that could help vouch for her credibility . and even then , the loan size would be way too small to really have an impact on her business , average around 150 dollar . loan shark be always an option , but with interest rate that be well above 300 percent , they be financially risky . and because jenipher do not have collateral or a credit history , she can not walk into a bank and ask for a business loan .     but one day , jenipher 's son convince she to download our application and apply for a loan . jenipher answer a few question on her phone and she give we access to a few key datum point on her device .     and here be what we see . so , bad news first . jenipher have a low saving balance and no previous loan history . these be factor that would have throw up a red flag to a traditional bank . but there be other point in her history that show we a much rich picture of her potential . so for one , we see that she make regular phone call to her family in uganda . well , it turn out that the datum show a four percent increase in repayment among people who consistently communicate with a few close contact . we could also see that though she travel around a lot throughout the day , she actually have pretty regular travel pattern , and she be either at home or at her food stall . and the datum show a six percent increase in repayment among customer who be consistent with where they spend most of their time .     we could also see that she communicate a lot with many different people throughout the day and that she have a strong support network . our datum show that people who communicate with more than 58 different contact tend to be more likely to be good borrower . in jenipher 's case , she communicate with 89 different individual , which show a nine percent increase in her repayment .     these be just some of the thousand of different datum point that we look at to understand a person 's creditworthiness . and after you all of these different data point , we take the first risk and give jenipher a loan . this be datum that would not be find on a paper trail or in any formal financial record . but it prove trust . by look beyond income , we can see that people in emerge market that may seem risky and unpredictable on the surface be actually willing and have the capacity to repay .     our credit score have help we deliver over 200,000 loan in kenya in just the past year . and our repayment rate be above 90 percent — which , by the way , be in line with traditional bank repayment rate .     with something as simple as a credit score , we be give people the power to build their own future . our customer have use their loan for family expense , emergency , travel and for invest back into grow their business . they be now build well economy and community where more people can succeed .     over the past two year of use our product , jenipher have increase her saving by 60 percent . she be also start two additional food stall and be now make plan for her own restaurant . she be apply for a small - business loan from a commercial bank , because she now have the credit history to prove she deserve it .    hello . this be my first trip , first time in life I be outside of the wall of gaza . I be so happy to be here .    design be a slippery and elusive phenomenon , which have mean different thing at different time . but all truly inspire design project have one thing in common : they begin with a dream . and the bold the dream , the great the design feat that will be require to achieve it . and this be why the great designer be almost always the big dreamer and rebel and renegade .     this have be the case throughout history , all the way back to the year 300 bc , when a 13 - year - old become the king of a remote , very poor and very small asian country . he dream of acquire land , rich and power through military conquest . and his design skill — improbable though it sound — would be essential in enable he to do so .     at the time , all weapon be make by hand to different specification . so if an archer run out of arrow during a battle , they would not necessarily be able to fire another archer 's arrow from their bow . this of course mean that they would be less effective in combat and very vulnerable , too . ying solve this problem by insist that all bow and arrow be design identically , so they be interchangeable . and he do the same for dagger , axis , spear , shield and every other form of weaponry . his formidably equip army win batter after battle , and within 15 year , his tiny kingdom have succeed in conquer all its large , rich , more powerful neighbor , to find the mighty chinese empire .     now , no one , of course , would have think of describe ying zheng as a designer at the time — why would they ? and yet he use design unknowingly and instinctively but with tremendous ingenuity to achieve his end . and so do another equally improbable , accidental designer , who be also not above use violence to get what he want . this be edward teach , well know as the british pirate , blackbeard .     this be the golden age of piracy , where pirate like teach be terrorize the high sea . colonial trade be flourish , and piracy be highly profitable . and the smart pirate like he realize that to maximize their spoil , they need to attack their enemy so brutally that they would surrender on sight . so in other word , they could take the ship without waste ammunition , or incur casualty .     so edward teach redesign himself as blackbeard by play the part of a merciless brute . he wear heavy jacket and big hat to accentuate his height . he grow the bushy black beard that obscure his face . he sling brace of pistol on either shoulder . he even attach match to the brim of his hat and set they alight , so they sizzle menacingly whenever his ship be poise to attack . and like many pirate of that era , he fly a flag that bear the macabre symbol of a human skull and a pair of crossed bone , because those motif have signify death in so many culture for century , that their meaning be instantly recognizable , even in the lawless , illiterate world of the high sea : surrender or you 'll suffer . so of course , all his sensible victim surrender on sight .     put like that , it be easy to see why edward teach and his fellow pirate could be see as pioneer of modern communication design , and why their deadly symbol —     ( laughter )     there be more — why their deadly symbol of the skull and crossbone be a precursor of today 's logo , rather like the big red letter stand behind I , but of course with a different message .     ( laughter )     yet design be also use to nobler end by an equally brilliant and equally improbable designer , the 19th - century british nurse , florence nightingale . her mission be to provide decent healthcare for everyone . nightingale be bear into a rather grand , very wealthy british family , who be horrify when she volunteer to work in military hospital during the crimean war . once there , she swiftly realize that more patient be die of infection that they catch there , in the filthy , fetid ward , than they be of battle wound . so she campaign for clean , lighter , airier clinic to be design and build .     back in britain , she mount another campaign , this time for civilian hospital , and insist that the same design principle be apply to they . the nightingale ward , as it be call , dominate hospital design for decade to come , and element of it be still use today . but by then , design be see as a tool of the industrial age . it be formalize and professionalize , but it be restrict to specific role and generally apply in pursuit of commercial goal rather than be use intuitively , as florence nightingale , blackbeard and ying zheng have do .     by the 20th century , this commercial ethos be so powerful , that any designer who deviate from it risk be see as crank or subversive .     now among they be one of my great design hero , the brilliant lászló moholy - nagy . he be the hungarian artist and designer whose experiment with the impact of technology on daily life be so powerful that they still influence the design of the digital image we see on our phone and computer screen . he radicalize the bauhaus design school in 1920s germany , and yet some of his former colleague shun he when he struggle to open a new bauhaus in chicago year later . moholy 's idea be as bold and incisive as ever , but his approach to design be too experimental , as be his insistence on see it , as he put it , as an attitude , not a profession to be in tune with the time .     and sadly , the same apply to another design maverick : richard buckminster fuller . he be yet another brilliant design visionary and design activist , who be completely commit to design a sustainable society in such a forward - think way that he start talk about the importance of environmentalism in design in the 1920 . now he , despite his effort , be routinely mock as a crank by many in the design establishment , and admittedly , some of his experiment fail , like the fly car that never get off the ground . and yet , the geodesic dome , his design formula to build an emergency shelter from scrap of wood , metal , plastic , bit of tree , old blanket , plastic sheeting — just about anything that be available at the time — be one of the great feat of humanitarian design , and have provide sorely need refuge to many , many people in desperate circumstance ever since .     now , it be the courage and verve of radical designer like bucky and moholy that draw I to design . I begin my career as a news journalist and foreign correspondent . I write about politic , economic and corporate affair , and I could have choose to specialize in any of those field . but I pick design , because I believe it be one of the most powerful tool at our disposal to improve our quality of life .     thank you , fellow ted design buff .     ( applause )     and greatly as I admire the achievement of professional designer , which have be extraordinary and immense , I also believe that design benefit hugely from the originality , the lateral thinking and the resourcefulness of its rebel and renegade . and we be live at a remarkable moment in design , because this be a time when the two camp be come close together . because even very basic advance in digital technology have enable they to operate increasingly independently , in or out of a commercial context , to pursue ever more ambitious and eclectic objective .     so in theory , basic platform like crowdfunde , cloud computing , social medium be give great freedom to professional designer and give more resource for the improvisational one , and hopefully , a more receptive response to their idea .     now , some of my favorite example of this be in africa , where a new generation of designer be develop incredible internet of thing technology to fulfill florence nightingale 's dream of improve healthcare in country where more people now have access to cell phone than to clean , running water .     and among they be arthur zang . he be a young , cameroonian design engineer who have a adapt a tablet computer into the cardiopad , a mobile heart - monitor device . it can be use to monitor the heart of patient in remote , rural area . the datum be then send on a cellular network to well - equip hospital hundred of mile away for analysis . and if any problem be spot by the specialist there , a suitable course of treatment be recommend . and this of course save many patient from make long , arduous , expensive and often pointless journey to those hospital , and make it much , much likeli that their heart will actually be check .     arthur zang start work on the cardiopad eight year ago , in his final year at university . but he fail to persuade any conventional source to give he investment to get the project off the ground . he post the idea on facebook , where a cameroonian government official see it and manage to secure a government grant for he . he be now develop not only the cardiopad , but other mobile medical device to treat different condition .     and he be not alone , because there be many other inspiring and enterprising designer who be also pursue extraordinary project of their own . and I be go to finish by look at just a few of they . one be peek vision . this be a group of doctor and designer in kenya , who 've develop an internet of thing technology of their own , as a portable eye examination kit . then there be gabriel maher , who be develop a new design language to enable we to articulate the subtlety of our change gender identity , without recourse to traditional stereotype .     all of these designer and many more be pursue their dream , by the making the most of their newfound freedom , with the discipline of professional designer and the resourcefulness of rebel and renegade . and we all stand to benefit .     thank you .    so this be a talk about gene drive , but I be go to start by tell you a brief story . 20 year ago , a biologist name anthony james got obsess with the idea of make mosquito that do not transmit malaria .     it be a great idea , and pretty much a complete failure . for one thing , it turn out to be really hard to make a malaria - resistant mosquito . james manage it , finally , just a few year ago , by add some gene that make it impossible for the malaria parasite to survive inside the mosquito .     but that just create another problem . now that you 've get a malaria - resistant mosquito , how do you get it to replace all the malaria - carry mosquito ? there be a couple option , but plan a be basically to breed up a bunch of the new genetically - engineer mosquito release they into the wild and hope that they pass on their gene . the problem be that you would have to release literally 10 time the number of native mosquito to work . so in a village with 10,000 mosquito , you release an extra 100,000 . as you might guess , this be not a very popular strategy with the villager .     ( laughter )     then , last january , anthony james get an email from a biologist name ethan bier . bier say that he and his grad student valentino gantz have stumble on a tool that could not only guarantee that a particular genetic trait would be inherit , but that it would spread incredibly quickly . if they be right , it would basically solve the problem that he and james have be work on for 20 year .     as a test , they engineer two mosquito to carry the anti - malaria gene and also this new tool , a gene drive , which I 'll explain in a minute . finally , they set it up so that any mosquito that have inherit the anti - malaria gene would not have the usual white eye , but would instead have red eye . that be pretty much just for convenience so they could tell just at a glance which be which .     so they take their two anti - malarial , red - eyed mosquito and put they in a box with 30 ordinary white - eyed one , and let they breed . in two generation , those have produce 3,800 grandchild . that be not the surprising part . this be the surprising part : give that you start with just two red - eyed mosquito and 30 white - eyed one , you expect mostly white - eyed descendant . instead , when james open the box , all 3,800 mosquito have red eye .     when I ask ethan bi about this moment , he become so excited that he be literally shout into the phone . that be because get only red - eyed mosquito violate a rule that be the absolute cornerstone of biology , mendelian genetic . I 'll keep this quick , but mendelian genetic say when a male and a female mate , their baby inherit half of its dna from each parent . so if our original mosquito be aa and our new mosquito be ab , where b be the anti - malarial gene , the baby should come out in four permutation : aa , ab , aa , ba . instead , with the new gene drive , you all come out ab . biologically , that should not even be possible .     so what happen ? the first thing that happen be the arrival of a gene - editing tool know as crispr in 2012 . many of you have probably hear about crispr , so I 'll just say briefly that crispr be a tool that allow researcher to edit gene very precisely , easily and quickly . it do this by harness a mechanism that already exist in bacteria . basically , there be a protein that act like a scissor and cut the dna , and there be an rna molecule that direct the scissor to any point on the genome you want . the result be basically a word processor for gene . you can take an entire gene out , put one in , or even edit just a single letter within a gene . and you can do it in nearly any specie .     ok , remember how I say that gene drive originally have two problem ? the first be that it be hard to engineer a mosquito to be malaria - resistant . that be basically go now , thank to crispr . but the other problem be logistical . how do you get your trait to spread ? this be where it get clever .     a couple year ago , a biologist at harvard name kevin esvelt wonder what would happen if you make it so that crispr insert not only your new gene but also the machinery that do the cutting and pasting . in other word , what if crispr also copy and paste itself . you would end up with a perpetual motion machine for gene editing . and that be exactly what happen . this crispr gene drive that esvelt create not only guarantee that a trait will get pass on , but if it be use in the germline cell , it will automatically copy and paste your new gene into both chromosome of every single individual . it be like a global search and replace , or in science term , it make a heterozygous trait homozygous .     so , what do this mean ? for one thing , it mean we have a very powerful , but also somewhat alarm new tool . up until now , the fact that gene drive do not work very well be actually kind of a relief . normally when we mess around with an organism 's gene , we make that thing less evolutionarily fit . so biologist can make all the mutant fruit fly they want without worry about it . if some escape , natural selection just take care of they .     what be remarkable and powerful and frightening about gene drive be that that will no long be true . assume that your trait do not have a big evolutionary handicap , like a mosquito that can not fly , the crispr - base gene drive will spread the change relentlessly until it be in every single individual in the population . now , it be not easy to make a gene drive that work that well , but james and esvelt think that we can .     the good news be that this open the door to some remarkable thing . if you put an anti - malarial gene drive in just 1 percent of anophele mosquito , the specie that transmit malaria , researcher estimate that it would spread to the entire population in a year . so in a year , you could virtually eliminate malaria . in practice , we be still a few year out from be able to do that , but still , a 1,000 child a day die of malaria . in a year , that number could be almost zero . the same go for dengue fever , chikungunya , yellow fever .     and it get well . say you want to get rid of an invasive specie , like get asian carp out of the great lake . all you have to do be release a gene drive that make the fish produce only male offspring . in a few generation , there 'll be no female leave , no more carp . in theory , this mean we could restore hundred of native specie that have be push to the brink .     ok , that be the good news , this be the bad news . gene drive be so effective that even an accidental release could change an entire specie , and often very quickly . anthony james take good precaution . he breed his mosquito in a bio - containment lab and he also use a specie that be not native to the we so that even if some do escape , they would just die off , there would be nothing for they to mate with . but it be also true that if a dozen asian carp with the all - male gene drive accidentally got carry from the great lake back to asia , they could potentially wipe out the native asian carp population . and that be not so unlikely , give how connected our world be . in fact , it be why we have an invasive species problem . and that be fish . thing like mosquito and fruit fly , there be literally no way to contain they . they cross border and ocean all the time .     ok , the other piece of bad news be that a gene drive might not stay confine to what we call the target specie . that be because of gene flow , which be a fancy way of say that neighboring specie sometimes interbreed . if that happen , it be possible a gene drive could cross over , like asian carp could infect some other kind of carp . that be not so bad if your drive just promote a trait , like eye color . in fact , there be a decent chance that we 'll see a wave of very weird fruit fly in the near future . but it could be a disaster if your drive be deign to eliminate the specie entirely .     the last worrisome thing be that the technology to do this , to genetically engineer an organism and include a gene drive , be something that basically any lab in the world can do . an undergraduate can do it . a talented high schooler with some equipment can do it .     now , I be guess that this sound terrifying .     ( laughter )     interestingly though , nearly every scientist I talk to seem to think that gene drive be not actually that frightening or dangerous . partly because they believe that scientist will be very cautious and responsible about use they .     ( laughter )     so far , that be be true . but gene drive also have some actual limitation . so for one thing , they work only in sexually reproduce specie . so thank goodness , they can not be use to engineer virus or bacteria . also , the trait spread only with each successive generation . so change or eliminate a population be practical only if that species have a fast reproductive cycle , like insect or maybe small vertebrate like mouse or fish . in elephant or people , it would take century for a trait to spread widely enough to matter .     also , even with crispr , it be not that easy to engineer a truly devastating trait . say you want to make a fruit fly that feed on ordinary fruit instead of rot fruit , with the aim of sabotage american agriculture . first , you would have to figure out which gene control what the fly want to eat , which be already a very long and complicated project . then you would have to alter those gene to change the fly 's behavior to whatever you would want it to be , which be an even long and more complicated project . and it might not even work , because the gene that control behavior be complex . so if you be a terrorist and have to choose between start a gruele basic research program that will require year of meticulous lab work and still might not pan out , or just blow stuff up ? you 'll probably choose the later .     this be especially true because at least in theory , it should be pretty easy to build what be call a reversal drive . that be one that basically overwrite the change make by the first gene drive . so if you do not like the effect of a change , you can just release a second drive that will cancel it out , at least in theory .     ok , so where do this leave we ? we now have the ability to change entire specie at will . should we ? be we god now ? I be not sure I would say that . but I would say this : first , some very smart people be even now debate how to regulate gene drive . at the same time , some other very smart people be work hard to create safeguard , like gene drive that self - regulate or peter out after a few generation . that be great . but this technology still require a conversation . and give the nature of gene drive , that conversation have to be global . what if kenya want to use a drive but tanzania do not ? who decide whether to release a gene drive that can fly ?     I do not have the answer to that question . all we can do go forward , I think , be talk honestly about the risk and benefit and take responsibility for our choice . by that I mean , not just the choice to use a gene drive , but also the choice not to use one . human have a tendency to assume that the safe option be to preserve the status quo . but that be not always the case . gene drive have risk , and those need to be discuss , but malaria exist now and kill 1,000 people a day . to combat it , we spray pesticide that do grave damage to other specie , include amphibian and bird .     so when you hear about gene drive in the come month , and trust I , you will be hear about they , remember that . it can be frightening to act , but sometimes , not act be bad . " but here be the thing : we be already do this in a limited way , and it be already start to make a big difference .     so here be what be happen . now , I tell you I train as a cancer doctor . but like many , many doctor who train in san francisco in the ' 80 , I also train as an aids doctor . it be a terrible time . aids be a death sentence . all my patient die . now , thing be well , but hiv / aids remain a terrible global challenge . worldwide , about 17 million woman be live with hiv . we know that when these woman become pregnant , they can transfer the virus to their baby . we also know in the absence of therapy , half those baby will not survive until the age of two . but we know that antiretroviral therapy can virtually guarantee that she will not transmit the virus to the baby . so what do we do ?     well , a one - size - fit - all approach , kind of like that blast of chemo , would mean we test and treat every pregnant woman in the world . that would do the job . but it be just not practical . so instead , we target those area where hiv rate be the high . we know in certain country in sub - saharan africa we can test and treat pregnant woman where rate be high . this precision approach to a public health problem have cut by nearly half hiv transmission from mother to baby in the last five year . " and that conversation may take place as long as three month after the baby have die . now , put yourself in the shoe of that mom . it be a heartbreaking , excruciating conversation . and even bad — it be not that helpful , because we might know there be a fever or vomiting , but we do not know why . so in the absence of know that knowledge , we can not prevent that mom , that family , or other family in that community from suffer the same tragedy .     but what if we apply a precision public health approach ? let us say , for example , we find out in certain area of africa that baby be die because of a bacterial infection transfer from the mother to the baby , know as group b streptococcus . in the absence of treatment , mom have a seven time high chance that her next baby will die . once we define the problem , we can prevent that death with something as cheap and safe as penicillin . we can do that because then we 'll know . and that be the point : once we know , we can bring the right intervention to the right population in the right place to save life .     with this approach , and with these intervention and other like they , I have no doubt that a precision public health approach can help our world achieve our 15 - year goal . and that would translate into a million baby ' life save every single year . one million baby every single year .     and why would we stop there ? a much more powerful approach to public health — imagine what might be possible . why could not we more effectively tackle malnutrition ? why would not we prevent cervical cancer in woman ? and why not eradicate malaria ? " so let I reassure you : there be a sacred respect for privacy among we , but also a commitment to what we call " radical hospitality " — not the kind advertise by the four season , but the kind that say that every single person be worthy of kindness , full stop , end of sentence .     the big surprise for I of live in a community like this ? I know that I be not a tribute to my great - grandmother , who live such a short and brutish life , if I earn enough money to afford every creature comfort . you can not buy your way out of suffering or into meaning . there be no home big enough to erase the pain that she must have endure .    how many people here would like to live to be at least 80 year old ? yeah . I think we all have this hopeful expectation of live into old age . let us project out into the future , to your future " you be , " and let us imagine that we be all 85 . now , everyone look at two people . one of you probably have alzheimer 's disease .     ( laughter )     alright , alright . and maybe you be think , " well , it will not be I . " then , ok . you be a caregiver . so —     ( laughter )     so in some way , this terrifying disease be likely to affect we all .     part of the fear around alzheimer 's stem from the sense that there be nothing we can do about it . despite decade of research , we still have no disease - modify treatment and no cure . so if we be lucky enough to live long enough , alzheimer 's appear to be our brain 's destiny .     but maybe it do not have to be . what if I tell you we could change these statistic , literally change our brain 's destiny , without rely on a cure or advancement in medicine ?     let us begin by look at what we currently understand about the neuroscience of alzheimer 's . here be a picture of two neuron connect . the point of connection , this space circle in red , be call the synapse . the synapse be where neurotransmitter be release . this be where signal be transmit , where communication happen . this be where we think , feel , see , hear , desire ... and remember . and the synapse be where alzheimer 's happen .     let us zoom in on the synapse and look at a cartoon representation of what be go on . during the business of communicate information , in addition to release neurotransmitter like glutamate into the synapse , neuron also release a small peptide call amyloid beta . normally , amyloid beta be clear away metabolize by microglia , the janitor cell of our brain . while the molecular cause of alzheimer 's be still debate , most neuroscientist believe that the disease begin when amyloid beta begin to accumulate . too much be release , or not enough be clear away , and the synapse begin to pile up with amyloid beta . and when this happen , it bind to itself , form sticky aggregate call amyloid plaque .     how many people here be 40 year old or old ? you be afraid to admit it now . this initial step into the disease , this presence of amyloid plaque accumulate , can already be find in your brain . the only way we could be sure of this would be through a pet scan , because at this point , you be blissfully unaware . you be not show any impairment in memory , language , or cognition ... yet . we think it take at least 15 to 20 year of amyloid plaque accumulation before it reach a tipping point , then trigger a molecular cascade that cause the clinical symptom of the disease . prior to the tipping point , your lapse in memory might include thing like , " why do I come in this room ? " or " oh ... what be his name ? " or " where do I put my key ? "     now , before you all start freak out again , because I know half of you do at least one of those in the last 24 hour — these be all normal kind of forget . in fact , I would argue that these example might not even involve your memory , because you do not pay attention to where you put your key in the first place . after the tipping point , the glitch in memory , language and cognition be different . instead of eventually find your key in your coat pocket or on the table by the door , you find they in the refrigerator , or you find they and you think , " what be these for ? "     so what happen when amyloid plaque accumulate to this tipping point ? our microglia janitor cell become hyper - activate , release chemical that cause inflammation and cellular damage . we think they might actually start clear away the synapsis themselves . a crucial neural transport protein call " tau " become hyperphosphorylated and twist itself into something call " tangle , " which choke off the neuron from the inside . by mid - stage alzheimer 's , we have massive inflammation and tangle and all - out war at the synapse and cell death .     so if you be a scientist try to cure this disease , at what point would you ideally want to intervene ? many scientist be bet big on the simple solution : keep amyloid plaque from reach that tipping point , which mean that drug discovery be largely focused on develop a compound that will prevent , eliminate , or reduce amyloid plaque accumulation . so the cure for alzheimer 's will likely be a preventative medicine . we be go to have to take this pill before we reach that tipping point , before the cascade be trigger , before we start leave our key in the refrigerator . we think this be why , to date , these kind of drug have fail in clinical trial — not because the science be not sound , but because the people in these trial be already symptomatic . it be too late . think of amyloid plaque as a light match . at the tipping point , the match set fire to the forest . once the forest be ablaze , it do not do any good to blow out the match . you have to blow out the match before the forest catch fire .     even before scientist sort this out , this information be actually really good news for we , because it turn out that the way we live can influence the accumulation of amyloid plaque . and so there be thing we can do to keep we from reach that tipping point .     let us picture your risk of alzheimer 's as a see - saw scale . we be go to pile risk factor on one arm , and when that arm hit the floor , you be symptomatic and diagnose with alzheimer 's . let us imagine you be 50 year old . you be not a spring chicken anymore , so you 've accumulate some amyloid plaque with age . your scale be tip a little bit .     now let us look at your dna . we 've all inherit our gene from our mom and our dad . some of these gene will increase our risk and some will decrease it . if you be like alice in " still alice , " you 've inherit a rare genetic mutation that crank out amyloid beta , and this alone will tip your scale arm to the ground . but for most of we , the gene we inherit will only tip the arm a bit . for example , apoe4 be a gene variant that increase amyloid , but you can inherit a copy of apoe4 from mom and dad and still never get alzheimer 's , which mean that for most of we , our dna alone do not determine whether we get alzheimer 's . so what do ? we can not do anything about get old or the gene we 've inherit . so far , we have not change our brain 's destiny .     what about sleep ? in slow - wave deep sleep , our glial cell rinse cerebral spinal fluid throughout our brain , clear away metabolic waste that accumulate in our synapsis while we be awake . deep sleep be like a power cleanse for the brain . but what happen if you shortchange yourself on sleep ? many scientist believe that poor sleep hygiene might actually be a predictor of alzheimer 's . a single night of sleep deprivation lead to an increase in amyloid beta . and amyloid accumulation have be show to disrupt sleep , which in turn cause more amyloid to accumulate . and so now we have this positive feedback loop that be go to accelerate the tipping of that scale .     what else ? cardiovascular health . high blood pressure , diabetes , obesity , smoking , high cholesterol , have all be show to increase our risk of develop alzheimer 's . some autopsy study have show that as many as 80 percent of people with alzheimer 's also have cardiovascular disease . aerobic exercise have be show in many study to decrease amyloid beta in animal model of the disease . so a heart - healthy mediterranean lifestyle and diet can help to counter the tipping of this scale .     so there be many thing we can do to prevent or delay the onset of alzheimer 's . but let us say you have not do any of they . let us say you be 65 ; there be alzheimer 's in your family , so you 've likely inherit a gene or two that tip your scale arm a bit ; you 've be burn the candle at both end for year ; you love bacon ; and you do not run unless someone be chase you .     ( laughter )     let us imagine that your amyloid plaque have reach that tipping point . your scale arm have crash to the floor . you 've trip the cascade , set fire to the forest , cause inflammation , tangle , and cell death . you should be symptomatic for alzheimer 's . you should be have trouble find word and key and remember what I say at the beginning of this talk . but you might not be .     there be one more thing you can do to protect yourself from experience the symptom of alzheimer 's , even if you have the full - blow disease pathology ablaze in your brain . it have to do with neural plasticity and cognitive reserve . remember , the experience of have alzheimer 's be ultimately a result of lose synapsis . the average brain have over a hundred trillion synapsis , which be fantastic ; we 've get a lot to work with . and this be not a static number . we gain and lose you all the time , through a process call neural plasticity . every time we learn something new , we be create and strengthen new neural connection , new synapsis .     in the nun study , 678 nun , all over the age of 75 when the study begin , be follow for more than two decade . they be regularly give physical checkup and cognitive test , and when they die , their brain be all donate for autopsy . in some of these brain , scientist discover something surprising . despite the presence of plaque and tangle and brain shrinkage — what appear to be unquestionable alzheimer 's — the nun who have belong to these brain show no sign of have the disease while they be alive .     how can this be ? we think it be because these nun have a high level of cognitive reserve , which be a way of say that they have more functional synapsis . people who have more year of formal education , who have a high degree of literacy , who engage regularly in mentally stimulating activity , all have more cognitive reserve . they have an abundance and a redundancy in neural connection . so even if they have a disease like alzheimer 's compromise some of their synapsis , they 've get many extra backup connection , and this buffer they from notice that anything be amiss .     let us imagine a simplified example . let us say you only know one thing about a subject . let us say it be about I . you know that lisa genova write " still alice , " and that be the only thing you know about I . you have that single neural connection , that one synapse . now imagine you have alzheimer 's . you have plaque and tangle and inflammation and microglia devour that synapse . now when someone ask you , " hey , who write ' still alice ? ' " you can not remember , because that synapse be either fail or go . you 've forget I forever .     but what if you have learn more about I ? let us say you learn four thing about I . now imagine you have alzheimer 's , and three of those synapsis be damage or destroy . you still have a way to detour the wreckage . you can still remember my name . so we can be resilient to the presence of alzheimer 's pathology through the recruitment of yet - undamaged pathway . and we create these pathway , this cognitive reserve , by learn new thing . ideally , we want these new thing to be as rich in meaning as possible , recruiting sight and sound and association and emotion .     so this really do not mean do crossword puzzle . you do not want to simply retrieve information you 've already learn , because this be like travel down old , familiar street , cruise neighborhood you already know . you want to pave new neural road . build an alzheimer's - resistant brain mean learn to speak italian , meet new friend , read a book , or listen to a great ted talk .     and if , despite all of this , you be someday diagnose with alzheimer 's , there be three lesson I 've learn from my grandmother and the dozen of people I 've come to know live with this disease . diagnosis do not mean you be die tomorrow . keep live . you will not lose your emotional memory . you 'll still be able to understand love and joy . you might not remember what I say five minute ago , but you 'll remember how I make you feel . and you be more than what you can remember .     thank you .
