   let us say you despise western democracy . democracy , in all its trapping , free election , town hall , endless debate about the proper role of government . too messy , too unpredictable , too constrain for your taste . and the way these democracy band together and lecture everyone else about individual right and freedom — it get under your skin .     so what to do about it ? you can call out the hypocrisy and failure of western democracy and explain how your way be well , but that be never really work for you . what if you could get the people whose support be the very foundation of these democracy to start question the system ? make the idea occur in their own mind that democracy and its institution be fail they , their elite be corrupt puppet master and the country they know be in free fall . to do that , you 'll need to infiltrate the information sphere of these democracy . you 'll need to turn their most powerful asset — an open mind — into their great vulnerability . you 'll need people to question the truth .     now , you 'll be familiar of hack and leak that happen in 2016 . one be the democratic national committee 's network , and the personal email account of its staff , later release on wikileak . after that , various online persona , like a suppose romanian cybercriminal who do not speak romanian , aggressively push news of these leak to journalist . the medium take the bait . they be consume by how much the dnc hate bernie . at the time , it be that narrative that far outshine the news that a group of russian government sponsor hacker who we call " advanced persistent threat 28 , " or " apt28 " for short , be carry out these operation against the us .     and there be no shortage of evidence . this group of russian government hacker have not just appear out of nowhere in 2016 . we have start track this group back in 2014 . and the tool that apt28 use to compromise its victim ' network demonstrate a thoughtful , well - resource effort that have take place for now over a decade in moscow 's time zone from about 9 am to 6 pm . apt28 love to prey on the email and contact of journalist in chechnya , the georgian government , eastern european defense attachés — all target with an undeniable interest to the russian government .     we be not the only one onto this . government , research team across the world , be come to similar conclusion and observe the same type of operation . but what russia be do in 2016 go far beyond espionage . the dnc hack be just one of many where steal datum be post online accompany by a sensational narrative , then amplify in social medium for lightning - speed adoption by the medium . this do not ring the alarm bell that a nation - state be try to interfere with the credibility of another 's internal affair .     so why , collectively , do we not see this come ? why do it take month before americans understand that they be under a state - sponsor information attack ? the easy answer be politic . the obama administration be catch in a perfect catch-22 . by raise the specter that the russian government be interfere in the us presidential campaign , the administration risk appear to meddle in the campaign itself . but the well answer , I think , be that the us and the west be utterly unequipped to recognize and respond to a modern information operation , despite the fact that the we have wield information with devastating success in an era not so long ago .     look , so while the us and the west spend the last 20 year catch up in cybersecurity — what network to harden , which infrastructure to deem critical , how to set up army of cyber warrior and cyber command — russia be think in far more consequential term . before the first iphone even hit the shelf , the russian government understand the risk and the opportunity that technology provide and the inter - communication and instant communication it provide we .     as our reality be increasingly base on the information that we be consume at the palm of our hand and from the news feed that we be scan and the hashtag and story that we see trend , the russian government be the first to recognize how this evolution have turn your mind into the most exploitable device on the planet . and your mind be particularly exploitable if you be accustomed to an unfettered flow of information , now increasingly curate to your own taste . this panorama of information that be so interesting to you give a state , or anyone for that matter , a perfect back door into your mind .     it be this new brand of state - sponsor information operation that can be that much more successful , more insidious , and hard for the target audience — that include the medium — to decipher and characterize . if you can get a hashtag trend on twitter , or chum the water with fake news direct to audience prime to receive it , or drive journalist to dissect terabyte of email for a cent of impropriety — all tactic use in russian operation — then you 've get a shot at effectively camouflage your operation in the mind of your target . this be what russia 's long call " reflexive control . " it be the ability to use information on someone else so that they make a decision on their own accord that be favorable to you . this be nation - state - grade image control and perception management , and it be conduct by any mean , with any tool , network - base or otherwise , that will achieve it .     take this for another example . in early february 2014 , a few week before russia would invade crimea , a phone call be post on youtube . in it , there be two us diplomat . they sound like they be play kingmaker in ukraine , and bad , they curse the eu for its lack of speed and leadership in resolve the crisis . the medium cover the phone call , and then the ensue diplomatic backlash leave washington and europe reel . and it create a fissure response and a feckless attitude towards russia 's land grab in ukraine . mission accomplish .     so while hack phone call and email and network keep grab the headline , the real operation be the one that be influence the decision you make and the opinion you hold , all in the service of a nation - state 's strategic interest . this be power in the information age . and this information be all that much more seductive , all that much easy to take at face value and pass on , when it be authentic . who be not interested in the truth that be present in phone call and email that be never intend for public consumption ? vanessa garrison : I be vanessa , daughter of annette , daughter of olympia , daughter of melvina , daughter of katie , bear 1878 , parish county , louisiana .     t. morgan dixon : and my name be morgan , daughter of carol , daughter of letha , daughter of willie , daughter of sarah , bear 1849 in bardstown , kentucky .     vg : and in the tradition of our family , the great oral tradition of almost every black church we know honor the culture from which we draw so much power , we be going to start the way our momma and grandmas would want we to start .     tmd : in prayer . let the word of my mouth , the meditation of our heart , be acceptable in thy sight , oh lord , my strength and my redeemer .     vg : we call the name and ritual of our ancestor into this room today because from they we receive a powerful blueprint for survival , strategy and tactic for healing carry across ocean by african woman , pass down to generation of black woman in america who use those skill to navigate institution of slavery and state - relate disease ?     the question hurt I . I be shake a little bit . it feel value - laden . it hurt my body because the weight represent so much . but we be go to talk about it and invite you into an inside conversation today because it be necessary , and because we need you .     vg : each night , before the first day of school , my grandmother would sit I next to the stove and with expert precision use a hot comb to press my hair . my grandmother be legendary , big , loud . she fill up a room with laughter and oftentime curse word . she cook a mean peach cobbler , have 11 child , a house full of grandchild , and like every black woman I know , like most all woman I know , she have prioritize the care of other over care for herself . we measure her strength by her capacity to endure pain and suffering . we celebrate she for it , and our choice would prove to be deadly . one night after press my hair before the first day of eighth grade , my grandmother go to bed and never wake up , dead at 66 year old from a heart attack . by the time I would graduate college , I would lose two more beloved family member to chronic disease : my aunt diane , dead at 55 , my aunt tricia , dead at 63 . after live with these loss , the hole that they leave , I decide to calculate the life expectancy of the woman in my family . stare back at I , the number 65 . I know I could not sit by and watch another woman I love die an early death .     tmd : so we do not usually put our business in the street . let us just put that out there . but I have to tell you the statistic . black woman be die at alarming rate , and I use to be a classroom teacher , and I be at south atlanta high school , and I remember stand in front of my classroom , and I remember a statistic that half of black girl will get diabetes unless diet and level of activity change . half of the girl in my classroom . so I could not teach anymore . so I start take girl hike , which be why we be call girltrek , but vanessa be like , that be not go to move the dial on the health crisis ; it be cute . she be like , it be a cute hiking club . so what we think be if we could rally a million of their mother ... 82 percent of black woman be over a healthy weight right now . 53 percent of we be obese . but the number that I can not , that I can not get out of my head be that every single day in america , 137 black woman die from a preventable disease , heart disease . that be every 11 minute . 137 be more than gun violence , cigarette smoking and hiv combine , every day . it be roughly the amount of people that be on my plane from new jersey to vancouver . can you imagine that ? a plane fill with black woman crash to the ground every day , and no one be talk about it .     vg : so the question that you be all ask yourself right now be why ? why be black woman die ? we ask ourselves that same question . why be what be out there not work for they ? private weight loss company , government intervention , public health campaign . I be go to tell you why : because they focus on weight loss or look good in skinny jean without acknowledge the trauma that black woman hold in our belly and bone , that have be embed in our very dna . the good advice from hospital and doctor , the good medication from pharmaceutical company to treat the congestive heart failure of my grandmother do not work because they do not acknowledge the systemic racism that she have deal with since birth .     ( applause )     a divestment in school , discriminatory housing practice , predatory lending , a crack cocaine epidemic , mass incarceration put more black body behind bar than be own at the height of slavery .     but girltrek do . for black woman whose body be buckle under the weight of system never design to support they , girltrek be a lifeline . august 16 , 2015 , danita kimball , a member of girltrek in detroit , receive the news that too many black mother have receive . her son norman , 23 year old , a father of two , be gun down while on an afternoon drive . imagine the grief that overcome your body in that moment , the immobilize fear . now , know this , that just day after lay her son to rest , danita kimball post online , " I do not know what to do or how to move forward , but my sister keep tell I I need to walk , so I will . "     tmd : walk through pain be what we have always do . my mom , she be in the middle right there , my mom desegregate her high school in 1955 . her mom walk down the step of an abandon school bus where she raise 11 kid as a sharecropper . and her mom step onto indian territory flee the terror of the jim crow south . and her mom walk her man to the door as he go off to fight in the kentucky color regiment , the civil war . they be bear slave but they would not die slave . change - making , it be in my blood . it be what I do , and this health crisis be not nothing compare to the road we have travel . " woman like susie paige in philadelphia , who after walk daily past an abandon building in her neighborhood , decide , " I be not wait . let I rally my team . let I grab some supply . let I do what no one else have do for I and my community . "     tmd : we know one woman can make a difference , because one woman have already change the world , and her name be harriet tubman . and trust I , I love harriet tubman . I be obsess with she , and I use to be a history teacher . I will not tell you the whole history . I will tell you four thing . so I use to have an old saab — the kind of canvas top that drip on your head when it rain — and I drive all the way down to the eastern shore of maryland , and when I step on the dirt that harriet tubman make her first escape , I know she be a woman just like we be and that we could do what she have do , and we learn four thing from harriet tubman .     the first one : do not wait . walk right now in the direction of your healthiest , most fulfil life , because self - care be a revolutionary act .     number two : when you learn the way forward , come back and get a sister . so in our case , start a team with your friend — your friend , your family , your church .     number three : rally your ally . every single person in this room be complicit in a tubman - inspire takeover .     and number four : find joy . the most underreported fact of harriet tubman be that she live to be 93 year old , and she do not live just an ordinary life ; uh - uh . she be stand up for the good guy . she marry a young man . she adopt a child . I be not kid . she live . and I drive up to her house of freedom in upstate new york , and she have plant apple tree , and when I be there on a sunday , they be bloom . do you call it — do they bloom ? the apple be in season , and I be think , she leave fruit for we , the legacy of harriet tubman , every single year . and we know that we be harriet , and we know that there be a harriet in every community in america .     vg : we also know that there be a harriet in every community across the globe , and that they could learn from our tubman doctrine , as we call it , the four step . imagine the possibility beyond the neighborhood of oakland and newark , to the woman work rice field in vietnam , tea field in sri lanka , the woman on the mountainside in guatemala , the indigenous reservation throughout the vast plain of the dakota . we believe that woman walk and talk together to solve their problem be a global solution .     tmd : and I 'll leave you with this , because we also believe it can become the center of social justice again . vanessa and I be in fort lauderdale . we have an organizer training , and I be leave and I get on the airplane , and I see someone I know , so I wave , and as I be wait in that long line that you guy know , wait for people to put their stuff away , I look back and I realize I do not know the woman but I recognize she . and so I blow she a kiss because it be sybrina fulton , trayvon martin 's mom , and she whisper " thank you " back to I . and I can not help but wonder what would happen if there be group of woman walk on trayvon 's block that day , or what would happen in the south side of chicago every day if there be group of woman and mother and aunt and cousin walk , or along the polluted river of flint , michigan .    my seven - year - old grandson sleep just down the hall from I , and he wake up a lot of morning and he say , " you know , this could be the good day ever . " and other time , in the middle of the night , he call out in a tremulous voice , " nana , will you ever get sick and die ? "     I think this pretty much say it for I and most of the people I know , that we be a mixed grill of happy anticipation and dread . so I sit down a few day before my 61st birthday , and I decide to compile a list of everything I know for sure . there be so little truth in the popular culture , and it be good to be sure of a few thing .     for instance , I be no long 47 , although this be the age I feel , and the age I like to think of myself as be . my friend paul use to say in his late 70 that he feel like a young man with something really wrong with he .     ( laughter )     our true person be outside of time and space , but look at the paperwork , I can , in fact , see that I be bear in 1954 . my inside self be outside of time and space . it do not have an age . I be every age I 've ever be , and so be you , although I can not help mention as an aside that it might have be helpful if I have not follow the skin care rule of the ' 60 , which involve get as much sun as possible while slather in baby oil and bask in the glow of a tinfoil reflector shield . be go to get ? well , to a large extent , it be because they do not agree on what cloud will do in the future . and that be because , just like I , computer hate cloud . computer hate cloud because    loneliness . all of we in this room will experience loneliness at some point in our life . loneliness be not a function of be alone , but rather , a function of how socially connect you be to those around you . there could be somebody in this room right now surround by a thousand people experience loneliness . and while loneliness can be attribute to many thing , as an architect , I be go to tell you today how loneliness can be the result of our build environment — the very home we choose to live in .     let us take a look at this house . it be a nice house . there be a big yard , picket fence , two - car garage . and the home might be in a neighborhood like this . and for many people around the globe , this home , this neighborhood — it be a dream . and yet the danger of achieve this dream be a false sense of connection and an increase in social isolation . look after one another . in cohousing , you have your own home , but you also share significant space , both indoor and out . before I show you some picture of cohousing , I would like to first " or a cry from one of the kid . these be the sound of our daily life , and the sound of social connectedness . at the bottom of the courtyard , there be a set of double door , and those lead into the common house .     I consider the common house the secret sauce of cohousing . it be the secret sauce because it be the place where the social interaction and community life begin , and from there , it radiate out through the rest of the community . inside our common house , we have a large dining room to seat all 28 of we and our guest , and we dine together three time a week . in support of those meal , we have a large kitchen so that we can take turn cook for each other in team of three . so that mean , with 17 adult , I lead cook once every six week . two other time , I show up and help my team with the preparation and cleanup . and all those other night , I just show up . " communita . " communita be a fancy social science way of say " spirit of community . everyone — all age , all gender , all nationality — be old or future - old , and unless we put an end to it , ageism will oppress we all . and that make it a perfect target for collective advocacy .     why add another -ism to the list when so many , racism in particular , call out for action ? I be in it , and I hope you will join I .     ( applause and cheer )     thank you . let us do it ! let us do it !     ( applause )

   here be an intriguing fact . in the develop world , everywhere , woman live an average of six to eight year long than man do . six to eight year long . that be , like , a huge gap . in 2015 , the " lancet " publish an article show that man in rich country be twice as likely to die as woman be at any age .     but there be one place in the world where man live as long as woman . it be a remote , mountainous zone , a blue zone , where super longevity be common to both sex . this be the blue zone in sardinia , an italian island in the mediterranean , between corsica and tunisia , where there be six time as many centenarian as on the italian mainland , less than 200 mile away . there be 10 time as many centenarian as there be in north america . it be the only place where man live as long as woman .     but why ? my curiosity be pique . I decide to research the science and the habit of the place , and I start with the genetic profile . I discover soon enough that gene account for just 25 percent of their longevity . the other 75 percent be lifestyle .     so what do it take to live to 100 or beyond ? what be they do right ? what you be look at be an aerial view of villagrande . it be a village at the epicenter of the blue zone where I go to investigate this , and as you can see , architectural beauty be not its main virtue , density be : tightly space house , interwoven alley and street . it mean that the villager ' life constantly intersect . and as I walk through the village , I could feel hundred of pair of eye watch I from behind doorway and curtain , from behind shutter . because like all ancient village , villagrande could not have survive without this structure , without its wall , without its cathedral , without its village square , because defense and social cohesion define its design .     urban priority change as we move towards the industrial revolution because infectious disease become the risk of the day . but what about now ? now , social isolation be the public health risk of our time . now , a third of the population say they have two or few people to lean on .     but let us go to villagrande now as a contrast to meet some centenarian .     meet giuseppe murinu . he be 102 , a supercentenarian and a lifelong resident of the village of villagrande . he be a gregarious man . he love to recount story such as how he live like a bird from what he could find on the forest floor during not one but two world war , how he and his wife , who also live past 100 , raise six child in a small , homey kitchen where I interview he . here he be with his son angelo and domenico , both in their 70 and look after their father , and who be quite frankly very suspicious of I and my daughter who come along with I on this research trip , because the flip side of social cohesion be a wariness of stranger and outsider . but giuseppe , he be not suspicious at all . he be a happy - go - lucky guy , very outgoing with a positive outlook . and I wonder : so be that what it take to live to be 100 or beyond , think positively ?    I use to think the whole purpose of life be pursue happiness . everyone say the path to happiness be success , so I search for that ideal job , that perfect boyfriend , that beautiful apartment . but instead of ever feel fulfilled , I feel anxious and adrift . and I be not alone ; my friend — they struggle with this , too .     eventually , I decide to go to graduate school for positive psychology to learn what truly make people happy . but what I discover there change my life . the datum show that chase happiness can make people unhappy . and what really strike I be this : the suicide rate have be rise around the world , and it recently reach a 30 - year high in america . even though life be get objectively well by nearly every conceivable standard , more people feel hopeless , depressed and alone . there be an emptiness gnaw away at people , and you do not have to be clinically depressed to feel it . soon or later , I think we all wonder : be this all there be ? and accord to the research , what predict this despair be not a lack of happiness . it be a lack of something else , a lack of have meaning in life .     but that raise some question for I . be there more to life than be happy ? and what be the difference between be happy and have meaning in life ? many psychologist define happiness as a state of comfort and ease , feel good in the moment . mean , though , be deep . the renowned psychologist martin seligman say meaning come from belong to and serve something beyond yourself and from develop the good within you . our culture be obsess with happiness , but I come to see that seek meaning be the more fulfilling path . and the study show that people who have meaning in life , they be more resilient , they do well in school and at work , and they even live long .     so this all make I wonder : how can we each live more meaningfully ? to find out , I spend five year interview hundred of people and read through thousand of page of psychology , neuroscience and philosophy . bring it all together , I find that there be what I call four pillar of a meaningful life . and we can each create life of meaning by build some or all of these pillar in our life .     the first pillar be belong . belong come from be in relationship where you be value for who you be intrinsically and where you value other as well . but some group and relationship deliver a cheap form of belong ; you be value for what you believe , for who you hate , not for who you be . true belong spring from love . it live in moment among individual , and it be a choice — you can choose to cultivate belong with other .     here be an example . each morning , my friend jonathan buy a newspaper from the same street vendor in new york . they do not just conduct a transaction , though . they take a moment to slow down , talk , and treat each other like human . but one time , jonathan do not have the right change , and the vendor say , " do not worry about it . " but jonathan insist on pay , so he go to the store and buy something he do not need to make change . but when he give the money to the vendor , the vendor draw back . he be hurt . he be try to do something kind , but jonathan have reject he .     I think we all reject people in small way like this without realize it . I do . I 'll walk by someone I know and barely acknowledge they . I 'll check my phone when someone be talk to I . these act devalue other . they make they feel invisible and unworthy . but when you lead with love , you create a bond that lift each of you up .     for many people , belong be the most essential source of meaning , those bond to family and friend . for other , the key to meaning be the second pillar : purpose . now , find your purpose be not the same thing as find that job that make you happy . purpose be less about what you want than about what you give . a hospital custodian tell I her purpose be heal sick people . many parent tell I , " my purpose be raise my child . " the key to purpose be use your strength to serve other . of course , for many of we , that happen through work . that be how we contribute and feel need . but that also mean that issue like disengagement at work , unemployment , low labor force participation — these be not just economic problem , they be existential one , too . without something worthwhile to do , people flounder . of course , you do not have to find purpose at work , but purpose give you something to live for , some " why " that drive you forward .     the third pillar of meaning be also about step beyond yourself , but in a completely different way : transcendence . transcendent state be those rare moment when you be lift above the hustle and bustle of daily life , your sense of self fade away , and you feel connected to a high reality . for one person I talk to , transcendence come from see art . for another person , it be at church . for I , I be a writer , and it happen through writing . sometimes I get so in the zone that I lose all sense of time and place . these transcendent experience can change you . one study have student look up at 200 - foot - tall eucalyptus tree for one minute . but afterwards they feel less self - center , and they even behave more generously when give the chance to help someone .     belong , purpose , transcendence . now , the fourth pillar of meaning , I 've find , tend to surprise people . the fourth pillar be storytelle , the story you tell yourself about yourself . create a narrative from the event of your life bring clarity . it help you understand how you become you . but we do not always realize that we be the author of our story and can change the way we be tell they . your life be not just a list of event . you can edit , interpret and retell your story , even as you be constrain by the fact .     I meet a young man name emeka , who have be paralyze playing football . after his injury , emeka tell himself , " my life be great playing football , but now look at I . " people who tell story like this — " my life be good . now it be bad . " — tend to be more anxious and depressed . and that be emeka for a while . but with time , he start to weave a different story . his new story be , " before my injury , my life be purposeless . I partie a lot and be a pretty selfish guy . but my injury make I realize I could be a well man . " that edit to his story change emeka 's life . after tell the new story to himself , emeka start mentor kid , and he discover what his purpose be : serve other . the psychologist dan mcadams call this a " redemptive story , " where the bad be redeem by the good . people lead meaningful life , he be find , tend to tell story about their life define by redemption , growth and love .     but what make people change their story ? some people get help from a therapist , but you can do it on your own , too , just by reflect on your life thoughtfully , how your defining experience shape you , what you lose , what you gain . that be what emeka do . you will not change your story overnight ; it could take year and be painful . after all , we 've all suffer , and we all struggle . but embrace those painful memory can lead to new insight and wisdom , to find that good that sustain you .     belong , purpose , transcendence , storytelle : those be the four pillar of meaning . when I be young , I be lucky enough to be surround you all of the pillar . my parent run a sufi meetinghouse from our home in montreal . sufism be a spiritual practice associate with the whirling dervish and the poet rumi . twice a week , sufis would come to our home to meditate , drink persian tea , and share story . their practice also involve serve all of creation through small act of love , which mean be kind even when people wrong you . but it give they a purpose : to rein in the ego .     eventually , I leave home for college and without the daily grounding of sufism in my life , I feel unmoored . and I start search for those thing that make life worth live . that be what set I on this journey . look back , I now realize that the sufi house have a real culture of meaning . the pillar be part of the architecture , and the presence of the pillar help we all live more deeply .     of course , the same principle apply in other strong community as well — good one and bad one . gang , cult : these be culture of meaning that use the pillar and give people something to live and die for . but that be exactly why we as a society must offer well alternative . we need to build these pillar within our family and our institution to help people become their good self . but live a meaningful life take work . it be an ongoing process . as each day go by , we be constantly create our life , add to our story . and sometimes we can get off track .     whenever that happen to I , I remember a powerful experience I have with my father . several month after I graduate from college , my dad have a massive heart attack that should have kill he . he survive , and when I ask he what be go through his mind as he face death , he say all he could think about be need to live so he could be there for my brother and I , and this give he the will to fight for life . when he go under anesthesia for emergency surgery , instead of count backwards from 10 , he repeat our name like a mantra . he want our name to be the last word he speak on earth if he die .     my dad be a carpenter and a sufi . it be a humble life , but a good life . lie there face death , he have a reason to live : love . his sense of belong within his family , his purpose as a dad , his transcendent meditation , repeat our name — these , he say , be the reason why he survive . that be the story he tell himself .     that be the power of meaning . happiness come and go . but when life be really good and when thing be really bad , have meaning give you something to hold on to .     thank you .    in my early day as a graduate student , I go on a snorkeling trip off the coast of the bahama . I would actually never swum in the ocean before , so it be a bit terrifying . what I remember the most be , as I put my head in the water and I be try really hard to breathe through the snorkel , this huge group of stripe yellow and black fish come straight at I ... and I just freeze . and then , as if it have suddenly change its mind , come towards I and then swerve to the right and go right around I . it be absolutely mesmerizing . maybe many of you have have this experience . of course , there be the color and the beauty of it , but there be also just the sheer oneness of it , as if it be not hundred of fish but a single entity with a single collective mind that be make decision . when I look back , I think that experience really end up determine what I 've work on for most of my career .     I be a computer scientist , and the field that I work in be artificial intelligence . and a key theme in ai be be able to understand intelligence by create our own computational system that display intelligence the way we see it in nature . now , most popular view of ai , of course , come from science fiction and the movie , and I be personally a big star war fan . but that tend to be a very human - centric view of intelligence . when you think of a fish school , or when I think of a flock of starling , that feel like a really different kind of intelligence . for starter , any one fish be just so tiny compare to the sheer size of the collective , so it seem that any one individual would have a really limited and myopic view of what be go on , and intelligence be not really about the individual but somehow a property of the group itself .     secondly , and the thing that I still find most remarkable , be that we know that there be no leader supervise this fish school . instead , this incredible collective mind behavior be emerge purely from the interaction of one fish and another . somehow , there be these interaction or rule of engagement between neighboring fish that make it all work out .     so the question for ai then become , what be those rule of engagement that lead to this kind of intelligence , and of course , can we create our own ?     and that be the primary thing that I work on with my team in my lab . we work on it through theory , look at abstract rule system and think about the mathematic behind it . we also do it through biology , work closely with experimentalist . but mostly , we do it through robotic , where we try to create our own collective system that can do the kind of thing that we see in nature , or at least try to .     one of our first robotic quest along this line be to create our very own colony of a thousand robot . so very simple robot , but they could be program to exhibit collective intelligence , and that be what we be able to do . so this be what a single robot look like . it be quite small , about the size of a quarter , and you can program how it move , but it can also wirelessly communicate with other robot , and it can measure distance from they . and so now we can start to program exactly an interaction , a rule of engagement between neighbor . and once we have this system , we can start to program many different kind of rule of engagement that you would see in nature .     so for example , spontaneous synchronization , how audience be clap and suddenly start all clap together , the firefly flash together . we can program rule for pattern formation , how cell in a tissue determine what role they be go to take on and set the pattern of our body . we can program rule for migration , and in this way , we be really learn from nature 's rule .     but we can also take it a step far . we can actually take these rule that we 've learn from nature and combine they and create entirely new collective behavior of our very own .     so for example , imagine that you have two different kind of rule . so your first rule be a motion rule where a move robot can move around other stationary robot . and your second rule be a pattern rule where a robot take on a color base on its two near neighbor . so if I start with a blob of robot in a little pattern seed , it turn out that these two rule be sufficient for the group to be able to self - assemble a simple line pattern . and if I have more complicated pattern rule , and I design error correction rule , we can actually create really , really complicated self assembly , and here be what that look like .     so here , you be go to see a thousand robot that be work together to self - assemble the letter k. the k be on its side . and the important thing be that no one be in charge . so any single robot be only talk to a small number of robot nearby it , and it be use its motion rule to move around the half - build structure just look for a place to fit in base on its pattern rule . and even though no robot be do anything perfectly , the rule be such that we can get the collective to do its goal robustly together . and the illusion become almost so perfect , you know — you just start to not even notice that they be individual robot at all , and it become a single entity , kind of like the school of fish .     so these be robot and rule in two dimension , but we can also think about robot and rule in three dimension . so what if we could create robot that could build together ? and here , we can take inspiration from social insect . so if you think about mound - building termite or you think about army ant , they create incredible , complex nest structure out of mud and even out of their own body . and like the system I show you before , these insect actually also have pattern rule that help they determine what to build , but the pattern can be make out of other insect , or it could be make out of mud . and we can use that same idea to create rule for robot .     so here , you be go to see some simulated robot . so the simulated robot have a motion rule , which be how it traverse through the structure , look for a place to fit in , and it have pattern rule where it look at group of block to decide whether to place a block . and with the right motion rule and the right pattern rule , we can actually get the robot to build whatever we want . and of course , everybody want their own tower .     ( laughter )     so once we have these rule , we can start to create the robot body that go with these rule . so here , you see a robot that can climb over block , but it can also lift and move these block and it can start to edit the very structure that it be on . but with these rule , this be really only one kind of robot body that you could imagine . you could imagine many different kind of robot body . so if you think about robot that maybe could move sandbag and could help build levee , or we could think of robot that build out of soft material and work together to shore up a collapse building — so just the same kind of rule in different kind of body . or if , like my group , you be completely obsess with army ant , then maybe one day we can make robot that can climb over literally anything include other member of their tribe , and self - assemble thing out of their own body . once you understand the rule , just many different kind of robot vision become possible .     and come back to the snorkeling trip , we actually understand a great deal about the rule that fish school use . so if we can invent the body to go with that , then maybe there be a future where I and my group will get to snorkel with a fish school of our own creation .     each of these system that I show you bring we close to have the mathematical and the conceptual tool to create our own version of collective power , and this can enable many different kind of future application , whether you think about robot that build flood barrier or you think about robotic bee colony that could pollinate crop or underwater school of robot that monitor coral reef , or if we reach for the star and we think about program constellation of satellite . in each of these system , be able to understand how to design the rule of engagement and be able to create good collective behavior become a key to realize these vision .     so , so far I 've talk about rule for insect and for fish and for robot , but what about the rule that apply to our own human collective ? and the last thought that I would like to leave you with be that science be of course itself an incredible manifestation of collective intelligence , but unlike the beautiful fish school that I study , I feel we still have a much long evolutionary path to walk . so in addition to work on improve the science of robot collective , I also work on create robot and think about rule that will improve our own scientific collective . there be this saying that I love : who do science determine what science gets do . imagine a society where we have rule of engagement where every child grow up believe that they could stand here and be a technologist of the future , or where every adult believe that they have the ability not just to understand but to change how science and technology impact their everyday life . what would that society look like ? I believe that we can do that . I believe that we can choose our rule , and we engineer not just robot but we can engineer our own human collective , and if we do and when we do , it will be beautiful .     thank you .    back home , my friend call I nickname , such as " the giant clam girl , " " clam queen , " or , " the mother of clams . "     ( laughter )     this be because every time I see they , I talk nonstop about giant clam all day , every day . giant clam be these massive and colorful shell marine animal , the large of its kind . just look at this shell . the big record individual be four - and - a - half - foot long and weigh about 550 pound . that be almost as heavy as three baby elephant .     south pacific legend once describe giant clam as man - eater that would lie in wait on the seabed to trap unsuspecting diver . a story go that a diver have lose his leg while try to retrieve a pearl from a giant clam . I think , " really ? " so out of curiosity , I do an experiment use myself as bait .     ( laughter )     I carefully place my hand into the clam 's mouth and wait . hmm ... I still have my hand . it seem that these gentle giant would rather retreat and protect their fleshy body than feed on I . so much for those killer clam myth !     unfortunately , the reality be , we be the giant clam ' big threat . consider a delicacy throughout the western pacific and indian ocean , giant clam have be traditionally fish as seafood . fisherman be particularly interested in their adductor muscle , which be organ that hold the two shell together like a hinge . just for their muscle , giant clam be almost hunted to extinction between the 1960 and 1980 . clamshell be also popular in the ornamental trade as jewelry and for display . in the south china sea , fisherman go out of their way to collect fossilize clamshell by dig through large area of coral reef . these be later carve and sell as so - call " ivory handicraft " in china . giant clams , dead or alive , be not safe from we . it be a " clamity ! "     ( laughter )     ( applause )     with the spotlight on more charismatic marine animal such as the whale and coral reef , it be easy to forget that other marine life need our help , too . my fascination with giant clam get I start on conservation research to fill in the knowledge gap on their ecology and behavior . one of the discovery that we make be that giant clam could walk across the seafloor . yes , you hear I right : they can walk .     to find out , we place numerous baby clam on a grid . now watch what happen over 24 hour . we think that walking be important for get away from predator and finding mate for breeding . while it can hard to imagine any movement in these enormous animal , giant clam up to 400 pound can still walk , they just move slow .     during my phd , I discover more secret about the giant clams . but there be something miss in my work . I find myself ask , " why should people care about conserve giant clam ? " — other than myself , of course .     ( laughter )     it turn out that giant clam have a giant impact on coral reef . these multitasking clam be reef builder , food factory , shelter for shrimp and crab and water filter , all roll into one . in a nutshell , giant clam play a major contributing role as resident of their own reef home , and just have they around keep the reef healthy . and because they can live up to 100 year old , giant clam make vital indicator of coral reef health . so when giant clam start to disappear from coral reef , their absence can serve as an alarm bell for scientist to start pay attention , similar to the canary in a coal mine . but giant clam be endanger . the large clam in the world be face the threat of extinction , with more than 50 percent of the wild population severely deplete . and the ecological benefit of have giant clam on coral reef be likely to continue only if population be healthy , make their conservation paramount .     so I stand here today to give a voice to the giant clam , because I care a whole lot for these amazing animal , and they deserve to be care for . it be time for the giant clam to step out of their shell , and show the world that they , too , can be the hero of the ocean .     thank you very much . I find myself in a similar situation . when I be an architecture student about 13 year ago , I go to bangladesh to a remote village call rudrapur with the aim to design and build a school as my thesis project . ( laughter )     yeah , and the great thing be , if an earth wall be not need anymore , it can go back to the ground it come from , turn into a garden , or get fully recycle without any loss of quality . there be no other material that can do this , and this be why mud be so excellent in term of environmental performance .     what about the economic sustainability ? when we build the school , I practically live on the construction site , and in the evening , I use to go with the worker to the market , and I could see how they spend their money . and they would buy the vegetable from their neighbor , they would get a new haircut or a new blouse from the tailor . and because the main part of the building budget be spend on craftsmanship , the school be not just a building , it become a real catalyst for local development , and that make I happy . if I have design the school in cement and steel , this money would have be export and lose for those family .    when be I be 21 year old , I have all this physics homework . physics homework require take break , and wikipedia be relatively new , so I take a lot of break there . I do learn on wikipedia that the greenland ice sheet be huge , the size of mexico , and its ice from top to bottom be two mile thick . but it be not just static . the ice flow like a river downhill towards the ocean . as it flow around bend , it deform and crack .     I get to study these amazing ice dynamic , which be locate in one of the most remote physical environment remain on earth . to work in glaciology right now be like get in on the ground floor at facebook in the 2000s .     ( laughter )     our capability to fly airplane and satellite over the ice sheet be revolutionize glaciology . it be just start to do for science what the smartphone have do for social medium .     the satellite be report a wealth of observation that be reveal new hide fact about the ice sheet continuously . for instance , we have observation of the size of the greenland ice sheet every month go back to 2002 . you can look towards the bottom of the screen here to see the month and the year go forward . you can see that some area of the ice sheet melt or lose ice in the summer . other area experience snowfall or gain ice back in the winter . this seasonal cycle , though , be eclipse by an overall rate of mass loss that would have stun a glaciologist 50 year ago . we never think that an ice sheet could lose mass into the ocean this quickly . since these measurement begin in 2002 , the ice sheet have lose so much ice that if that water be pile up on our small continent , it would drown australia knee - deep . how be this possible ? well , under the ice lie the bedrock . we use radar to image the hill , valley , mountain and depression that the ice flow over . hide under the ice sheet be channel the size of the grand canyon that funnel ice and water off of greenland and into the ocean .     the reason that radar can reveal the bedrock be that ice be entirely transparent to radar . you can do an experiment . go home and put an ice cube in the microwave . it will not melt , because microwave , or radar , pass straight through the ice without interact . if you want to melt your ice cube , you have to get it wet , because water heat up easily in the microwave . that be the whole principle the microwave oven be design around . radar can see water . and radar have reveal a vast pool of liquid water hide under my colleague olivia , seven story beneath her foot . here , she be use a pump to bring some of that water back to the ice sheet 's surface .     just six year ago , we have no idea this glaci aquifer exist . the aquifer form when snow melt in the summer sun and trickle downward . it puddle up in huge pool . from there , the snow act as an igloo , insulate this water from the cold and the wind above . so the water can stay hidden in the ice sheet in liquid form year after year . the question be , what happen next ? do the water stay there forever ? it could . or do it find a way out to reach the global ocean ? one possible way for the water to reach the bedrock and from there the ocean be a crevasse , or a crack in the ice . when crack fill with water , the weight of the water force they deeply and deep . this be how fracking work to extract natural gas from deep within the earth . pressurize fluid fracture rock . all it take be a crack to get start .     well , we recently discover that there be crack available in the greenland ice sheet near this glaci aquifer . you can fly over most of the greenland ice sheet and see nothing , no crack , no feature on the surface , but as this helicopter fly towards the coast , the path that water would take on its quest to flow downhill , one crack appear , then another and another . be these crack fill with liquid water ? and if so , how deep do they take that water ? can they take it to the bedrock and the ocean ? to answer these question , we need something beyond remote sense datum . we need numeric model .     I write numeric model that run on supercomputer . a numeric model be simply a set of equation that work together to describe something . it can be as simple as the next number in a sequence — one , three , five , seven — or it can be a more complex set of equation that predict the future base on know condition in the present . in our case , what be the equation for how ice crack ? well , engineer already have a very good understanding of how aluminum , steel and plastic fracture under stress . it be an important problem in our society . and it turn out that the engineering equation for how material fracture be not that different from my physics homework . so I borrow they , adapt they for ice , and then I have a numeric model for how a crevasse can fracture when fill with water from the aquifer . this be the power of math . it can help we understand real process in our world .     I 'll show you now the result of my numeric model , but first I should point out that the crevasse be about a thousand time narrow than it be deep , so in the main panel here , we 've zoom in to well see the detail . you can look to the small panel on the right to see the true scale for how tall and skinny the crevasse be .     as the aquifer water flow into the crevasse , some of it refreeze in the negative 15 degree celsius ice . that be about as cold as your kitchen freezer . but this loss can be overcome if the flow rate in from the glaci aquifer be high enough . in our case , it be , and the aquifer water drive the crevasse all the way to the base of the ice sheet a thousand meter below . from there , it have a clear path to reach the ocean . so the aquifer water be a part of the three millimeter per year of sea level rise that we experience as a global society .     but there be more : the aquifer water might be punch above its weight . the ice flow in complex way . in some place , the ice flow very fast . there tend to be water at the base of the ice sheet here . in other place , not so fast . usually , there be not water present at the base there .     now that we know the aquifer water be get to the base of the ice sheet , the next question be : be it make the ice itself flow fast into the ocean ? we be try to uncover these mystery hide inside the greenland ice sheet so that we can well plan for the sea level rise it hold . the amount of ice that greenland have lose since 2002 be just a small fraction of what that ice sheet hold .     ice sheet be immense , powerful machine that operate on long timescale . in the next 80 year , global sea level will rise at least 20 centimeter , perhaps as much as one meter , and maybe more . our understanding of future sea level rise be good , but our projection have a wide range . it be our role as glaciologist and scientist to narrow these uncertainty .     how much sea level rise be come , and how fast will it get here ? we need to know how much and how fast , so the world and its community can plan for the sea level rise that be come .     thank you .    after decade of research and billion of dollar spend in clinical trial , we still have a problem with cancer drug delivery . we still give patient chemotherapy , which be so non - specific that even though it kill the cancer cell , it kind of kill the rest of your body , too . and yes , we have develop more selective drug , but it be still a challenge to get they into the tumor , and they end up accumulate in the other organ as well or pass through your urine , which be a total waste . and field like mine have emerge where we try to encapsulate these drug to protect they as they travel through the body . but these modification cause problem that we make more modification to fix .     so what I be really try to say be we need a well drug delivery system . and I propose , rather than use solely human design , why not use nature 's ?     immune cell be these versatile vehicle that travel throughout our body , patrol for sign of disease and arrive at a wound mere minute after injury . so I ask you guy : if immune cell be already travel to place of injury or disease in our body , why not add an extra passenger ? why not use immune cell to deliver drug to cure some of our big problem in disease ?     I be a biomedical engineer , and I want to tell you guy a story about how I use immune cell to target one of the large problem in cancer . do you know that over 90 percent of cancer death can be attribute to its spread ? so if we can stop these cancer cell from go from the primary tumor to a distant site , we can stop cancer right in its track and give people more of their life back .     to do this special mission , we decide to deliver a nanoparticle make of lipid , which be the same material that compose your cell membrane . and we 've add two special molecule . one be call e - selectin , which act as a glue that bind the nanoparticle to the immune cell . and the second one be call trail . trail be a therapeutic drug that kill cancer cell but not normal cell . now , when you put both of these together , you have a mean kill machine on wheel .     to test this , we run an experiment in a mouse . so what we do be we inject the nanoparticle , and they bind almost immediately to the immune cell in the bloodstream . and then we inject the cancer cell to mimic a process through which cancer cell spread throughout our body . and we find something very exciting . we find that in our treat group , over 75 percent of the cancer cell we initially inject be dead or die , in comparison to only around 25 percent . so just imagine : these few amount of cell be available to actually be able to spread to a different part of the body . and this be only after two hour of treatment .     our result be amazing , and we have some pretty interesting press . my favorite title be actually , " sticky ball may stop the spread of cancer . "     ( laughter )     I can not tell you just how smug my male colleague be , know that their sticky ball might one day cure cancer .     ( laughter )     but I can tell you they make some pretty , pretty , exciting , pretty ballsy t - shirt .     this be also my first experience talk to patient where they ask how soon our therapy would be available . and I keep these story with I to remind I of the importance of the science , the scientist and the patient .     now , our fast - act result be pretty interesting , but we still have one linger question : can our sticky ball , our particle actually attach to the immune cell , actually stop the spread of cancer ? so we go to our animal model , and we find three important part . our primary tumor be small in our treat animal , there be few cell in circulation , and there be little to no tumor burden in the distant organ .     now , this be not just a victory for we and our sticky ball . this be also a victory to I in drug delivery , and it represent a paradigm shift , a revolution — to go from just use drug , just inject they and hope they go to the right place in the body , to use immune cell as special delivery driver in your body . for this example , we use two molecule , e - selectin and trail , but really , the possibility of drug you can use be endless .     and I talk about cancer , but where disease go , so do immune cell . so this could be use for any disease . imagine use immune cell to deliver crucial wound - heal agent after a spinal cord injury , or use immune cell to deliver drug past the blood - brain barrier to treat parkinson 's or alzheimer 's disease .     these be the idea that excite I about science the most . and from where I stand , I see so much promise and opportunity .     thank you .    I be often ask why I do art , what do I want to say with my art photography , and what be the use of it ? once in a while I start to worry how to actually measure the impact from the art like we do with medicine or technology , where we can see the result and calculate it . then I would finally be able to explain to my mother my art with real number . but my art be so far from metric , and moreover , my photography be widely expose the theme of escapism .     my theory be that all of we struggle sometimes to escape in order to analyze our reality , appreciate it or change . I do not work with daily life as it be , and I be not a documentary photographer in the common sense . but I be a documentary photographer in a different sense . I document dream . I work with daily life as it could be , as I imagine it . I be a daydreamer , but at the same time I love thing that be authentic and deal with our innermost nature , which I would never want to escape from . I adore complicated personality , and real life inspire I to create my image . real life inspire our escape , and sometimes that escape be very needed .     I believe hero be not create easily , and I choose to work with individual who be survivor and face everyday routine that be not always full of color , people who be on their way to a well life , fight against life circumstance .     why do I choose people like that for my model ? because I 've be in that position myself , when I have to learn how to survive in real life . I be a student live abroad in london . I be work at two place at the same time as a waitress . obviously that be not my dream job , but I decide to play a game where I imagine that I be take a role in a film , and in the film I be a waitress , and I need to act great . I use to dye my hair and brow to gingerette , I change my hair to curly perm , I lose weight and make myself believe I be just a character act in a film . that be not forever , that be all just temporary . that help I a lot . it motivate I to change my life and take a hard time as a game . now , as an artist , I be create different life for my model in order to give they the experience of be someone else in reality . through the photographic process , all of my model become like silent movie actor . they be capture at the moment when they believe in be someone else entirely .     in order to create a new reality in its entirety , I physically create every single thing in my work , sometimes from outfit to the stage . because I work with analogue , and I do not make any digital manipulation to my photograph , I need everything to take place in reality , in spite of the fact that nowadays , digitally , you can create pretty much everything . I do not like this path . even if that reach perfection , I see the beauty in authenticity of making , and that be impossible without flaw . a digitally manipulate photograph be not true for I . it do not capture anything real . it be not experienced , not motivate . it be like , instead of go travel , you look at someone else 's travel photograph .     what I find so exciting be the ability to make people 's dream of be someone else a reality . that be like a drug which push I to keep work , even without metric .     one of my model have always dream of be see as a warrior , but she be not able to do sport because of her health problem . half a year ago , she pass away from heart disease at the age of 22 . but two day before her death , the image we spend month work on together of she as a warrior she dream of become be publish at a large exhibition in milan by vogue magazine . all her life be about overcome . before she die , she have know that thousand of people see her image from the land of escapism and believe in she as a brave and fearless warrior .     for my work , I invite people to play a game like we all use to as child when we pretend to be someone else and that process make we really happy . to my mind it be important for grown - up . we need these transformation to enact this in the name of art . it give we the very real feeling of be important and powerful in order to influence our reality . I know this from my own personal experience . I have have so many version of myself through my self - portrait that I 've be many different character .     be someone else in the land of escapism do not exactly give we number that we can gauge , but it be like a real lose form of magic which exist but can not be measure . there be a unique power in art to transform and lift our limit . art create what I call a conjured life , which help our existence and push , motivate and inspire we to dwell and express ourselves without metric or calculation .     thank you .
